mnemonics.meaning: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means fat.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means favor.

You use black dirt to make black ink. That's what you use to write in black! Make sure the dirt you're using to make black ink is really, really black. Like the kind you find around volcanoes or something.
mnemonics.reading: Be careful that you don't spill black ink on anyone or anything. If you do, you have to own it. Imagine spilling black ink on someone, and when they confront you, you yell, "Yeah I got black ink on you, so sue me (すみ)!" Imagine yelling "SUE ME!" at someone's face, which is covered in the black ink you spilled there.

mnemonics.meaning: Your eye gets kicked with a cleat that came careening toward your forehead when it popped off someone doing a dance, and you blink. Well, of course you blink, you can't control that. And when a cleat come hurtling toward your eye it blinks automatically.
mnemonics.reading: You blink and blink and soon (しゅん) there are tears coming out of them too. You try to blink them away but it's not working. Soon you're crying and blinking and crying some more. Soon the person who's cleat hit you is running over and trying to apologize and stop your crying, but it's too late.

mnemonics.meaning: If a tsunami wraps around itself, the resulting wave will create a lot of bubbles. You know how tsunamis wrap around once gravity kicks in, right? Well when that wave crashes, a whole lot of bubbles are created. Picture the bubbles bursting out of the wrapped up tsunami as it crashes down. The air that the tsunami sucked in while it was wrapping up come out as bubbles big and small.
mnemonics.reading: One of the biggest bubbles heads straight for your home (ほう), engulfs it, and picks it up into the air! Watch helplessly as your home, now trapped in a bubble, floats away into the sky.

mnemonics.meaning: Some grains get stuck in his cleat, and Wolverine's heart grows calm. Wolverine had been screaming and yelling and stomping around, but when the grains entered his cleat he realized where he was. He was finally able to calm down. He's calm now because he stomped right into a farmer's field (thus the rice) and if he didn't calm down he'd probably ruin it.
mnemonics.reading: Now that Wolverine is calm, tears come to his eyes. Being calm has given him perspective on what his anger has done. Oh, wait no. There are just some onions (おん) in his cleats too, and they're making calm tears trickle down his eyes. Picture Wolverine sitting calmly in this field, onions causing tears to stream down his cheeks as he reflects on what he's done.

mnemonics.meaning: You see a child with an umbrella in front of you. Suddenly, they fall straight down into a cavity in the road. It's a big hole! You run over to where the child fell. They are just fine! Because they had an umbrella, they were able to float to the bottom.
mnemonics.reading: "Into my cavity you go!" yells a voice. It is こういち.  "You will stay in that cavity and/or hole until you repent." If it hasn't been clear up until now, Emperor こういち is going mad with power.

mnemonics.meaning: This tree is very odd, to say the least. The shape is all crazy, like a lightning bolt stuck into the ground, or something. Oh wait, look at this. I can sit on it really nicely. It's just like a chair! Imagine this odd tree chair being the most comfortable chair you've ever sat on. It's shaped perfectly for you, and the moss makes it soft. Wow, what a chair.
mnemonics.reading: But, this odd tree chair is also home to an eagle (い). It swoops down upon you as you sit down, gouging your eyes out. Feel the fear and regret. You should have known not to sit in this "chair". Mother nature never forgives, and now you don't have eyeballs.

mnemonics.meaning: If you pick certain rice or flowers you'll be put in prison. The most famous of these is the chrysanthemum. Chrysanthemums are super important in Japan because they're the symbol of the imperial family. They're even on the cover of Japanese passports. If you get caught picking a chrysanthemum, you're going to prison. Chrysanthemums are really important to the Japanese people. Please don't ever pick them (or rice, because that's stealing food, someone planted that)!
mnemonics.reading: If you go to prison for chrysanthemum picking, everyone in the prison is going to kick (きく) you nonstop. You broke the chrysanthemum picking law, so kicking is your punishment. And believe me, you don't want these kicks. Imagine holding a chrysanthemum in your hands while you get kicked over and over and over in prison. Was it worth it?

mnemonics.meaning: A tsunami causes the capital to become very cool. The capital was already a pretty cool temperature, but with the addition of the water from the tsunami, the capital is now very cool. Imagine being in the capital. The tsunami hits and now you are all wet. You are also very cool because the water is not warm. You are cool and wet. How sad.
mnemonics.reading: You don’t like how cool it is in the capital now so you decide to get in your row (りょう) boat and row away to some place that is not so cool. Get in your row boat and row away! Imagine rowing in your row boat. The more you row, the less cool it gets. Feel your arms strain as you do so. It’s all worth it!

mnemonics.meaning: The white thread in your towel comes from cotton. We use cotton to make lots of things, like clothes and bedsheets. But white towels are always made from soft, fluffy cotton. Imagine shoving your face into a nice, clean, white cotton towel. Mmm, so fresh.
mnemonics.reading: This cotton is made by men (めん). Picture all of the men lined up, making towels out of pure white cotton. They're all rubbing their faces in the soft cotton whenever they can.

mnemonics.meaning: Below the canopy of trees is a demon. This demon is a devil. You thought the devil hangs out in hell, but he actually hangs out under this canopy of trees.
mnemonics.reading: Why is the devil under a canopy of trees? Because he's looking for his mama (ま). Into the trees is where all mamas go missing. And so the devil searches for his mama under this canopy of trees.

mnemonics.meaning: You need to bring charcoal under this roof to heat the dormitory. You live in this dormitory with a bunch of other kids, and you all have to take turns bringing in the charcoal from outside to heat it. Imagine looking at a dormitory chore wheel and seeing it's your turn to carry in the charcoal this week. Bleh!
mnemonics.reading: The dormitory is on an island, so when you go out to get the charcoal you have to take a row (りょう) boat. You row and row and row until you reach the shed with all the charcoal. Then you row and row and row it back to the dormitory. The dormitory row boat leaks a little too, so by the time you get back you really need to light the charcoal and heat up!

mnemonics.meaning: There are nine birds and one of them is a dove and another is a pigeon. These nine birds are a flock of all kinds, but the dove and the pigeon are the leaders. Look at these nine birds strutting down the street like they own the place. The dove and pigeon are out in front because they are the most important. Hear them chirping and fluttering their feathers about.
mnemonics.reading: Take a look at the pigeon in front of you. Now, grab it, tear it in half, and grab the heart (はと) from its little body.  Devour it. You love pigeon hearts. Discard the rest, keep the heart.

mnemonics.meaning: Make barracks out of gold and they will get dull quickly. Gold is soft, it's okay for jewelry and delicate things that aren't used much, but barracks for soldiers? Those are used constantly, and they get worn out easily. What was once shiny gold will go dull in days. Picture a huge barracks made of dull, almost brown, gold. Maybe you should have picked a better material.
mnemonics.reading: As you stare sadly at the dull barracks, the don (どん) shows up out of nowhere, and he's pissed. He turns his angry gaze toward you and says, "How did my barracks get so dull? Are you at fault? This is bad, this is very bad. Someone will pay for this." You stand cowering in front of the don as he inspects how dull the gold barracks are. You don't wanna be off'd for this just because the don was dull enough to make you use gold!

mnemonics.meaning: You want to turn your gold comb into a weapon, so you throw it into the forge. Once the gold comb has melted down in the forge, you can forge it into whatever weapon you want.
mnemonics.reading: You're trying to work the forge, but it's harder than you thought. You end up forging outside all day and get a wicked tan (たん). Most people who do forge work have tans. And now you know why.

mnemonics.meaning: A crab moves a stone because he is playing the game Go. You know this game, right? You put black or white stones on a board until you win the game. This is the Japanese game known as Go. This crab is pretty good. Look at this crab placing stones on the Go board. Hear them click and clack as the crab places them with expert precision.
mnemonics.reading: Go is pronounced Go (ご) in Japanese, too. How convenient is that? Like, super convenient. So easy even a crab could remember! Go is Go. Easy!

mnemonics.meaning: When you get sick you always eat a hot pepper. It's a habit you've picked up and you can't seem to shake it. One sniffle, one cough, and before you know it, you're eating a hot pepper or two. Imagine if you had a habit of eating hot peppers whenever you thought you might be getting sick. To be fair, it flushes out your sinuses and tastes good, so it's not the worst habit you could have.
mnemonics.reading: Everyone you know has a different habit when they get sick. Instead, they eat couscous (くせ). But you think couscous is gross. It's bland and does nothing for your stuffy noses and scratchy throats. I wonder how you can convince them to replace their habit with your own. Unfortunately, now you've gotten into the habit of telling everyone what to do when they get sick. "Yeah, yeah, eat a hot pepper, we know. But couscous is better," they say before you can speak. To each their own, I suppose.

mnemonics.meaning: The part of the grain people favor the most is the head of the plant. You don't eat the stems and leaves of rice or wheat plants, right? You eat the head where the grains are. Imagine yourself walking through a field of rice plants. Now look very closely at the head of the plant in front of you. See the rice bunched up there? That's the good stuff.
mnemonics.reading: When you want to harvest the head of the plant you'd like to eat, you need to use a hoe (ほ). Using a hoe, you can dig up the bottom of the plant without injuring the head. Imagine working in a field of rice and using a hoe so you don't injure the head of the plant. You're sweating and it's hot, but you keep at it.

mnemonics.meaning: I have five things in my mouth and I need them all for me. I own these five things, and I keep them in my mouth so people like you cannot take them from me. What five things would you keep in your mouth to protect them from me? Imagine these five things in your mouth and think of how important they are to you as you taste them on your tongue.
mnemonics.reading: Me, personally, I am quite thirsty so I ask for some “waga” (わが). I have five things in my mouth, so it is hard for me to pronounce the word “water”. So it sounds like “waga” when I ask for it. “Coulg I pweash hab sum waga?! I deed waga!!” Imagine how you would sound asking for “waga” with your mouth full of five things. You can carry out this experiment in real life if you would like, just be careful not to choke, okay?

mnemonics.meaning: You take some gold and cover your yoga brush in it, turning it into a key. You shove the brush you normally use for yoga into the lock to your car and pour the gold over it. Now it's the right shape to be a key! You lost your old key, you see. But you're a go with the flow type of person, thanks to all the yoga, so you make a new one!
mnemonics.reading: This key has to be perfect, because if it isn't the car guillotine (かぎ) will come down and chop off your hand! Imagine carefully putting your makeshift key into your car's lock. You close your eyes and pray that the car guillotine isn't going to trigger, knowing it isn't a legit key.

mnemonics.meaning: I found part of a plate at the lantern festival, and put it on a tray to keep it safe. There is a legendary plate broken into three parts. One part of the plate I found was at the lantern festival. The lantern festival was pretty cool, but I’m really glad I found the part of that plate I was looking for. Imagine holding a tray in your hands with this part of the plate on it, as the light from the lanterns glitters off it and dances around, illuminating the background. It’s enchanting.
mnemonics.reading: The plate part you found at the lantern festival (and put on the tray) is made out of bone (ぼん) china. How fancy. Is bone china made from real bones? Bones found in China? Probably not, huh. Tap this bone china plate with your knuckle. Hear the pleasant tap as you continue to view all the fancy lanterns around you at the festival.

mnemonics.meaning: You're standing under a canopy when you see something strange sticking out of the dirt. You pull it, but it won't budge. You pull harder and harder until the dirt starts rumbling and a giant manor starts rising out of the ground with you on top! Picture yourself on top of this manor that rose out of the ground. The canopy is still above you and it seems to be attached to the roof.
mnemonics.reading: The beautiful manor begins to shake and the shougun bursts out of the front door. "WHO HAS UNEARTHED MY SECRET MANOR?!" he screams. Imagine being chased by an angry shougun all through his giant, luxurious manor. You barely have time to admire the interior design with him gaining on you like this!

mnemonics.meaning: An animal that kicks dirt into people's mouths is a monkey. Monkeys are naughty little things. You should be happy it was just dirt it kicked into your mouth, and not something worse. Imagine looking at a monkey at the zoo. Aww, it's so cute. But then it turns around and kicks some dirt right into your aww-ing mouth. Yuck! Why monkey, why?!
mnemonics.reading: You spit the dirt out of your mouth and look back at the monkey to see that it's saluting (さる) you. Is... is it mocking you? Picture the monkey saluting you as you spit dirt out of your mouth. Taste the bitter dirt and the bitter shame. You were played by a monkey.

mnemonics.meaning: There’s a tree in the east that looks like a pillar. The tree is tall and straight and does not have any leaves or branches. The tree is basically a big wooden pillar that just happens to be alive still. Look at this big tree pillar over in the east. You always know where east is because of it.
mnemonics.reading: That pillar happens to be in the center of とうきょう. If you need to find east (which is where とうきょう is), you just look for the pillar. Imagine looking down on とうきょう from atop this magnificent pillar. The sun is rising behind you, slowly illuminating the city below.

mnemonics.meaning: "Say 'big,' ground beggar! Have pride!"  You are trying to tell a beggar on the ground to say they are big, because you want to make the beggar feel a little pride. "Have pride in your job as a beggar!" you tell them.
mnemonics.reading: After giving some pride to the ground beggar, he looks up at you and tears off his beard and skin. "I am a 子 (こ) again, thanks to you!" I'm not sure why gaining pride made the beggar revert back to being a child, but it seems like you did something good, maybe?

mnemonics.meaning: Inside your eye stands a tiny village that makes up your pupil. That's the black part of your eye! Oh, did you think your pupil was a hole? No, no, you misunderstand. That's where the village stands. It's full of little people who whisper to your brain what you should see.
mnemonics.reading: All of the people in your pupil eat doughnuts (どう) all day long. That's why your eye is shaped like a doughnut, with the "hole" (village) as their home. Even if you're a pupil non-believer, at least you can see how it's shaped like a doughnut hole, right?

mnemonics.meaning: On the roof is your heart. OR! In a net in the street. Which would you rather? Would you rather have your heart up on the roof, close to falling but out of the way of people. Or would you rather have your heart in a net, which people can't steal from, but is in the way of cars.
mnemonics.reading: As you try to decide which you'd rather have, your neighbors (ねい) come out and grab the heart out of your hands. "I'd rather you didn't have that!" you shout as your neighbors run through the neighborhood to their own house. You'd rather this wasn't happening! You'd rather your neighbors let you make your own choice!!

mnemonics.meaning: The leader of your sad life aims a kick at the sack you are holding. This leader is in charge of making your life sad. The next step in the leader making your life suck is attempting to kick your sack out of your hands. Your sack holds all your valuables, so it’s not something you want to have kicked. See this leader’s kick coming at your sack. Hear the leader yelling as he aims his kick at your sack. Hiyahhh! Also keep in mind that the life radical is missing the little drop/slide thing on the side. It’s missing that because your life is lousy and sad.
mnemonics.reading: You manage to get your sack out of the way as you shout “Heyo (ひょう)! Look, you missed! Heyo!” Unfortunately your leader’s friend was standing behind you and he kicks your sack as you move it out of the way. “Heyo!” he shouts, mockingly. You thought you were all cool saying “heyo” and moving your sack away from the kick, but they had this planned all along. Heyo…

mnemonics.meaning: Poop Poop Mountain is covered in poop because it is such a secluded place. A secluded place has no toilets, so you just poop right on the mountain.
mnemonics.reading: The secluded Poop Poop Mountain is a favorite of youths (ゆう). They go there to get away from their phones to get in touch with nature again.  Imagine hundreds of youths on this secluded mountain, all pooping on the ground while trying to get a cell phone signal.

mnemonics.meaning: With the power of your mouth you command a tree to become a shelf. Most of the time one would have to use their hands and tools to turn a tree into a shelf, but you are capable of turning a tree into a shelf by using the power of your mouth. Imagine using your mouth to turn a tree into a shelf. Yell at this tree and keep yelling at it until you see it become a shelf.
mnemonics.reading: Once you turn the tree into a shelf you put the shelf in your car (か) and sell it at a local pawn shop. You keep doing this over and over again until you are rich. You command the trees to turn into shelves and then you take the shelves in your car to sell them. Easy money. Imagine transporting the shelves in your car. Over and over. Back and forth in your car. Vroom vroom.

mnemonics.meaning: Your village wants to take the village dog and boil it, and you can think of no other response than SHUT UP!  The entire village is shouting and yelling and pointing at the poor dog. They're boiling a giant boiling pot of water, and you can't even hear yourself think anymore. Shut up, shut up, shut up!
mnemonics.reading: The villagers are mad that you told them to shut up, and they start to mock (もく) you. They put their hands on their hips, lean forward, cross their eyes, and yell "SHUT UP!" back. Even the dog is mocking you now. It's barks sound more like "shut up, shut up" than "bow wow, bow wow." What the heck dog, I was trying to save your life!

mnemonics.meaning: You use your car and an axe to slice down a pedestrian. This innocent guy is just walking along the road when you drive up to him in your car and axe him to death with your axe. You’re all like, VROOM! AXE! Now this guy is dead because you sliced him down in cold blood. Imagine driving your car, waving your axe out the window and slicing this guy down. Hear his scream ring in your ears as you slice, slice, SLICE.
mnemonics.reading: You were driving around in Zanzibar (ざん) when you sliced down this man. Luckily, Zanzibar has no laws at all, so you won’t get arrested for slicing down this guy with your axe. Zanzibar is a crazy place, huh? Continue to drive around Zanzibar as you wave your axe out your car window looking for another victim to slice.

mnemonics.meaning: You stand your towel up so everyone can see it. This announces that you are the sovereign ruler of this bathroom. Whenever someone walks into your bathroom, you start screaming that you are the sovereign ruler of this toilet, this sink, this toothbrush, and all that touch these tiles.
mnemonics.reading: As the sovereign ruler of this bathroom, you must choose a monogram to represent your rule. For this, you choose the symbol of the food that passes through you the most: The mighty tater (てい) tot! Picture your standing towel with a huge tater tot sewn into it. Everyone who sees this will know that you're the toilet tater tot sovereign.

mnemonics.meaning: Someone with a top hat comes and tells you that your grains are going to be taxed from now on. Top hat man says there is a tariff that's been enacted on grains. Rice? Triple the price. Wheat? Quadruple. People in top hats like to put tariffs on lots of things. Especially things you need, like grains you eat to stay alive. You have no choice but to pay.
mnemonics.reading: You're listening to all the things in this tariff and you finally get fed up and ask what isn't being taxed now. The top hat man looks at you and smiles, holding out his hand. In his hand is some soap (そ). Everything you get from other counties has been tariffed except for soap. You'll be hungry, but at least you'll be clean.

mnemonics.meaning: The gold from the east needs tempering before it can be sold. The gold from the east is good, it just needs some tempering before it’s entirely presentable. You know, tempering like you’d do in a forge. Imagine tempering this gold from the east. You’re heat treating the gold when you’re tempering it, so feel the heat from the fire on your face and arms.
mnemonics.reading: The smithy where you’re doing the tempering is pretty fancy, but it’s just a rental (れん). You haven’t sold enough gold to own a smithy as nice as this one yet, so for now, you rent one. It is pretty swanky though, even for a rental. Imagine yourself in this rental smithy. It’s really nice. There’s like TVs and live music and free WiFi and everything. It’s a very nice rental in which to do tempering. Also keep in mind that this kanji shares its reading with 練, which has the same right side.

mnemonics.meaning: If you see a building wearing a giant top hat, beware! This building is a fake and it's trying to thwart all of the plans the people in other buildings have. Picture the building, with it's tall top hat, inching closer to other buildings when no one is looking. It's planning to thwart everything!
mnemonics.reading: The building next door is being painted, and the top hat building is jealous. It thwarts the painting plans by dumping soap (そ) out of its windows and onto the painters and the building! Watch as the soap cleans all of the paint away, thwarting the entire paint project. The painters are on the ground, crying and squeaky clean.

mnemonics.meaning: You need to stop a drunkard from going down a slide with a jackhammer to ask him how many years old he is. He's doing a lot of dangerous things right now, and they all have age limits. Depending how many years old he is, this guy could be violating like three different laws right now.
mnemonics.reading: When you ask him how many years old he is, he turns to you and screams, "I'M A MILLION YEARS OLD AND YOU'LL NEVER STOP ME!" That's obviously not how old this kid is, so you take out your holy blue saber (せい) and slice the slide in half. Then the jackhammer. Then the kid's metal arm—wait! This kid is a cyborg (さい)! Your saber cuts through the cyborgs robo-body and it screams, "OKAY OKAY I'M NOT A MILLION I'M ONLY FIVE YEARS OLD AND A CYBORG PLEASE DON'T REPROGRAM ME!"

mnemonics.meaning: You get rain orders. Your orders are to make sure there is zero spill. Despite it raining, your orders are to make sure none (zero!) of the rain spills anywhere. Figure out what you need to do to make sure you follow these rain orders successfully. Zero spill, alright?
mnemonics.reading: The best way to make sure there is zero spill when it rains is to get rid of the rain. You use a special ray (れい) gun and zap the rain right out of the sky. There will be zero spills because there will be zero rain. You just take your ray gun and "zap!" the clouds are gone. There will be zero spills today. Hint: when you see the radical orders it's fairly likely the reading will be れい.

mnemonics.meaning: A blink is a blink and a wink as well, depending on how many eyes you use.
mnemonics.reading: A wink is all it takes to get the "Ma butter" (まばた) from the store. It's hidden, and they only bring it out if you do the wink.

sentences: 瞬きせずに、この絵を見続けてください。
Don’t blink and just keep looking at the picture please.

mnemonics.meaning: Energy bubbles are bubbles filled with the "energy" that's all around us (air). That's why this is an air bubble.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 一番最初にしなくちゃいけないことが、陶芸用の粘土から気泡を取り除くことです。
The first thing we have to do is remove the air bubbles from the pottery clay.

mnemonics.meaning: The art of tempering gold. That is alchemy.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ある錬金術士が鉛を金に変えようとして失敗した日、外は雨がザザ降りでした。
The rain poured down outside on the day the alchemist utterly failed at transforming lead into gold.

mnemonics.meaning: A blink interval of time is a very short period of time. It's an instant or a moment.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 蜘蛛の巣にぶつかった瞬間に、人は突然空手の達人へと変身する。
The moment they walk into a spider web, people suddenly turn into karate experts.

mnemonics.meaning: One blink is one instant. That is an instant or a moment.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 「お前には捕まらないぞ！」「捕まえたっ！」「うわっ！速い！一瞬だったな。でも、大人げないよ。子どもなんだからもう少し手加減してよ。」
"You’ll never catch me!" "Gotcha!" "What! That was fast! You caught me in an instant, but that’s childish. You should go a little easier on your kid."

mnemonics.meaning: Years old you have entered. These are your yearly (years old) amounts of money you've entered into the coffers. These are the annual revenue.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: どの政府にも、特別歳入基金はあるものなのですか。
Does every government have a special revenue fund?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji itself means habit but it usually refers to a bad habit, so try to remember that meaning if you could.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 突き指が癖になってしまっているんです。
I’ve fallen into the habit of spraining my fingers.

mnemonics.meaning: Ten thousand years old! That's a lot of time. This is the word for the turned-English Japanese phrase, banzai!
mnemonics.reading: The reading isn't the same as 万's normal reading. It's ばん instead of まん. But, since the word "banzai" is so well known, you probably can remember this reading.

sentences: トフグのコウイチに万歳三唱をしましょう！万歳！万歳！万歳！
Three cheers for Koichi of Tofugu! Hip hip hooray! Hip hip hooray! Hip hip hooray!

mnemonics.meaning: Zero below is below zero. Sub zero.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 零下十度だろうが二十度だろうがに関係なく、洗い物はここでします。
It doesn’t matter if it’s ten or twenty below zero, we do our wash here.

mnemonics.meaning: The devil art is black magic and sorcery. The kind of things that devils do.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 「好き嫌いしないの！黒魔術だけじゃなくて白魔術もちゃんと勉強しなさい！」「はいはい。いつも同じこと言ってるよね。」「"はい"は一回でしょ！」
"Don’t be so picky! You shouldn’t just study black magic, but white magic too!" "Yeah, yeah. You always say that." "One yeah is enough!"

mnemonics.meaning: You're using a dull container as a blunt weapon. It's all you have to hand.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 毎月の鈍器代はいくらですか。
How much do you spend on blunt weapons every month?

mnemonics.meaning: A dormitory student (comes from 学生) is a boarding student or a boarder. This is a student who lives in a dormitory.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 「新しい寮生はセクシー？」「ああ、セクシーだよ。フグなんて、すでに彼女に熱を上げているよ。」
"Is the new boarding student sexy?" "Yup, she is. Fugu’s got the hots for her already."

mnemonics.meaning: A write shelf is a shelf with writing on it. That's a bookshelf or bookcase.

mnemonics.meaning: The tariff of the world is a concession or settlement. That's just how the world works.

mnemonics.meaning: Secluded and closed off, putting you in confinement and imprisonment.

mnemonics.meaning: The shelf, once established, makes up the construction and building of the building. Just think of a building that's being built. It looks like a little shelf, doesn't it? That's important because this type of construction usually goes over something between two things, like a bridge.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今まで一度も橋梁を架設したことがありません。

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of cool? It's cool (or refreshing).

sentences: 残念ながら、今日はとても涼しかった。

mnemonics.meaning: A cool wind is a cool breeze.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

mnemonics.meaning: Cotton that comes off a tree is still cotton!

mnemonics.meaning: A cotton cloth is a cotton cloth of cotton material.

sentences: 水をよく吸収するので、私は綿布を布巾に使います。

mnemonics.reading: The reading can be either the kun'yomi or on'yomi reading, so you have a choice there. Let's learn the わた reading, though. Just think what (わた) is cotton? What is it? What does it mean? Ask a lot of "what" questions about cotton to yourself.

sentences: 綿菓子が大好きなんです。
I love cotton candy.
手芸用の綿はどこで買えますか？
Where can I buy cotton material for handicrafts?
ヌイグルミから綿がはみ出ている。
The cotton is sticking out of this stuffed animal

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how 揚げる can mean "to deep fry?" Something that was deep fried and then put in front of you is deep fried.

sentences: これは出来たてホカホカの美味しい揚げ出し豆腐ですよ。

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: 今は「魔の二歳児」ですからねー。

mnemonics.meaning: A bad devil is a devil (because they're all bad), or a demon or satan.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of dull? It's dull.
mnemonics.reading: To remember the reading, think about how when you're inebriated (にぶ) you need to use a dull knife. The にぶい reading talks about a thing that is dull. For のろい, which refers to a dull mind (someone who's thickheaded). Think about a Norse (のろ) God, the God of dullbrains.

mnemonics.meaning: The sovereign emperor of Japan is also the emperor of other places too!

mnemonics.meaning: Your eyeball cavity (hole) is where your eye is held. This is your eye socket.

It's kind of like how a "trump card" is the one that's above all the others, but with the emperor he's always up there, so it's a "me card" to him. And who's gonna argue with the emperor? Not me.

sentences: 彼が嫌いだと言うわけじゃないんだけど、あそこであの発言はちょっと穏当でないなと思ったわけよ。
It’s not that I don’t like him, I just thought his remarks at the time were improper.

mnemonics.meaning: Your pupil hole is still your pupil. It can also be called your pupillary.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the same as the ones you learned with the kanji!

sentences: いつ、どうして瞳孔の縮小と拡張が起きるのか、説明できますか？
Can you explain when and why contraction and expansion of the pupil occurs?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Remember, this is the eyeball pupil.
mnemonics.reading: A person's (ひと) seeing (見) ability comes from their pupil. That's how you can remember ひとみ.

sentences: 父の再婚相手の気怠い瞳を見ると、いつもたじろいでしまいます。
When I look at my stepmother’s listless eyes I always end up wincing.

mnemonics.meaning: This is the same as the kanji, rather. Can also mean better or instead.
mnemonics.reading: Just think: rather than a bug (むし), how about an animal?

sentences: お姫様よりも寧ろ猫になりたい。
I’d rather be a cat than a princess.

mnemonics.meaning: A pure cool is refreshing and cool, isn't it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 十分間にどれだけの炭酸入り清涼飲料水を飲めると思いますか？
How many carbonated soft drinks do you think you can drink in ten minutes?

mnemonics.meaning: On the soil we put sacks in a circle to mark the ring or arena in sumo. Go look up some pictures of this word in Japanese and you'll see exactly what we mean. Better yet, go see some live sumo!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 誰かが土俵にパンの欠片を投げ込みました。
Someone threw a piece of bread into the sumo arena.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: A bunch of sacks or straw bags are stacked upon each other to make a tower (たわら). Imagine walking into this sack tower and wonder how it's all held together. Such poor architecture.

sentences: 俵先生は、自分の名前が俵なので、あの金の米俵のキーホルダーを鞄に付けていると言っていましたよ。
Tawara-sensei told us that her name means straw bag and that’s why she has a gold straw rice-bag keychain on her bag.

mnemonics.meaning: A shout voice is a shout or a yell.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 叫ぶ and 声, put together. Careful of the rendaku.

sentences: マミは叫び声を上げながら、ベーコンを上下に動かしました。
Mami lifted the bacon up and down while she screamed.

mnemonics.meaning: 叫ぶ is "to shout" and "to scream." This is the noun version. This is a shout or scream.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 叫ぶ.

sentences: この人形に単四電池を入れて電源を入れると、叫び出すんです。
If you put triple A batteries in this toy and turn on the power, he will scream.

mnemonics.meaning: You sink down and shut up. You go into a silence and hush. This tends to be an awkward silence or hush.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 気まずい沈黙の後、私は塩の入った小瓶を掴みました。
There was an awkward silence and I grabbed a salt shaker.

mnemonics.meaning: If you put something spicy in your mouth you'll end up with a spicy taste or a dry taste in there. Spice sucks up all your mouth moistness.
mnemonics.reading: This is the kun'yomi readings together. You should have learned them both by now.

sentences: カレーはいつも、甘口、中辛、辛口、どれを買いますか？
Which curry do you usually buy: mild, medium-hot, or spicy?
庄司さんは、辛口の酒が好きです。
Shoji likes dry sake.
みんなは辛口コメントだったけど、私はこの映画好きだな。
Everyone gave harsh comments, but I actually like this movie.

mnemonics.meaning: A new sprout is a sprout or bud or shoot. All sprouts are new, after all.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the readings you learned with the kanji, combined.

sentences: このペースじゃ、夕方までにお茶の新芽を摘み終わるのは無理じゃないかな。
At this rate, it will be impossible to finish picking all the tea sprouts by evening.

mnemonics.meaning: It will carry or bear people like a shelf. This thing that carries people is a stretcher or litter.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あそこ家の息子さん、交通事故に巻き込まれて担架で病院に担ぎ込まれたんだけど、結局植物状態になっちゃったんだって。
Their son was in a car accident and was carried to the hospital on a stretcher, but he ended up in a vegetative state.

mnemonics.meaning: If you enter ink into (your body), you are getting yourself a tattoo.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 入れる and 墨 combined together. Careful of the rendaku.

sentences: その入れ墨には今までいくら費やしているんですか。
How much money have you spent on tattoos?

mnemonics.meaning: A tariff tax is a form of taxes or taxation.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 田んぼには特定の租税が課されているんですか？
Is there a specific tax for rice paddies?

mnemonics.meaning: Forging and tempering of things is tempering and forging of things. When you do this to your body, to get ready for the big race, it's called training. (Though body tempering sounds way cooler, don't you think?)
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 発音が一晩で上手くなる人なんていません。発音を上達させるには、継続的かつ正しい鍛錬が必要です。
Nobody can get perfect pronunciation overnight. To improve your pronunciation you need continuous and proper training.

mnemonics.meaning: A dull feeling in your head is thickheadedness.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あんたって、ほんと鈍感。今はフグの話はしたくないの。それくらい空気を読んでよ。
You are really insensitive. I don’t feel like talking about Fugu right now. Take a hint.

mnemonics.meaning: Years old in months shows time in years. Just imagine counting time by months and years... You kind of do anyways, right? How old are you? 5 years old. Or, 5 and a half years old (that's five years six months). So, it makes some sense.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: それから半世紀の歳月が流れ、彼のことなんてほとんど忘れかけていた時に、私達は小さなパン屋さんで偶然再会したんです。
After fifty years had passed and I was almost starting to forgot about him, we ran into each other in a tiny bakery.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means pride and the verb version is to be proud of or to boast of.
mnemonics.reading: The hoe 子 (ほこ) is the kid who is carrying around a hoe all the time, swinging it around, doing dumb things with it. He's so proud of it, though, and it shows on his face. He's always boasting about his hoe skillz too.

sentences: この短編映画では、日本が世界に誇るロボット産業をテーマとしています。
This short film is about the robotics industry that Japan boasts of to the world.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means blink and the verb vocab version is to blink.
mnemonics.reading: Mah ta ta (またた) is showing, causing you to blink. I don't know what a "tata" is, but I bet you could come up with something that's blink-worthy.

sentences: 辺りの景色は瞬く間に雪に覆われ、真っ白になった。
The landscape was covered by snow in a flash and everything turned white.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means slice and the verb vocab version means to cut down or to slice off or to lop off. This word mainly refers to cutting people with a sword, if you haven't figured it out yet.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as 切る, which means "to cut." Similar meaning, same reading.

sentences: その侍は、早口言葉が上手く言えなければお前の舌を斬るぞ、と私に言いました。
The samurai told me he would cut off my tongue if I couldn’t say the tongue twister properly.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means forge and the verb vocab version is to forge and to temper.
mnemonics.reading: To forge something, you need to have your kit (きた) with you. Without it, you won't be doing any forging at all.

sentences: 生まれたての頃からミッチリ鍛えたおかげで、息子は今ピアノの天才児と呼ばれています。
Thanks to the strict training I’ve given him since birth, my son is now called a child prodigy at piano.

mnemonics.meaning: Hey look! If you weren't sick of them yet, it's another verb that goes with shake! This one means to shake too!
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned 揺る, 揺する, and 揺れる so I reeeeally hope you can remember it by now!

sentences: それっぽっちのことで、気持ちが揺らぐんだ。
So few things sway my feelings.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means shut up so the verb vocab version is to shut up.
mnemonics.reading: You need to damn (だま) your mouth shut and shut up.

sentences: どうしたの？どうして黙っているの？
What’s the matter? Why are you so quiet?

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means thwart and the verb vocab version is to thwart or to hamper.
mnemonics.reading: Someone walks up to you, saying "habbah habbah habbah" (kind of like hubbah hubbah). He's trying to flash you or something. So, you go to thwart him with your taser.

sentences: 誰かが、彼が今日娘さんを連れてバージンロードを歩くのを阻もうとしているようなんです。
It seems like someone is trying to prevent him from walking his daughter down the aisle today.

mnemonics.meaning: Two time ten years old is twenty years old.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for twenty years old, specifically, is a really weird reading. It's はたち. When you turn twenty years old you become a hater of cheese. A hater cheese (はたち) kinda person.

sentences: 「僕は二十歳になる前に社長になるよ。」「そうだといいけどね。」
"I’ll be company president before I’m twenty years old." "I hope you’re right about that."

mnemonics.meaning: Something that's not calm is in a status of unrest and turbulence.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今夜の三日月は、何だか不穏な感じがするわ。
Tonight’s crescent moon looks a little disquieting to me.

mnemonics.meaning: A white chrysanthemum is a white chrysanthemum.
mnemonics.reading: The reading of 白 is a bit different from normal. It's しら instead of しろ, so do your best to keep that in mind. Watch out for the rendaku.

sentences: 家の前に大量の白菊を並べるなんて、迷惑行為以上のことだよ。だって、白菊は日本では死者を弔う花だからね。言ってる意味が分かりますか？
Placing a bunch of white chrysanthemums in front of a house is more than just a nuisance because they are used to mourn the dead in Japan. Do you get what I’m saying?

mnemonics.meaning: A devil woman is a witch. She uses magic, so she must be a witch! Also, does she float like wood / a very small rock?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 「ちょっと言ってもいいかな？」「もちろん。」「あのさ…やっぱいいや。」「ほら、白状しなって！」「えっと、実は私魔女なんだよね。」
"Can I tell you something?" "Of course." "Well… never mind." "Oh come on, out with it." "Well... to be honest, I am a witch."

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is put on the end of numbers to show how old someone is.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 三十歳を過ぎてから、全身がすごく痒いんだよね。
Ever since I turned thirty, my whole body has been itchy.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. That's 零 extra things for you to learn.

sentences: 母は、僕が零点を取ったことにショックを受けて寝込んでしまった。
My mother was so shocked that I got zero points on my test that she's bedridden.

mnemonics.meaning: Zero points means you got zero points. Could also refer to getting zero marks on your test.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 最大公約数を公分母にするということが全く理解できず、試験で零点を取ってしまった。
I couldn’t understand how to make the greatest common divisor a common denominator so I got zero points on the exam.

mnemonics.meaning: The meaning of this radical is the same as the alternative kanji meaning. It means before.
There are fins wrapped in a towel in winter. Who is drying these fish fins to eat them? A penguin.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means wave.
That penguin over there seems to have a towel stuffed with cash. The towel the cash is in even has a big $ on it like the ones they have at the bank. You follow the penguin into a back alley.
mnemonics.reading: Your eyes follow the cash, and you watch as the penguin stuffs it, towel and all, into a hay (へい) stack. What a smart penguin, people don't look for cash in hay, they're too busy looking for needles. You wait for the penguin to leave and you run over to the hay stack and stick your hand in. But you don't feel the towel or the cash! Instead you pull out your hand and it's full of hay and needles. Ouch! No fair, gimme that cash!!

mnemonics.meaning: You give bamboo to someone and they make them into chopsticks. They are very talented at turning bamboo into bamboo chopsticks. This someone is an expert at their profession. Watch this person take ordinary bamboo and transform it into chopsticks right before your eyes. Hear the whooshing and whittling sounds as they form the bamboo into chopsticks with expert speed and precision.
mnemonics.reading: Now use those chopsticks to eat some delicious hash (はし) browns! That's what chopsticks were made for. That's what they're always made for. Imagine trying to pick up hash browns with your chopsticks. They would be really hard to eat if you didn't have these handy eating tools!

mnemonics.meaning: Rub charcoal under your eyes if you want to see clearly. Sports players also rub charcoal under their eyes to see nice and clear in the bright sun. You can even rub charcoal in your eyes if you really want to clear them up, but you should probably only do this under the supervision of your eye doctor.
mnemonics.reading: You have to have clear vision because you're about to go out in your row (りょう) boat. The light off the water shines right into your eyes and you need the charcoal to clear that up for you. Otherwise you'll end up crashing into the shore or going over a waterfall to your death. Imagine how dangerous it would be not to have clear vision while you row around in a row boat. You might even smack yourself in the face with your own oars.

mnemonics.meaning: There is a mountain on top of a bunch of dirt with a steep cliff. This is a bit redundant, but the mountain and the dirt just make the cliff even bigger and steeper and scarier. Imagine a cliff. Now add two big helpings of dirt and a mountain to the top. It's still a cliff, it's just more cliff than before.
mnemonics.reading: As you’re peering over this tall cliff, somebody behind you shouts, “Hey, guy (がい)!” This startles you and you tumble down the cliff. Apparently so did he, because you can hear him saying, "Hey guy! OOF! Are you okay? OOF! Guy? Guy!!!” as you both fall. Imagine falling down this huge cliff and the last words you have to hear before you splat on the ground is someone yelling "Guy" at you over and over. What a way to go.

mnemonics.meaning: Without a fire, you will lack the ability to cook anything. You really need a fire to cook properly. Having a fire will make sure any cooking endeavors you attempt will not fail. Imagine yourself as you cook with a fire very confidently. Knowing you cannot fail, feel the heat and hear the crackling embers of the fire. Smell the delicious smell of whatever you are cooking as well.
mnemonics.reading: You cook your meal evenly by swinging (すい) it back and forth over the fire. You swing it left, you swing it right. You swing it to, you swing it fro. All this swinging ensures a properly cooked meal. Imagine swinging this meal over the fire. Feel the flames licking at your fingertips as you cook this meal by swinging it back and forth over the fire.

mnemonics.meaning: Sitting safely under your canopy you take rice and dirt, mix it up, and create unique cosmetics for your face. Imagine mixing dirt and rice together to make some cosmetics that best fit your skin tone and type. No one will see you doing it under this canopy too, so the secret formula you come up with will be safe.
mnemonics.reading: You need these cosmetics because you have a meeting with the Shougun (しょう) coming up. You want to impress him, and you don't want anyone to copy your look. Imagine meeting the Shougun with your new cosmetics all over your face. You look amazing! Stunning! The shougun wants to know where you got that foundation, you're glowing!

mnemonics.meaning: A building falls into the dirt when a pig with horns crashes into it. The building literally crashes to the ground when the horned pig attacks it. Picture a pig with horns crashing into a building and both of them crashing into the dirt. Uh oh, is the pig dead?
mnemonics.reading: You pull the poor pig out of the rubble of the crash. It's not dead, but it had a nasty bump to the head and now thinks it's a bird. "TWEET (つい)!" says the pig. "Tweet, tweet, tweet!" Poor confused pig. Imagine trying to explain to the pig that it's a pig, and not a bird. "Tweet, tweet, tweet!" says the pig again. Oh dear.

mnemonics.meaning: A crab will try to hide what it lacks with deceit. Lying, stealing, faking things—no type of deceit is too much for a crab. Covering things up with deceit is pretty much the worst thing you can do, so don't be like this crab.
mnemonics.reading: Deceit can only take you so far, and soon the crab is caught, tried for its crimes and coverups, and sentenced to death via guillotine (ぎ). Picture the crab with its head, er, front half? Whatever, it's in the guillotine and it's screaming, "You've been deceived! I never deceived anyone, you're all sheep!"

mnemonics.meaning: A tsunami hits your mohawk and it begins to drip. The water from the tsunami continues to drip from your mohawk long after the tsunami has passed. There’s a lot of water in your hair now, so it’s probably going to drip for a while. Imagine having all this tsunami water in your hair. Hear it drip from your mohawk. Drip… drip… drip…
mnemonics.reading: Luckily, you’re a self-proclaimed techie (てき), so you develop a device to stop the drip drip dripping. This techie device of yours is like a hair dryer helmet. You put it over your mohawk, it does its thing, and your hair is dry! Being a techie sure does have its benefits. Feel the weight of this dryer helmet on your head as you listen to it whirr away. The dripping has finally stopped! Success!

mnemonics.meaning: In the dirt there are flags and horns lined up with a lantern attached to them, making a fence. It's a little weird looking, but these things are definitely supposed to fence something in. Can you see the fence made of horns and flags through the light of the lantern?
mnemonics.reading: You want to know what this fence is fencing in, so you take a step closer. As the light from the lantern gets brighter you see that the fence is around a ton of hay (へい). Picture yourself climbing over this fence (that you're definitely not supposed to climb based on all these flags and horns) and falling into the piles of hay. It's a little scratchy, but otherwise pretty comfy!

mnemonics.meaning: It's raining on your spear that has winter power. When the warm rain hits your cold, winter spear, it creates fog. When warm water touches a cold spear, fog billows out and covers everything.
mnemonics.reading: Through the fog you see the shape of a mythical kirin (きり). You can only see the outline through the fog, but you know it's there. You walk toward the kirin through the fog. When you get close, the image before you becomes clear: it's two cans of Kirin beer on a slide. Next time you see fog, keep your eyes peeled for the real kirin in the kiri.

mnemonics.meaning: After passing through a door, you use a feather to put the finishing touches on a folding fan. The door leads to your folding fan workshop where you make all your folding fans. This folding fan is now complete that you’ve added a feather to it. How lovely it is. Use this folding fan to fan your face. Feel the refreshing breeze as you admire the gorgeous feather you just added. What a fashionista you’ve become.
mnemonics.reading: Your biggest folding fan customer is a centaur (せん). This centaur just loves your folding fans and this one you just made with the feather was for the centaur’s latest order. You go back out your door and deliver this folding fan to the centaur. Imagine handing this newly made folding fan to the centaur. See his face light up with delight as he examines your fine craftsmanship and starts fanning himself with it. Another satisfied customer!

mnemonics.meaning: The door a criminal will get into is the front door. Now hold on, you may be thinking, wouldn't they go for the back door? No! 99% of home invasions happen when you leave your own front door unlocked! You better check the locks on your front door right now, because odds are you left it open and didn't even notice. It's the perfect door for a criminal to get access to your home.
mnemonics.reading: To protect your front door from criminals you plan to fill it with heat (ひ). Oh yeah, we're gonna Kevin McCallister this. Imagine how you'd heat up your front door. A hot iron? A blow torch? A small fire? It doesn't matter how, as long as the heat makes it all the way through your front door and hurts any criminals trying to get into it.

mnemonics.meaning: A soul will only inhabit a root if it's holding a grudge. Have you ever seen a nice, haunted tree? No! They're always angry and trying to get someone back for something. Don't die with a grudge, or your soul might end up angry and trapped in some roots.
mnemonics.reading: If you see one of these grudge trees, it's probably inhabited by the soul of a condor (こん). Humans tend to kill condors and take their trees away to build houses and make toilet paper. So condors hold pretty bad grudges against us, and so their souls end up stuck in a lot of trees. Picture a tree with the soul of a condor with a grudge in it before you. You feel bad about being so wasteful with paper and chopsticks now, huh?

mnemonics.meaning: You take a towel and wrap it around your head to keep the sun out of your eyes. You've invented... the hat! A hat is just a piece of cloth or a towel you get to stay on your head. Extra points if it protect your eyes from the sun.
mnemonics.reading: People see you wearing this fancy new hat thing and start asking you to share. You grab all your extra towels, roll them up, and bowl (ぼう) them down the street toward everyone who asks for one. Imagine bowling with hats. Thankfully, they work as bowling balls just as well as they work as hats. You're so innovative!

mnemonics.meaning: The soul mask helps you to see the deepest part of anyone's soul. You look around and in all the people you only see hate. You're supposed to see all the emotions, so why do you only see hate inside everyone?
mnemonics.reading: It turns out you're not looking at normal people. You see so much hate because all the people you're looking at are actually just a group of zombies (ぞう). Zombies are pretty filled with hate, so it makes sense that you'd see a bunch of hate if you used the soul mask on them.

mnemonics.meaning: The leader of a narwhal construction crew needs all the help he can get. The narwhals are beginning construction on an underwater city. The leader knows the narwhals are hard construction workers, but they’ll need some help building this city. Imagine being the narwhal leader and asking others for help. Ask a shark for help. Ask a whale for help. Ask a shrimp for help. Go on, ask.
mnemonics.reading: Then you discover a saw (さ) who would be a great big help. This saw is very strong and would help you and your narwhal construction team out a lot. You should make use of this saw right away. Imagine using this saw and realizing how big of a help it is. Hear the saw sawing away as you and your fellow narwhals get to work.

mnemonics.meaning: You have fingers in the thousands and while looking up at the sun you decide you want to insert them in there. Hold your thousand+ fingers up to the sun and imagine inserting them into the sun's super-hot ... s-sun lava. (That's what it is, right? Yeah, let's go with that.)
mnemonics.reading: You insert one finger, it burns up immediately, and its soul (そう) comes flying out screaming for a moment before it disappears. Hmm. You insert another finger and as it burns up, another little soul comes out screeching, "WHY WOULD YOU INSERT ME IN THERE!" and is gone. Since you have a thousand fingers too many, you decide to insert them all into the sun and watch as their souls pop out. You listen to the little souls scream at you.

mnemonics.meaning: A leader and Wolverine take a slide to Italy. Wolverine’s leader is Professor X, and they are both sliding down a big slide to Italy. How fun! Imagine Wolverine and his leader Professor X going down this slide to Italy. Hear them wooping and cheering as they ride down the slide. Whee~
mnemonics.reading: Before Professor X can get off the slide into Italy, a large eagle (い) swoops down and plucks him right out of his wheelchair. That eagle is very strong. Goodbye, Professor X! Imagine this eagle carrying Professor X away from Italy and out over the ocean. You can also remember this reading easily because Italy starts with the letter I. Super simple stuff.

mnemonics.meaning: They say the key to telling a lie is to totally believe the lie yourself. They say that if you believe your own lie, others will believe it as well. This is key. Imagine an actual key going from you to another person. This key is the lie. You gotta believe in the lie for it to reach the other person and unlock their understanding. Visualize this visual lie.
mnemonics.reading: The lie you told was about not stealing your buddy’s saw (さ). You actually did steal his saw. He saw you steal his saw, but now you are trying to lie your way out of it. It’s not going well. Imagine trying to lie your way out of this. He saw you steal his saw. He caught you red handed. What sort of lie can you spin to get yourself out of this situation?

mnemonics.meaning: With a woman's mouth, you have a likeness to me. Imagine someone's putting a woman's mouth over your mouth, looking at you, and commenting on your likeness. All it took was this woman's mouth.
mnemonics.reading: You have a likeness to Jo-Anne (じょ) when you wear that mouth. Jo-Anne popped her mouth off and put it on you. Indeed with that mouth on, you have an extreme likeness to her.

mnemonics.meaning: A landslide came out of your mouth and created your lips. Before the landslide, you just had a wide open mouth hole. Picture your mouth as an open hole. Now a landslide of something (words? food? something worse?) comes pouring out, and when it's done you have lips. You flap them open and closed to test them out.
mnemonics.reading: Now you can use your new lips to enjoy a nice, cold Kuchi beer (くちびる). The Kuchi people are Afghan Pashtun nomads. They are lesser known for their amazing beer. And you've never been able to get this delicious beer into your mouth, but now that you have lips you can get it all in there. Imagine wrapping your new lips around the mouth of this Kuchi beer bottle. It's so good! And you aren't spilling any of it!

mnemonics.meaning: A Viking moves your mouth with his hand to manipulate it. He sticks his hand into your mouth. With the Viking's hand in your mouth, he can make you look like you’re saying anything he wants. Imagine the Viking having his hand in your mouth. Taste his salty flesh on your tongue. Imagine him manipulating your mouth and your jaw and making it look like you are saying all sorts of funny things.
mnemonics.reading: The Viking is manipulating you so that he can manipulate the Shougun (しょう)! You and the Shougun have grown pretty close over the last year or so, and this Viking is going to take advantage! You don't want to manipulate the Shougun, but you can't seem to get the Viking's hand out of your mouth. You frantically imagine all the manipulative things the Viking could get the Shougun to do for him like this.

mnemonics.meaning: A wave crashes into a woman, transforming her into an old woman! The wave washes away all of the woman’s makeup, revealing her to be an old woman. The makeup she had on made her appear to be a much younger woman, but once the wave washed away her makeup, she was revealed for the old woman she is. Imagine a gorgeous woman. Now see her get hit by a wave of water and turn into an old woman. The old woman could still be pretty too, she just looks way old now. Like ancient.
mnemonics.reading: In an attempt to distract you from the fact that she is actually an old woman, the old woman starts to baa (ば) and act like a sheep. The old woman goes “Baa! Baa!” and hops around on all fours like a sheep. Imagine this old woman acting like a sheep, just saying “baa” over and over and over again. Baa! Baa! Baa!

mnemonics.meaning: With a lid, you hit yourself in the mouth and then kick it like a pathetic loser. You kick the lid, even though it is your fault that you hit yourself in the mouth with it. It’s not the lid’s fault. You don’t need to kick it. You’re being pathetic. Imagine kicking this lid and with each kick you feel a little bit more pathetic. Your mouth hurts a lot too.
mnemonics.reading: You kick the lid one last time and it bounces off the wall and hits you in the eye (あい). How pathetic. You are a pathetic mess. You should have never kicked the lid. Now both your eye and your mouth are in pain, you pathetic fool, you. Hold your eye with one hand and your mouth with the other. Feel them pulse in pain as you reflect on how pathetic you are today.

mnemonics.meaning: An insect specializing in construction builds a rainbow. Did you ever wonder where rainbows come from? Construction insects build them. Construction insects build rainbows. Imagine this insect with a construction hat on, building a rainbow. He works very fast. The resulting rainbow is beautiful!
mnemonics.reading: This rainbow building insect is so needy (にじ). He is needy because he needs everyone to look at his rainbow and praise him for what he’s done. “Look at my rainbow! Look at how good it is and I am! I’m so needy! Needy for praise and recognition!” Imagine this construction insect being all whiny and needy for attention and stuff. It’s pathetic. Hear him whine and whine because of how needy he is.

mnemonics.meaning: A big treasure treasure treasure treasure is refreshing! Sorry, I can’t say treasure treasure treasure treasure without saying it four times. See? I did it again. Anyway, this big treasure treasure treasure treasure is really refreshing. It’s been a long time since you found a treasure treasure treasure treasure, so finding this big one is really refreshing. Imagine finding this big treasure treasure treasure treasure and being really refreshed and relieved and happy. This treasure treasure treasure treasure is so big, you’ll be set for life!
mnemonics.reading: You’d had a sour (さわ) taste in your mouth for not being able to find any treasure treasure treasure treasure for such a long time, but now that you found this big one, the sour taste is totally gone and it’s sooooo refreshing! Imagine the most sour taste you could ever imagine. So super-duper sour! Now imagine that sour taste instantly melting away once you discover this big refreshing treasure treasure treasure treasure. Jackpot!

mnemonics.meaning: You keep your tongue to your self to give your heart a rest. You’ve been talking and moving your tongue around all day expressing your feelings. This has tired both your tongue and your heart out, so you stop your tongue moving and decide that you need some self rest time. It's important to let yourself rest every now and then, you know.
mnemonics.reading: What better way to rest than to eat some cake (けい)! No talking necessary. Just enjoy the delicious taste of cake on your tongue and feel your heart let out a sigh of relief. You should rest right now. Take a break from Japanese and go eat some cake. (Just remember to come back when your tongue and heart are sufficiently rested!)

mnemonics.meaning: Before you boil something, make sure that you roast it. Why would you roast something before you boil it? Because that something is tea! Or maybe coffee. Tea leaves and coffee beans are roasted before they're boiled.
mnemonics.reading: Now you roast yourself some centaur (せん). Roasted centaur goes well with tea. Smell the wafting scent of roasted centaur as you sip on your freshly-roasted tea.

mnemonics.meaning: This shrimp is the exact length of a shaku, or Japanese foot. That’s how they came up with this form of measurement. They measured the length of this shrimp and it was the length of a Japanese foot which they deemed the shaku. It’s equal to 30.3cm, very close to one imperial foot. Imagine this foot long shrimp. It’s pretty big. Imagine it squirming about making a “shaku shaku” sound as it worms about.
mnemonics.reading: How is shaku, the Japanese foot, pronounced by Shaq (しゃく) in Japanese? Why Shaq pronounces it shaku. It’s pronounced shaku in both English and Japanese. Imagine Shaq dribbling the shrimp like a basketball, saying “shaku, shaku, shaku” every time he bounces the shrimp.

mnemonics.meaning: Take this stone and throw it at nine crosses to smash them! It's like old-fashioned bowling, but instead of rolling this stone to knock down the crosses, you want to completely smash them to bits! Picture the nine crosses in front of you, lined up in a triangle. Now take your rock, hold it above your head, and SMASH it down on them as hard as you can!!
mnemonics.reading: As you smash these crosses, you think of your cyborg (さい) and how much you want to smash the people who took it away from you. Your cyborg was so good at smashing things too. You could be smashing together, if you didn't have to sell it. You smash things because your own heart has been smashed by your cyborg. :'(

mnemonics.meaning: Your rice fortune is sticky. Rice is sticky. So is your rice fortune. Your fortune of rice is sticky because it is made up entirely of sticky rice. Look at this sticky rice fortune of yours. Run your hands through it and feel the sticky rice between your fingers. Hear the sticky sucking sounds and you stir the sticky rice about.
mnemonics.reading: This rice is so sticky that you are able to sculpt nendoroids (ねん) from it. Your rice fortune is worth even more now that you are hand making limited edition nendoroids from it. Imagine sculpting these sticky rice nendoroids with your bare hands. Feel the sticky rice between your fingers as you smush the rice into cute little nendoroids.

mnemonics.meaning: In the rice paddy there is a forehead with a top hat. It sits atop an area of tatami mats. The meaning you're trying to learn is tatami mat, so focus on the beautiful tatami mats that are strangely in the middle of this rice paddy. On top is a forehead with a top hat. It almost looks like the tatami mats are an altar for this gruesome scene.
mnemonics.reading: Who made this creepy tatami mat altar? It was Jourm (じょう) the increasingly concerning farmhand who lives in your village. You saw Jourm setting up the tatami mats a day earlier, but you thought he was just making an area for workers in the field to rest in. Does the forehead with a top hat have anything to do with Jourm? Did he... do something bad?

mnemonics.meaning: The moon is the same as your torso. You must have a really huge torso for it to be the same as the moon. Imagine if your torso was as large as the moon. You’re a gigantic human. Imagine floating around in space like this. Wooooaaaahhh.
mnemonics.reading: Your torso got so big because of all the doughnuts (どう) you ate. You ate so many doughnuts that your torso got to be the size of the moon and then you floated away into space with your own gravitational pull and everything. Doughnuts are dangerous things. Imagine how many doughnuts you would have to eat to get your torso this size. Now imagine eating all of those doughnuts. I hope you like doughnuts, because you’re going to be eating a lot of them.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for towel first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means towel as well. Make sure you know those radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: You know who loves towels? The King (きん) of England. He loves towels so much that he went around and put きん on every towel in the land, so you think of him whenever you use one. Go into your bathroom or your linen closet right now. Look at your towels. Look for the small きん hidden there.

mnemonics.meaning: There are flowers growing around a heart with a wick sticking out of it. The heart is a sacrifice to the old gods and the life energy bleeds from the burning wick to feed the flowers. The wick burns, releasing the power of the heart which spreads into the ground around the heart causing the flowers to grow. See this morbid scene. As the wick burns you can smell the smell of burning organs. The flowers are pretty though.
mnemonics.reading: Sometimes the wick burning the heart isn’t enough for the flowers to grow properly and they get thirsty for the blood from your shin (しん). So, you slice open your shin with a sacrificial knife and drip your blood over the thirsty demon flowers. Imagine slicing your shin with a knife, causing blood to drip on the flowers around the heart with a wick in it. Your shin really hurts from the injury, but the flowers are rejoicing as they’re showered in blood.

mnemonics.meaning: A tree that is stamped with one pattern, then stamped with another pattern, over and over, is the willow tree.  A willow tree is a tree that looks like it's on repeat over and over again. It also looks nice on a stamp. Note that the first stamp is kind of an ugly looking backwards stamp, and the second stamp is the normal stamp radical.
mnemonics.reading: Ryu (りゅう) from Street Fighter really loves willow trees. Ryu loves them so much that he makes out with them. Ryu is open mouth kissing a willow tree. You are watching this. It is happening. Watch Ryu as he French kisses this willow tree. Hear him slurping and moaning in ecstasy. Why are you watching this? This is gross. Wait – is this turning you on!? Ew.

mnemonics.meaning: A supplement of help is an aid or help or assistance. Not a full on help, but an aid of sorts.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私はトーフグ営業部の補佐として働きました。
I worked as an assistant in the Tofugu sales department.

mnemonics.meaning: If you have a naked foot, it means you're not wearing anything on your foot, making you barefoot.
mnemonics.reading: The reading here is a bit weird. It's like the words 裸 (はだか) and 足 (あし) were smushed together into one word. The 裸 becomes はだ and the 足 becomes し. You can think of it this way: You were barefoot too long, and because of this, you don't have feet anymore, though you had ashi (はだし) at one point in the past.

sentences: 水虫になりたくないなら、スリッパを裸足で履かない方がいいですよ。
You shouldn’t wear slippers barefoot if you don’t want to get athlete’s foot.

mnemonics.meaning: Your torso body is the body area that's your torso. It's your body and trunk and torso, depending on what kind of body you have.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 君は今までみた中で一番胴体が長いよ。
You have the longest torso I’ve ever seen.

mnemonics.meaning: If you insert a drawing into a book, it becomes a book illustration.
mnemonics.reading: The reading used for 挿絵 is an exceptional one. Instead of そう it's さし. When you think of a book illustration, think of an illustration of a sash. Just picture after picture of a sash. Purple sashes. Green sashes. Flashy sashes. What a weird book, that only has illustrations of sashes. 絵, however, is the reading you learned with the kanji, so at least you have that.

sentences: アイツの話によると、彼女、本の挿絵を描いてるんだってさ。
According to him, she draws illustrations for books.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 口コミがあっという間に広がって、その折りたたみ式の陶器のお箸はとても人気が出ました。
Word of mouth spread rapidly and the foldable ceramic chopsticks became really popular.

mnemonics.meaning: Something that is bright and clear has great clarity and clearness. Just look at something with such brightness and such clearness! It has so much clarity!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: さすがベテランアナウンサーなだけあって、彼女はとてもよく聞き取れる明瞭な声でその質問に答えました。
As one would expect from a veteran announcer like her, she answered the question in an easy to understand, clear voice.

mnemonics.meaning: Sticky earth is clay. Just think about feeling the clay. It's sticky especially when fresh and kind of wet, right?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 粘土を買おうかなと思ってるの？
Are you thinking of buying some clay?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: You can't believe how big the cliff is. You look at it for so long, you just become another gawker (がけ) who can't stop staring at the huge cliff. It really is huge.

sentences: 崖っぷちではさすがに携帯圏外だったわ。
Of course my phone had no reception at the edge of the cliff.

mnemonics.meaning: If something sticky wears something else on it, it will stick together and form a cohesion or adhesion onto that thing. It's sticky after all.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: どうして粘着テープを宝石箱に仕舞っているの？
Why do you keep the adhesive tape in your jewelry box?

mnemonics.meaning: A big help is a colonel or navy captain. They go around the seas, helping people in need by fighting the bad guys.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 大佐にお会いできるのを楽しみにしています。
I’m looking forward to meeting the colonel.

mnemonics.meaning: A river of willows... so hilarious! What a great comic haiku, that one is. Try to think of a comic haiku about the river willow, if you can. The River Willow Flows upstream like a salmon This is not funny
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. And for once the kanji 川 doesn't use the kun'yomi reading. When you think of a comic haiku, think of something hilarious... like a centaur (せん), doing a standup act with a comedy haiku.

sentences: ここにあなたの川柳を書いてもらえませんか？
Could you write your senryu here?

mnemonics.meaning: The cook action is the action of cooking. It's the culinary arts.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 僕たちは、炊事をする男を雇った。
We hired a man to do kitchen work.

mnemonics.meaning: A self cook is cooking for oneself. Better break out the TV tray.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 忙しいけど、ちゃんと自炊してるよ。実際、昨日の夜はラタトゥイユっていう野菜の煮込み料理を作ったよ。
I’ve been busy, but I do cook for myself. In fact, last night I made a stewed vegetable dish called ratatouille.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji means wick and this word also means wick, but it means things at the core of other long things more often. Things like pencil lead and marrow.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: お買い得だったので、HBのシャー芯を百ケース買いました。
I bought one hundred cases of HB mechanical pencil lead because they were at a bargain price.

mnemonics.meaning: The 〜 shows the number of tatami mats, and the 畳 part is "tatami" of course. So, this is a counter for tatami mats. It is generally used to show how big an apartment or something is. Oh, your apartment is 12 tatami mats? Nice and big!
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 10.5畳で毎月のお家賃が一万円のこの部屋は、早い者勝ちの物件です。
This ten and a half mat room for just 10,000 yen a month is a first come, first served deal.

mnemonics.meaning: A cloth towel is just a cloth towel. Essentially it's known as a dish cloth or tea towel.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 誰かが棒のてっぺんに、日の丸の代わりに布巾をはためかせたみたいですね。
It seems that somebody put a dish cloth on top of the pole instead of the national flag of Japan.

mnemonics.meaning: A gate's front door is the doors of a gate or gate doors.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

sentences: 私が門扉の前で待っていると、誰かが割り込んできました。
When I was waiting in front of the gate doors someone cut in front of me.

mnemonics.meaning: A water drip is a drop of water or a water drop.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 車の窓には水滴がついています。
Water droplets are beading on the car windows.

mnemonics.meaning: A miscellaneous cloth is a dust cloth or house cloth. It's just a cloth that you use on random things.
mnemonics.reading: The reading of 雑 is different from what you've learned. Instead of ざつ it's ぞう. Just imagine using this dust cloth to wipe down a 象 (ぞう). Its trunk is particularly dusty.

sentences: コウイチに雑巾を売り込もうと電話を掛けたんだけど、全く相手にされなかったよ。
I called Koichi trying to sell him our dust cloth, but he didn’t want anything to do with me.

mnemonics.meaning: 稼ぐ is "to earn income." This is the noun version. It's just earnings, the things you earn.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 稼ぐ.

sentences: 稼ぎがそんなに多くないので、何によくお金を使っているか習慣を見直して節約するために家計簿をつけています。
Our earnings aren’t very high, so I keep a budget account book to look at our spending habits in order to save money.

mnemonics.meaning: A folding fan wind machine is a machine that blows wind like a folding fan. That's an electric fan or an electronic fan.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Careful of the rendaku.

sentences: 時計のチクタクという音と、扇風機のブーンという音しか聞こえなかった。
The only thing I could hear was the sound of the clock ticking and the whirring of the electric fan.
