mnemonics.meaning: If you attain Italy-ness, you are becoming like the Italians. In this case, that's pure elegance and dandyism. Also sophistication. Mamamia!
mnemonics.reading: The readings for both kanji are ones you haven't seen before. But, just think about how when you go on a date (だて) you probably want to have as much elegance as possible. Makes the date go better.

sentences: 伊達巻きはおせち料理の中で私が好きなものの一つです。
Of all the food served during the Japanese New Year, rolled omelette is one of my favorites.

mnemonics.meaning: Insert some talking. Now you have an episode! Now put some more talking in that story. You have another episode!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 挿話を十カテゴリーに分類する予定です。
We are going to sort these episodes into ten categories.

mnemonics.meaning: If you crash and fall then you're crashing or falling, maybe both.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あのジェット機の墜落は人為的ミスが原因だったと思う？
Do you think that jet crashed due to human error?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading of the vocab is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 七夕の日、朝は霧がかかっていましたが、お昼には晴れました。
On the day of Tanabata it was foggy in the morning, but it cleared up by noon.

mnemonics.meaning: A folding fan's child is, for some reason, a folding fan. I'm guessing there are different sizes of folding fans, and this is the smaller more manageable kind you can carry around easily and make it smaller by folding it up, which is why it's the "child" version of the folding fan. Still a folding fan, though.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この扇子は特価で買ったんですよ。
I bought this folding fan on special.

mnemonics.meaning: If there are lies and deceit in your interactions with people, you're committing fraud, you're carrying out a scam, you're swindling.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 色々な詐欺の手口について知りたいなら、ジェニーに聞いたらいいよ。
If you want to know various swindling tricks, you should ask Jenny.
うちのお婆ちゃん、オレオレ詐欺にあって、百万円を騙し取られたんだ。
My grandmother was cheated out of one million yen in an imposter scam.
詐欺を働いて告訴された経験はおありですか。
Have you ever been accused of committing fraud?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Out of the front door jumps (飛び) Ra (ら). Every morning he can't wait to burst forth from the front door to soak in the Sun. He is the Egyptian sun god, after all.

sentences: おい、ふざけている場合か！扉を開けろ！
Hey, this isn’t funny! Open the door!

mnemonics.meaning: An old woman, even with an honorific and an お is still an old woman. She might be your grandmother as well, though, so be nice!
mnemonics.reading: Even if she is your grandmother, something is wrong. You look closely at her face. She's a sheep! Baa! (ばあ).

sentences: この度は本当にご愁傷様です。あなたのお婆さんはとても素敵な人だったので、あなたのお爺さんの代わりに私が一緒にいられればいいのにといつも願っていたほどですよ。残念ながら願いは叶いませんでしたがね。
I am so sorry for your loss. Your grandmother was such a nice lady that I always wished she was with me instead of your grandfather. Sadly, my wish never came true.

mnemonics.meaning: Manipulate your grip over and over. You have to manipulate it because you're slipping. You're just grasping right now.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 恐らく気づいていないと思うが、コウイチ大統領は全てを掌握しているんだよ。
You probably haven’t noticed, but president Koichi holds absolute power.

mnemonics.meaning: If sand makes a lot of profit, it swells up and becomes gravel. They're like the fat cats of the beach.
mnemonics.reading: You learned the reading for 利 with the kanji, but the reading for 砂 is irregular, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're walking through that big fat gravel, when a pile of it starts moving, and something suddenly leaps out at you. It's a... jaguar (じゃ)! Run!

sentences: アスファルトは、砂利を石油で固めたものなんですよ。
Asphalt is gravel that's hardened with petroleum.
ウラン鉱山はこの砂利道の先にあります。
The uranium mine is at the end of this gravel road.
折角野菜を育てられるのに、庭に砂利を敷いてしまうのはもったいないと思うんだけど。
I think it would be a shame to spread gravel over the garden when we could grow vegetables.

mnemonics.meaning: When you roast tea, you get green tea, also known as green leaf teaor sencha. In reality there are various ways to make green tea, but for the purposes of this mnemonic, let's imagine it's always roasted!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 煎茶を入れたので良かったら飲みませんか。
I made green tea. Would you like some?
スタバの煎茶グリーンアップルが大好きなんです。
I love Starbucks' sencha green apple tea.
私の兄はホットケーキに煎茶をかけて食べるんです。
My big brother pours green leaf tea over pancakes.

mnemonics.meaning: A hat child is a hat or cap. Sadly, it's not made from children, unless you're crazy.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: こないだ海でフグって名前のめちゃくちゃ大きい男に会ったんだけど、その人シルクハットみたいな帽子被っててさぁ、…あ、そういう感じの帽子、分かる？
The other day I met this ridiculously big man named Fugu in the ocean and he was wearing something that looked like a top hat, you know that kind of hat?

mnemonics.meaning: You know that 狩り is hunting already. This is the same thing (hunting). Difference is this one is attached to other words to specify what kind of hunting you're doing.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as 狩り, so if you know that you'll know this, no need to hunt for the reading of this word.

sentences: 鹿狩り用の見張り台は、今は大きなブルーシートで覆われています。
The lookout platform we use for deer hunting is covered in a big blue tarp now.

mnemonics.meaning: If you insert and enter something, you are doing insertion to it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: このパラグラフの間にアヤのイラストを挿入するのはどうでしょうか。
Why don’t we insert Aya’s illustration between these paragraphs?

mnemonics.meaning: Point drips are drips coming down little by little. These are the drips of an intravenous drip. Back in the day this was a way of talking about raindrops, or really any falling drops of water. But nowadays we only use it for IV drips.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 点滴を受けた後、彼は綿密な診察を受けました。
After getting an IV drip, he was thoroughly examined.

mnemonics.meaning: The place with Italy force is a place known as Ise. It's a region of Japan that has a nice peninsula, I think. Going straight to the reading for this one may be your best bet.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out, because this uses the せ, not the せい you're used to seeing.

sentences: 伊勢神宮には、一度行ってみた方がいいよ。
You should go see the Ise Shrine once.

mnemonics.meaning: A lump spirit is the lump of spirit that's used in the famous game Katamari Damacy.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is 塊 and 魂 put together. Watch out for the rendaku.

sentences: 最近は塊魂というゲームをプレイしています。
I’ve recently been playing a game called Katamari Damacy.

mnemonics.meaning: You lack likeness to anything out there. You totally lack something that gives you likeness. It's a deficiency, or something.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ビタミンB1が欠如すると、脚気になるかもしれないですよ。
A Vitamin B1 deficiency might cause beriberi.

mnemonics.meaning: The middle help in the army or navy is the lieutenant colonel or the navy commander. I'm guessing these ranks are kind of in the middle or middle high end of the ranking scales?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 中佐は、日本への移住に反対することを決めた。
The lieutenant colonel decided against immigrating to Japan.

mnemonics.meaning: A leap of likeness is when something that's not real takes a big leap towards the likeness of life. That's lifelike or vivid. Note that you need to add と to the end of this word to make it an adverb, and たる to make it an adjective!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: そいつにチャンピオンの面目躍如たるところを見せつけてやれ！
Show him what kind of champion you are!

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: たらこ唇にコンプレックスを感じるって言うけど、僕は君の唇、とっても可愛いと思うよ。
You say you have an inferiority complex about your pouty lips, but I find them really cute.

mnemonics.meaning: If you have love and hate then you have love and hate.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この愛憎の入り混じった気持ちをコントロールするのはもう無理だよ。
I can’t control these mixed feelings of love and hate anymore.

mnemonics.meaning: The bottom lip is your lower lip or bottom lip.
mnemonics.reading: したくちびる is the vocab reading for 下 and the reading you learned with the kanji for 唇. This is how you'd usually read this word. かしん is very technical and it's rarely used outside of scientific writing. If you don't plan to read science papers in Japanese, you can ignore this reading!

sentences: 赤ちゃんは、木綿のミトンをしていたにも関わらず、下唇を引っ掻いてしまった。
Even though the baby was wearing cotton mittens, he still scratched his lower lip.
「お金が無いから、今週は外食出来ないの。」と言って、瞳は下唇をかんだ。
"I can’t eat out this week because I’m broke." Hitomi said, biting her bottom lip.
古代鮫ヘリコプリオン、とにかく下唇がすごいから、一度ググってみて！
The bottom lip of the ancient shark Helicoprion is just amazing. You should Google it!

mnemonics.meaning: The few who help are the majors or lieutenant commanders. They are the few who step up to the plate to help out in the army, according to this word's kanji.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その少佐は、大佐に飲み物を奢ると言ってきかなかった。
The lieutenant insisted on buying the colonel a drink.

mnemonics.meaning: Change your face with cosmetics! This is via makeup or, of course, cosmetics.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 化 is a new reading, け. To remember this, think about someone putting on makeup. They finish putting it on, and then you say "K, show (けしょう) me!"

sentences: 出産後お肌の調子が悪くってさ〜。前に言ってたおススメの化粧品の名前教えてくれない？
My skin has gotten worse since I gave birth. What was that cosmetic brand you recommended before?

mnemonics.meaning: If you lie about your title, the title which represents who you are, then that is a misrepresentation. A false statement.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 庭師は彼女が年齢を詐称していることにすぐに気がつきましたが、何も言いませんでした。
The gardener immediately recognized the misrepresentation of her age but didn’t say anything.

mnemonics.meaning: The freight of cash comes in. What is a freight of cash? It's just money, currency, or coinage.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私は実は、昔の貨幣の収集家なんです。
I’m actually a collector of old coins.

mnemonics.meaning: Morning fog is morning fog, because it's fog in the morning. This is the best kind of fog, I think.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the readings you learned with both kanji. Be careful of the rendaku.

sentences: チャリティーオークションで、朝霧から山々が浮き出ている素晴らしく美しい絵を落札しました。
At a charity auction I made a successful bid on an incredibly beautiful painting of mountains breaking through the morning fog.

mnemonics.meaning: A soil fence is a fence made from soil. Usually this is in the form of a mud wall or an earthen wall.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

sentences: あなたの家の土塀をよじ登っている人がいたので、それをお知らせするためにお電話させて頂きました。
I’m calling to let you know that I noticed someone climbing up your mud wall.

mnemonics.meaning: An elderly old woman is just an old woman.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あの老婆は絶対に賭博を認めようとしないんだ。
That old woman will never approve of gambling.

mnemonics.meaning: When you manipulate something, imagine you're doing it with your palm. You use your palm to manipulate the movement, and then you fine tune it further, all with your palm! Something to note here is that you'll typically see palm in Japanese written as 手のひら. This kanji isn't as common but it does still mean the same thing.
mnemonics.reading: Where is the palm of one's hand? It's on your 手のhere (てのひら). Right here. I point to my palm, and say "hand here, is where my palm was." Another noteworthy thing about this kanji is it can be read as たなごころ. You won't see it read this way as often though so we're only teaching you the main reading.

sentences: 掌サイズの小さな電子辞書を買いました。
I bought a small, palm-sized electronic dictionary.

mnemonics.meaning: Paper cash is paper money.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the on'yomi reading for 紙 even though you went through all that trouble to learn the kun'yomi reading. Did you know paper money is made of sheep (し)? Well, part sheep, but there's sheep in there for sure. That's why you can wash your paper money with your t-shirts in the washing machine.

sentences: アメリカに行くと、お財布に紙幣がギッシリ入るのでお金持ちになった気がするんですよね。まあ、それは全部一ドル札なんですが。
Whenever I go to America I feel like I’m rich with all the money in my wallet. Though, they are all one dollar bills.

mnemonics.meaning: The peak of the mountain is a peak or mountain.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  When you climb to the top of the peak, you're so amazed to find vegetation at this altitude. The only thing that grows here, and in thick amounts, is 竹 (たけ). It is impeding your progress to the very top of the peak, in fact, which is a bother. It's as if it's guarding something...

sentences: 富山県には、剣の山という意味の、剣岳と呼ばれる山があります。
There is a mountain called Tsurugidake, which literally means Mt. Sword, in Toyama prefecture.

mnemonics.meaning: A possible pathetic concept. It's not just possibly pathetic, to be honest. It's pitiful and pathetic, for sure.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Well, at least most of it does. To remember the reading for 哀 imagine some pathetic person who lost their home. They may be pitiful but at some point after losing their home they decided that the hood of your car would make a fine place to live. You can't help but ask them, "Why (わい) my car?" There are so many other cars this pathetic person could be camping out on, but they chose yours.

sentences: お酒を付き合い程度にしか飲まない人のこと、なんだか可哀想だなって思うんだよね。
I think it’s a little pathetic to be a social drinker.

mnemonics.meaning: If something is pathetic then you should have pity on it. You should also feel a little sorrow and grief for it, because seriously, so pathetic!
mnemonics.reading: You look at the thing you're feeling is so pathetic that you feel pity for and just think... aww (あわ), that's really pathetic.

sentences: 衣食住もままならない彼らの事を哀れに思います。
I pity them because they don’t have enough food, clothing, or shelter.

mnemonics.meaning: The spear ahead is the most ahead part of the halberd. That's the point of spear or spearpoint.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from the vocab versions of 矛 and 先 combined together.

sentences: でも、どうしてハッカーは攻撃の矛先を俺たちに向けてきたんだ？
But, why did the hackers aim the brunt of their attack at us?

mnemonics.meaning: To powder I will smash it! If I do that, it's pulverization and smashing.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私の従兄弟は、転んで左足の膝のお皿を粉砕骨折しました。
My cousin fell and got a comminuted fracture in his left kneecap.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: はためく日本国旗の上には、美しい虹が掛かっていた。
There was a beautiful rainbow above the fluttering Japanese flag.

mnemonics.meaning: Rainbow colored things are rainbow colored.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the kanji readings for both 虹 and 色.

sentences: 虹色の山葵を購入してみたんですが、味はまんま山葵ですね。
I purchased rainbow colored wasabi but it tastes just like regular wasabi.

mnemonics.meaning: The flower willow for some reason is a red light district. Just imagine a shady red light district, and right in the middle is a flowering willow.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼は花柳小説の有名な著者ですよ。
He’s a famous author of red-light district novels.

mnemonics.meaning: This is the noun version of the kanji, making it refreshing as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same reading you learned with the kanji!

sentences: 爽やかなイケメンが横を通り過ぎたので、思わず三度見をしちゃいました。
An eloquent hunk passed by me and I had to do a triple-take.

mnemonics.meaning: A pain grudge is pain you feel from the grudge. I wish I could change my grudge. It is my regret.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 痛恨のミスをしてしまい、彼にアドバイスしてもらうはめになりました。
I made a mistake I regret and ended up asking him for advice.

mnemonics.meaning: A rest rest is a rest. A break. A recess.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今までに、休憩を取ることを考えたことはありますか。
Have you ever thought about taking a break?

mnemonics.meaning: A cook food container is a container used to cook the main food staple in Japan. In this case it's a rice cooker.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私達はみんな、剛志が炊飯器を買うのを楽しみにしています。
We are all looking forward to Takeshi buying a rice cooker.

mnemonics.meaning: Smashed stone is smashed stone. It's rubble and broken stone.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この道は現在砕石舗装工事中です。
This road is currently being paved.

mnemonics.meaning: What do you get when you roast mochi? Senbei, a crispy Japanese rice cracker!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned the on'yomi for the second kanji, but if you remember the meaning of the word, that will get you to the reading. In case you're having trouble, here's a mnemonic to help: You sit eating senbei next to a bay (べい), looking out over the water as you crunch.

sentences: これは東京土産の煎餅です。
These are rice crackers, a souvenir from Tokyo.
やっぱり煎餅には煎茶が合うよね。
Green tea always goes well with senbei.
ビエトは苛々して煎餅を投げた。
Viet got annoyed and threw the rice crackers.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: うちのチワワに二平方尺の犬小屋を作ってあげました。
I made a two square foot dog house for our Chihuahua.

mnemonics.meaning: An attack that causes a crash is when you're shooting down something, usually an aircraft.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: iPhoneで軍事飛行機がヘリコプターを撃墜する瞬間を撮影しました。
My iPhone captured the moment that the military plane shot down the helicopter.

mnemonics.meaning: I am sad and pathetic in how I feel. Such a deep sorrow! Such grief from my sad pathetic feelings.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: ベーコンを取り上げられたプードルは、悲哀と悲しみに満ちた声でクーンクーンと鳴いていました。
The poodle, whose bacon had been taken away, was whining with a voice full of sorrow and grief.

mnemonics.meaning: Divideable chopsticks are chopsticks you can split apart. They are splittable chopsticks, almost always made from wood of some kind.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 割る and 箸 put together. Be careful of the rendaku.

sentences: 日本の首相を歓迎するために、通りは割り箸で飾られました。
The streets were decorated with chopsticks to welcome the Japanese prime minister.

mnemonics.meaning: Sticky sticky things are really sticky and covered with stickiness.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 粘る. I suppose you never never want to touch something sticky.

sentences: 綿棒で犬の耳垢を取ったら何だか粘々していたんですが、それは普通ですか。
I removed my dog’s ear wax with a cotton swab and it was kind of sticky. Is it normal?

mnemonics.meaning: You stab your likeness suddenly. The reason it's so all of a sudden is because who stabs their likeness? The person looks just like you, and... well... wow, really? Is this highlander?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼女が突如彼をセクハラで訴え始めたのには理由があります。
There is a reason for her sudden accusations of sexual harassment.

mnemonics.meaning: You use your lie to take what you want. That's when you swindle or cheat someone to get their stuff. How dare you!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私は偽の売買契約書で、お金を詐取されました。
My money was swindled by a forged title deed.

mnemonics.meaning: A scroll of shaku. So, a scroll is all rolled up, right? And a shaku is an older form of Japanese measurement. If you roll up a measuring thing into a scroll-like container... what does it become? A tape measure!
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 巻 is the 巻く reading, pushed into the kanji. The 尺 reading is the normal reading of 尺. Careful of the rendaku.

sentences: この巻尺で胸囲を測るのを手伝ってもらえませんか。
Could you help me get my chest measurement with this tape measure?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes right from the vocab meaning, which is tatami mat. The たたみ part, specifically.

sentences: 私は畳の上に脱ぎ捨てられた、表裏が逆になった皺々のワイシャツを見つけました。
I found his inside out, wrinkled dress shirt on the tatami where he threw it.

mnemonics.meaning: 陰 is a shade or shadow. For some reason when you add お to shade it becomes "thanks to," as in "thanks to you, I was able to pass the test." Just think about a shade helping you out. Perhaps thanks to the shade you were able to survive the heat of the desert.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from the word 陰. Thanks to that other vocab word, you can read this one!

sentences: 皆様のお陰で、我々は甲子園球場で開催されている高校野球のトーナメントで、準々決勝にまで進出することができました。
Thanks to everyone, we could go to the quarter-finals of the Japan National High School Baseball Tournament held in Koshien stadium.

mnemonics.meaning: A black fog is going to be a really thick fog or black veil that covers suspicious acts or crimes. It's not a literal cloud of fog or a physical veil, it's what you hide your bad deeds in, metaphorically speaking.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 黒い and 霧.

sentences: ホームステイ先のお父さんが、今日の夕飯の際に黒い霧事件について説明をしてくれました。
My home stay father explained the Black Mist Scandal to me at dinner tonight.

mnemonics.meaning: 疲れる is "to be exhausted." This is the noun version, which makes it tiredness or fatigue.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 疲れる.

sentences: うちの町が大雪に見舞われて、昨日は一日中雪かきしなきゃいけなかったんだよ。もう疲れてクタクタだよ。
Heavy snow hit my town and I had to shovel it all day yesterday. I’m already worn out.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sticky and the verb vocab version is to be sticky. It can also mean to persevere, because if you're being sticky towards the situation, not giving up and not letting go. You're totally persevering by sticking around.
mnemonics.reading: Will I give up? I'll nevah (ねば) give up! I'll also nevah unstick from you.

sentences: ええっ！あのセールスマンまだうちの母ちゃんと話をしてるよ。粘るね〜！
Wow! That salesman is still talking to my mom. How persistent!

mnemonics.meaning: 磨く is "to polish" or "to shine." If you're doing that to your teeth you are brushing them. That's why this is to brush one's teeth.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 歯 and 磨く, put together.

sentences: 「どうして歯を磨かないの？」「だって、食べ物の味が口に残っているのが好きなんだもん。それっていけないことかしら？」
"Why don’t you brush your teeth?" "Because I like how the taste of food stays in my mouth! What’s so wrong with that?!

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means carve and the verb version is to carve something, or to engrave something. This is a transitive verb, meaning it can take a direct object. You engrave letters into a stone, and you carve a scary face into a pumpkin. Those letters and that face are your objects.
mnemonics.reading: Imagine trying to carve something using a hoe (ほ). Its long handle makes it a pretty impractical tool for carving. Now imagine all the trouble you have carving with it.

sentences: その石には仏像が彫ってありました。
There was an image of Buddha carved into the stone.
この由緒ある神社の前には、白鳥が彫られた門がある。
In front of this historic shrine, there's a gate with a swan carved on it.
工場で、彫刻機を使って文字を彫る仕事を担当しています。
At the factory, I'm in charge of engraving text using an engraving machine.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means deceit, so when you're doing deceit, you are going to deceive someone.
mnemonics.reading: As a human everyone would know who you are. You can't deceive anyone like that. But, as a moo (あざむ)... a cow is what I mean... nobody would know who you are.

sentences: 孝志は彼女をうまく欺いた。
Takashi successfully deceived his girlfriend.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means drip and the verb vocab version is to drip.
mnemonics.reading: To drip drip drip on your head... what's dripping on your head? You're standing below a toilet that's leaking. The dripping sounds like "sh*tt, ta, ta (したた), with each drip making a "ta" sound because it's kind of thick and poopy.

sentences: 彼の額から、血が滴り落ちました。
The blood dripped from his forehead.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means folding fan and since you don't "to folding fan" something, this word means to fan instead.
mnemonics.reading: Imagine yourself trying to fan yourself with an 青 (あお) fan. For some reason blue fans feel cooler. Maybe it's because they're the color of ice/water?

sentences: 重ね着しすぎてすごく暑いんだけど、ちょっと私に向かって扇いでくれない？
I’m wearing too many layers and it’s so hot. Could you fan me?

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hate and the verb vocab version is to hate or to detest.
mnemonics.reading: What do you hate and detest more than anything? 肉 (にく). That stuff is gross, and you detest it.

sentences: 私は母を憎んだが、母も同様に私のことを憎んでいました。
I hated my mom and she hated me just the same.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means grudge and the verb vocab version is to hold a grudge.
mnemonics.reading: Who do you hold a grudge against the most? That would be you, Ra (うら). You and your dumb sun.

sentences: どうしてあのスタントマンを恨んでいるんだい？
Why do you have a grudge against that stuntman?

mnemonics.meaning: 澄む is "to become clear" - this is when you make something clear, because you must (ます) make it clear. You have to. That's why this is or to make something clear or to clear something. This can also mean to strain when used together with 耳, as in 耳を澄ます, "to strain one's ears".
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the kanji, so if you know that, that'll make this answer clear too.

sentences: 今立て込んでるんだ。後で戻ってきてから泥水を澄ますよ。
I'm in the middle of something. I'll come back later and make the muddy water clear.
私は、一つ上の階からコンスタントに聞こえてくる気味の悪い金切り声を聞くために、耳を澄ましました。
I strained my ears to hear the faint but constant screeching coming from upstairs.
少佐は、大佐に怒られても澄ました顔をしていた。
The Major kept a composed face even when the Colonel was angry with him.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how 湿る is "to be moist"? This is the version where you're doing the moistening, making it to moisten or to dampen.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as 湿る.

sentences: 唇を舐めて湿らせることは、結局その後乾燥させてしまうことになりうるので、あまりいいことではありません。
Licking your lips to moisten them isn’t good because it can actually dry them out instead.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means rest and the verb vocab version is to rest or to relax.
mnemonics.reading: I'm going to rest and play some Ico (いこ) on the ol' PlayStation.

sentences: この山小屋でちょっと憩わないか。
Why don’t we rest for a bit in this hut?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 剣道の試合で、コウイチは竹刀で相手の胴を完璧に討ち取りました。
In a kendo match, Koichi hit the lower part of the opponent’s torso perfectly with his bamboo sword.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means zero, but the verb vocab version means to spill something or to drop something. Think of it this way, if you spill something, eventually it will reach zero.
mnemonics.reading: Imagine a barrel of corn cobs, spilling and dropping out corn cobs, until they reach zero.

sentences: 「あんた、今カーペットに珈琲を零したでしょう？」「しまった!ごめん!」「ごめんで済んだら警察はいらないわよ！」
"Did you just spill coffee on the carpet?" "Oh no! Sorry." "If sorry fixed everything, we wouldn’t need the police!"

mnemonics.meaning: A car manipulator is someone who manipulates the car. This 車 riffs off of 電車, which is a train, making the train manipulator a train conductor.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 車掌は、乗客たちを待たせていることについて、お詫びをした。
The train conductor apologized to the passengers for keeping them waiting.

mnemonics.meaning: The above lip is the upper lip.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 上 is a bit weird, it's うわ instead of うえ. It's almost like うえ, just a little different.

sentences: 疲れると、上唇がよく腫れちゃうんですよね。
When I’m tired my upper lip usually swells.

mnemonics.meaning: 眺める is "to stare at." The noun version is view or scene. It's what you're staring at.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as 眺める.

sentences: シャワーの後、髪の毛が半乾きのまましばらく部屋の窓からの眺めを見つめていました。
After taking a shower, she was staring at the view out her bedroom window for a short while with her hair still damp.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: ブロック塀の取付け費用がいくらかかるのかが知りたいんですが。
I want to know how much concrete-block wall installation will cost.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The willow you have outside is a naggy willow, always asking for more water. That's yah naggy weeping willow.

sentences: あの居酒屋の柳模様の暖簾が好きなのよね。
I like the willow design on that Izakaya restaurant’s curtain.

mnemonics.meaning: This is like 嬢さん, but even more polite. You usually use it when addressing a young lady. If your friends have any young daughters, you can call them this to sound like a true lady/gentleman yourself.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as 嬢さん and uses the reading from the kanji.

sentences: 部長のお嬢さんは確か歌手志望じゃなかったですっけ？
Isn’t the manager’s daughter a wannabe singer?

mnemonics.meaning: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means form.
What's under this lid that smells like poop? I don't know! How mysterious.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means sunlight.

A scooter with horns with a pig riding on it will be able to accomplish anything. Imagine the pig scooting around. It is able to accomplish anything you can imagine (so go nuts with your imagination).
mnemonics.reading: It was even able to successfully accomplish a feat that involved it jumping its scooter right into a swing (すい), swinging back and forth, then jumping off. Perhaps it even takes the swing all the way around in a full 360 degree rotation. This horned scooter riding pig can truly accomplish anything.

mnemonics.meaning: Flowers are mysteriously appearing in the rice paddy. No matter what you do to them, they continue to amass. Imagine yourself spraying poison on these mysterious flowers, but they just double in size, and continue to amass.
mnemonics.reading: As the flowers amass it starts attracting wildlife. Soon thousands of baby chicks (ちく) are amassing in the rice paddy as well.  Feel the wetness of the rice paddy under your feet and the fluffiness of the chicks pressing in on you. Watch the looming, mysterious flowers above you as the chicks smother you.

mnemonics.meaning: The moon has a lot of power that is power it gets from the power of every armpit of every human on earth! Why does your armpit smell? It’s because the moon is draining the power from your armpit. The moon saps power from your armpit and that power is sucked up into the sky where the moon collects the power for its own devices. Imagine an aura of stinky power traveling from your armpit to the moon. Feel the power leaving you as the moon saps your power through your armpits.
mnemonics.reading: This is a pretty wacky (わき) armpit image isn’t it? Seeing lines of power traveling from your armpit to the moon. Definitely wacky. Have you ever seen something this wacky in real life? Imagine this whole scene again but keep in mind how wacky it all really is. The moon sapping power from you through your armpits? So wacky.

mnemonics.meaning: Give a district weapons and it will assault other districts. Picture two districts using weapons to assault each other from above. Like in a video game, with little arrows showing you where they're launching each assault.
mnemonics.reading: This assault is all the 王's (おう) fault. The 王 gave the weapons to each of the districts on purpose so this would happen. Picture the districts assaulting each other from above again, and then pan out and see the 王 standing above, watching it all happen. He's cackling.

mnemonics.meaning: Having a foul mouth and horns will prevent you from getting into Heaven where you would blossom into an angel. If you have horns, you are not meant for Heaven and will not blossom there. To blossom in Heaven, you must not have horns or a foul mouth. Swear like a sailor as you imagine yourself with some horns. You’re not going to blossom in Heaven. You’re going to blossom in Hell and become a demon.
mnemonics.reading: You don’t want to blossom into a demon so you saw (さ) off your horns with a saw. If you saw off your horns, maybe you can beg for forgiveness and have your foul mouth forgiven. Imagine taking a saw to your horns and sawing them off. Hear the reverberation of the saw in your skull as you painfully saw off your horns.

mnemonics.meaning: Cast a book in gold to make a bowl. Books can be bent into the shape of a bowl, so then all you have to do is pour gold over it to keep it in that shape and ta-da! A bowl has been born! Imagine creating this bowl yourself. Try not to burn your fingers with that hot gold.
mnemonics.reading: The gold bowl has a hatch (はち) attached to it, which used to be the book's back cover. That's fine, you use the hatch as a lid for the bowl! Okay, so this may not be the best bowl. You usually don't need a hatch or this much gold coating. But that's how they used to do it in the old days, so that's good enough for you!

mnemonics.meaning: Your servant uses a stool to break open shellfish. You know how much work shucking shellfish is so this method is really clever. You knew hiring this servant was a good idea. "Clever girl," you say, as your servant sits on some shellfish again.
mnemonics.reading: "More clever than you!" your servant yells, tearing off his wig. "It is I, Ken (けん) the samurai. I saw you take this shellfish from my master's lands." You thought you were being so clever, taking shellfish from someone else. It turns out, there is a cost for being shellfish.

mnemonics.meaning: You use a cleat to climb a tree and your hair gets the same coloring as the foliage because your hair is like a chameleon. The coloring of your hair changes to whatever color is around you, so you use your cleats to climb trees to make your hair turn green and brown, and in the fall, yellow and orange and red! Imagine digging your cleats into the bark of the tree until you get high enough for your hair to start coloring itself tree colors. It might be a lot of work, but it's worth it.
mnemonics.reading: This cool coloring can only happen because you turned yourself into a cyborg (さい). Your hair and scalp are now made of high tech parts, not human ones. You couldn't take the pain of losing your cyborg, so you've become one. Your robo-hair can change its coloring, but soon you'll be even more cyborg-y than before!

mnemonics.meaning: In this building there's a small sun that's small. They keep this small, small sun inside of a crevice. You wouldn't want to keep a sun out in the open, even if it's small (and small). You'd put it inside something, like a crevice. Imagine walking into the building and seeing the small sun right inside, in a crevice.
mnemonics.reading: They keep the sun in the crevice because this is a place where people ski (すき). If the sun were out in the open, it'd melt all the snow, making it hard to ski here. So they hide the sun away in a crevice so people can ski.

mnemonics.meaning: You need to put a clown in the dirt if you want to cultivate good crops there. Clowns act as a natural fertilizer, and this will make it super easy to cultivate any crops you could ever want in this dirt. Isn't nature amazing? Imagine burying a dead clown in the dirt and then planting some seeds on top. It's worth it, you think, if it helps cultivate your crops.
mnemonics.reading: Before you can start this whole cultivation process however, you have to say bye (ばい) to the clown. Say bye to him, then bash his head in, and drop him in the dirt. Saying bye is polite. Never forget to say bye, even in the middle of a cold-blooded clown murder.

mnemonics.meaning: Your foot, as your mama says, was given the task to dance. Shake those two foots your mama gave you and dance dance dance! Picture your mama asking you to dance. The two of you pick up and kick your feet to dance, spinning 'round and 'round.
mnemonics.reading: You both dance so much that you develop an odor (おど). Not just any odor, an odor particular to stinky dancing feet. Lean down and take a big whiff of your dancing feet. The odor is... HORRIBLE! AHGH!

mnemonics.meaning: This gate makes the sound of darkness. The gate looks like darkness, but it’s even more creepy that it sounds like darkness too. Imagine this gate making an ominous sound. The sound of darkness. Look deep into the darkness of the gate as you hear the sound it makes. Ouummmmm…
mnemonics.reading: You decide to taste the darkness and discover that it is so yummy (やみ)! Who knew that darkness was so yummy? Mmm… this darkness tastes so yummy! Take the darkness in your hands. It’s like really dark cotton candy. Imagine eating it and how yummy it is. Keep hearing the sound it’s making as you eat. Yummy!

mnemonics.meaning: You have a surplus of ladles laid out diagonally in front of you. Why are they diagonal? And why do you have so many ladles? Why the surplus? Hang on, we'll get there. Look at all these ladles lying diagonally in front of you. Pick them up. Feel the wood grain. Wonder why you have so many.
mnemonics.reading: In front of this diagonal pattern is a shaman (しゃ) who is currently staring at you. You slowly reach down and turn one of the ladles around, diagonally, and look back up. The shaman's eyes are wide, and now they're scribbling on in a notebook. Uh oh, is this one of those weird tests where they find out if you're the chosen one or some old scholar reincarnated? Who knew laying ladles at diagonal angles could reveal this kinda stuff?!

mnemonics.meaning: You see shrimp on ice at the market in the morning. "I'll get some on the way home" you think to yourself. Later that evening, you see no shrimp, just ice. The supply of shrimp has been exhausted. It's all gone!  Imagine the lack of shrimp on the ice. All you wanted was some delicious shrimp for dinner, but now it's all gone 😩
mnemonics.reading: How could the store exhaust its shrimp supply so quickly? Suddenly you notice the worker behind the fish counter has shrimp stuffed into their jeans (じん) . Aha! The culprit!  Imagine the worker's jeans and how gross they are with all those shrimp stuffed into them. Yuck!

mnemonics.meaning: Rain falls off a tree and lands in your eye where it turns to frost. It turns to frost because it’s super cold outside and your body is freezing. The rain that fell off the tree turns to frost as soon as it hits your eye. Feel the rain hit your eye and then crystalize into frost immediately. The rain in your eye is wet, and then very cold as it becomes frost.
mnemonics.reading: This whole description is pretty emo. You came up with this whole emo frost idea because you are a shemo (しも). An emo who goes by she pronouns.  Picture yourself walking proudly, casting your frost gaze at all who you pass. "Wow look at that frosty, cool shemo. She's sooooo cool!" you hear them whisper. (Haha cool, get it? Because you're frosty and also a little sad, which is totally in when you're a teen.)

mnemonics.meaning: You need to feed this grain to a flower wearing turkey on a stool so you start the harvest. Grains don't pick themselves, you have to harvest them. Picture this fat turkey with flowers on its head, sitting on a stool. It's gobbling for grains and you need to be the one who harvests them.
mnemonics.reading: You're just starting to harvest the grains when an angry cock (かく) shows up! He's mad because these are his grains and you're about to harvest them and feed them to a turkey instead of him. Imagine an angry cock chasing you around as you try to harvest grain. He keeps pecking you, ouch!

mnemonics.meaning: This canopy of trees isn't actually a canopy of trees at all. When you look closely, you see these trees are actually giant stalks of hemp. Wow, these hemp plants are so big that they look like trees. But, despite their size they're still just hemp.
mnemonics.reading: Who planted all this hemp? Your mama (ま) did. Your mama knew that you were going to like hemp in the future, so she planted these hemp plants for you. What a great mama.

mnemonics.meaning: An odd horse is still a horse. It may look a little funny, but that doesn't change what it is on the inside. Look at this odd horse. Hear it whinny and neigh like a normal horse. It's not so odd, after all.
mnemonics.reading: This horse is particularly odd because it knows how to use a key (き). It carries a key around its neck and uses it to get in and out of its stable. Watch the horse take the key in its mouth and open the stable doors. It may be odd, but it sure is resourceful.

mnemonics.meaning: The landslide measurement humiliates you. You told everyone you couldn't come to work, that your house had been destroyed and your car was carried away, but then scientists measured the landslide, and it only went a few feet. Honestly, that's what you get for lying. But it doesn't make it any less humiliating even if you deserve it.
mnemonics.reading: Your friends and coworkers humiliate you more by making jokes (じょく). "Uh oh, I heard it might rain later, I hope you don't drown in the inch of water that's coming!" Imagine all of the cruel jokes people say to humiliate you. Feel your face burn and your stomach flip.

mnemonics.meaning: Fire you use to light up the street needs to go in a lamp. Campfires, matches? No, none of those work. You need bright, safe lamps to keep the street nice at night. Picture these lamps lining the street, with their little fires burning brightly. Nowadays we don't have real fire in them, we use electricity!
mnemonics.reading: These street lamps were first used in とうきょう. It was the most advanced city after all. And more people were out at night in とうきょう than anywhere else in Japan. So they needed lamps to light things up! Picture とうきょう, not lit up by all of the electricity, signs, shops, and things that light up its streets today, but by old-fashioned fire lamps!

mnemonics.meaning: In the mysterious rice paddy there is some livestock. This livestock is also mysterious because no one knows where it came from. The mysterious livestock are only seen in the mysterious rice paddy. How mysterious indeed. Examine this mysterious livestock from a distance. Imagine them floating around the mysterious rice paddy like they aren’t even walking. Hear them moo and oink as well.
mnemonics.reading: Your favorite member of the mysterious livestock crew is a little chick (ちく). The chick is very cute and little. The chick is also very mysterious because it floats about without even flapping its little wings. Look at this chick bobbling about in the air. It looks very ephemeral and other worldly. Still a very cute chick though. You want to pet it.

mnemonics.meaning: The tsunami hits your form and you begin to melt. You are a witch and water makes you melt. The tsunami is a lot of water, so once it touches your form, you begin to melt. Feel the water from the tsunami crashing into your form. Feel the water on your body as your form begins to melt. I’m melting! I’m mellltiinnnggg!
mnemonics.reading: The only way to reverse the melt process is to eat some yogurt (よう). The yogurt counteracts the melting from the water and your form will become whole again. Quick, eat some yogurt! Feel the melt begin to reverse as you eat your yogurt. Taste the yogurt on your tongue as your form begins to solidify once again.

mnemonics.meaning: The type of insect that ruins your writing is the mosquito. You're trying to write, when you hear that horrible high-pitched mosquito noise in your ear. You jerk your head and swat and it's gone. But when you look down, there's lines all over what you were writing. Imagine sitting at your desk writing when a mosquito starts bzzzzing in your ear. You can't ignore it, it's gonna bite you. So you flail around helplessly.
mnemonics.reading: That mosquito noise sounds like it's driving a tiny car (か) in your ear. How are you supposed to write with a bug driving around going bzzz bzzz like a revving car? You can't. You can't write like this. You need to kill the mosquito and its little car too.

mnemonics.meaning: Take your towel and make it long. It has to be longer than that! For this will be your notebook, which you will write all your notes in. You are making the towel really long, because it's white and it might be good for writing in. It's going to become your notebook.
mnemonics.reading: Inside your long towel notebook you just write the same name over and over again: "Mrs. Chou" (ちょう). Something bad is going to happen, and you need to warn everybody. It's her, it's her, it's her. Mrs. Chou, Mrs. Chou, Mrs. Chou!

mnemonics.meaning: A tsunami surplus will cover all the dirt with paint. The surplus of tsunamis will strike the paint factories first (everyone knows paint factories are built close to the ocean). Then the paint will flow over all the dirt and paint it a ton of rainbow colors. Picture all of the different colors of paint being swept along by tsunami after tsunami, painting the dirt as it goes.
mnemonics.reading: You touch the paint in the dirt with your toe (と) to see if it's still wet. It is. The paint is still very wet and now your toe looks like a tiny rainbow. Imagine dipping each of your toes into the paint-dirt, one by one, to paint each of them a different color. Why are you doing this?

mnemonics.meaning: Your shellfish are worth a fortune because you decided to paste your fortune to the shellfish. Picture all of your riches, your money, your jewels. They're all pasted directly onto all of your shellfish!
mnemonics.reading: You're a little crazy, which is why you decided to use paste to paste your entire fortune to these shellfish, and as you paste each one you yell out, "Ha (は)!" Paste. "Ha ha!" Paste paste. "Ha ha ha!!" PASTE PASTE PASTE.

mnemonics.meaning: The sunlight shines on your forehead in your car with a great radiance. The car you are in is a convertible, so the sunlight shines right onto your big bald forehead. The sun has a pretty powerful radiance as it is, but the sheen from the sunlight hitting your forehead is the most powerful radiance ever witnessed by man. Imagine this radiance emanating from your shiny dome. The radiance is blinding!
mnemonics.reading: This radiance is the key (き) to powering your car. Your car runs on reflected solar energy, and the radiance coming from your forehead is the most powerful source of radiant sunlight ever imagined. Your forehead is a perfect key for this car. Point your shiny forehead, filled with radiance, at your car. Hear the engine start and jump to life as you power it with the reflected sunlight from your forehead.

mnemonics.meaning: When your soul has an idea it's just a recollection of something you already know. Only your brain can have original ideas, so when your soul tries to come up with one, it's just a recollection of something you thought before now. When you have a recollection of some idea or thing in the past, it's just your soul saying, hey remember this? Let's not forget this.
mnemonics.reading: Your soul is sending you a recollection right now of... your past life as a farmer in Oklahoma (おく). You see yourself farming and sweating and living a wonderful life. Hmm, maybe you should move to Oklahoma and live the simple life again. Imagine recollecting a past life in Oklahoma. Life was simple and nice. You should consider taking this as a sign to move there again!

mnemonics.meaning: If you try to put your soul into everything, you'll regret it. It's not so much that putting your soul into things is bad, but every single thing? You'll burn out immediately. You won't be able to be good at any of those things. And you'll regret all the time you wasted trying to be the best at everything. Imagine if you went full force into everything you've ever even thought of doing. Imagine how burnt out your soul would be. Imagine all the regret you'd have that you didn't just stick to one thing and do it well.
mnemonics.reading: The regret is too strong for you to ignore, so you decide to drop everything but kayaking (かい). If there's one thing you refuse to regret, it's your bright orange kayak and all the friends you made at kayaking club. Throw everything you regret away. Only kayak from now on.

mnemonics.meaning: You take a rake in for a measurement but it is resistant. The rake doesn’t want to have its measurements taken. The rake is resistant to have any measurement taken because it feels inferior to the other rakes and doesn’t want to be embarrassed if it ends up being smaller than the others. Try and move this rake over to the measurement table. It is resistant so you have a hard time moving it. Imagine the rake struggling and resisting endlessly.
mnemonics.reading: Because the rake is persistently resistant, you eventually tie it to the table with your neck tie (たい). The tie won’t hold for long, so you need to take each measurement quickly. See yourself tying the tie around the rake and attaching it to the measurement table. The rake is still jostling around, but the tie keeps it from moving about too terribly much.

mnemonics.meaning: On a cliff, the pope is holding a shield. The pope is near the edge of the cliff and is using the shield to fend off demons. The demons want to shove the pope off the cliff, but the pope is using his holy shield of popery to fend them off. Imagine the shield glowing brightly as hymns play in the background. The demons try to get close to the pope to shove him off the cliff but the holy shield is too bright and popey.
mnemonics.reading: The light of the pope's shield begins to fade. The shield's holy power is waning! Just as the demons are about to push him off the cliff, the sun begins to rise. That's right! It's June (じゅん) and summer has just begun. The pope's shield reflects the power of June's bright sun into the eyes of the demons, casting them off the cliff behind him and back into hell! This pope would have been in a lot of trouble if June's summer sun hadn't risen at just the right moment. His shield would have become useless and he might have been shoved off the cliff if it was a less sunny month.

mnemonics.meaning: There is an insect on the roof in a spoon. It's there for the eating, and it's how you plan to attract a snake to your roof. Snakes love insects, especially when they're ready to eat on a spoon. But, snakes don't usually go on top of the roof, so that's why you have to tempt one with an insect in a spoon.
mnemonics.reading: Why don't you just bring a snake up to the roof yourself? Because snakes are heavy (へび). Especially big snakes. They're really, really hebi.

mnemonics.meaning: If the king gives you a knife you become part of his squad. Every king has a knife squad or two protecting him and making sure his subjects keep in line. Imagine if you were given a knife and allowed into the king's squad. Would you let the power corrupt you?
mnemonics.reading: This squad is led by Han (はん) Solo, so it's basically a 50/50 shot that the king is gonna die. I'm not saying Han Solo is a bad squad leader, but his track record isn't the greatest. I mean, best case scenario the king gets stabbed in the arm and they manage to win.

mnemonics.meaning: If you have nothing to eat but your ego, you'll starve. You can't eat it, and your ego is keeping you from accepting actual food or help from other people. You have to check your ego at the door, because you'll definitely starve otherwise.
mnemonics.reading: You starve (thanks ego) and turn into a gargoyle (が). As your stomach aches, your skin turns gray and you slowly harden into a crouched position. Now your starved body has been moved to the top of a castle, where you scare away people and birds with your loud grumbling stomach and scary face.

mnemonics.meaning: You’re so hungry that you eat a table so you won’t starve. If you don’t eat this table, you will most definitely starve, so you eat the table to stay alive. You don’t want to starve, do you? Feel your tummy gurgle in pain. You gotta eat this table. Taste the dry wood taste on your tongue as you eat the table and get splinters in your tongue and gums.
mnemonics.reading: After you finish the table, you still feel like you might starve so you decide to eat every key (き) off your key ring. One by one, you eat each and every key so you don’t starve. Imagine eating every key. Taste the cold metal on your tongue. After you swallow each key, you hear it clink against the other keys already in your tummy. Clink!

mnemonics.meaning: You drive your scooter off this cliff, holding your cross tight to your chest, at a swift speed. Imagine swiftly shooting off the side of the cliff on your scooter, holding the cross for dear life.
mnemonics.reading: Because you had such a swift take off, you didn't notice that your jeans (じん) were ripped right off your body. Until now. Now you're swiftly shooting through the sky as your jeans flutter down toward the ground behind you. You also feel a swift breeze on all of your downstairs bits now.

mnemonics.meaning: There's power, power, and power stacked on top of the moon, threatening to bring it down! The moon actually looks like it wants to threaten you now too. It seems to have grown a big, smiling, angry mouth and it's way closer to you than you've ever seen it. All that power is radiating out of it and down towards you, threateningly.
mnemonics.reading: This extra power-filled moon is now trying to threaten the safety of きょうと. All of きょうと is shaking and getting dark as the moon comes closer and closer. Picture the powerful moon, threatening to crush きょうと and all its residents. If only a small green boy could turn back time and save everyone from this powerful moon!

mnemonics.meaning: Accomplish and go forth! These are your accomplishments. This is your execution of actions.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 恥ずかしいことに、その任務の遂行に失敗してしまいました。
I am embarrassed that I failed the execution of the mission.

mnemonics.meaning: Even though you have this habit you're still able to win. That's why this is And yet, though, and in spite of. Because, in spite of your bad habit, you still won. Frustrating.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from the word 癖.

sentences: 彼は陰では顧客のことを「カモ」と呼んでいる癖に、表ではペコペコ頭を下げておべっかを言っている。
He calls his clients suckers behind their backs and yet he bobs his head and says flattering things to their faces.

mnemonics.meaning: A hemp drunkness is when you take some "hemp" and put it into your body so you don't really feel anything anymore. This is anesthesia.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 麻酔でまだ寝ぼけています。
I’m still half asleep from the anesthesia.

mnemonics.meaning: Livestock will give birth to more livestock. You're in the biz of raising livestock, that's why. This is animal husbandry.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: このトウモロコシは畜産用飼料なので、人間用ではありません。
This corn is stockbreeding feed and not for human consumption.

mnemonics.meaning: Let's paint a cloth's worth of paint on the wall. This is one application or coating of paint.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 昨日は一日中石膏を乾式工法の壁に塗布していました。
I applied plaster to drywall all day yesterday.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Now isn't that a bit wacky (わき)?

sentences: 俺が逆らうと、兄貴はよく脇をこしょばしてきました。
My older brother used to tickle my armpits when I opposed him.

mnemonics.meaning: I have not yet accomplished anything yet. This is only an attempt, so we'll see how it goes.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼は取り付け騒ぎを防ぐ為にもう少しで預金者に嘘をつくところだったが、結局未遂に終わった。
He was very close to lying to depositors to prevent a bank run, but in the end he gave up on the attempt.

mnemonics.meaning: The rear shield is the shield that protects your back. This is your backing or support. So, not a literal shield, but the kind of protection that you want to have anyways.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 後ろ and 盾 put together. Watch out for the rendaku.

sentences: 私は友人の後ろ盾に勇気づけられました。
I was encouraged by my friend’s support.

mnemonics.meaning: The lantern festival dance is the bon festival dance (or bon odori or lantern festival dance). It's a fun time, be sure to go to one sometime!
mnemonics.reading: The reading is 盆 plus 躍り put together into one word.

sentences: みんなが、私に一緒に盆踊りをやってみるようにしつこく言ってきたんです。
Everyone insisted that I try doing the Bon Festival dance with them.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 私は鉢にピーナッツを植えました。
I planted peanuts in the pot.

mnemonics.meaning: A fire bowl is something you use to put fire in. It's a brazier.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the vocab reading for 火 and the reading you learned for 鉢, rendaku'd.

sentences: 私は正座をして、火鉢に手をかざしました。
I sat with my legs bent beneath me and warmed my hands over the brazier.

mnemonics.meaning: The sunlight's radiance is that of brightness and splendor.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼は光輝燦然と旗を掲げました。
He raised the flag in all its splendor.

mnemonics.meaning: Astray coloring is coloring that's all over the place. It's astray all over your clothes. This astray coloring is camouflage.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今日迷彩柄のズボンを買いに行ったんだけど、ひとつも見つけられなかったよ。
I went out to buy some camouflage pants today, but I couldn’t find any.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well, but it also means cannabis as well.
mnemonics.reading: You always smoke your cannabis in the 朝. No other time. Just the 朝.

sentences: これは麻の木じゃないって、何回説明したら分かってもらえるんですか？
How many times do I have to tell you that this is not a hemp plant?

mnemonics.meaning: A horse soldier is a member of the cavalry.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その騎兵の写真、なんだか若かりし頃を思い出すな。
That photo of the cavalries reminds me a bit of my youth.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of clever? It's clever or intelligent.
mnemonics.reading: If you're clever enough, you can start up an awesome company that makes tons of cash. A cash co (かしこ).

sentences: 僕はあまり賢くはないけど、やるときはちゃんとやってみせるよ。
I’m not too clever, but I have my moments.

mnemonics.meaning: With paint I want to attire the wall. Let's put a coating of painting up on the wall.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 遅くなって、本当にすみません。トイレの壁の塗装が思ったよりも長引いてしまって。
I am so sorry for being late. Painting my bathroom walls took me longer than I thought.

mnemonics.meaning: The color coloring is the color of something.
mnemonics.reading: 色 uses the しき reading (remember 景色?). Use that here with the 彩 kanji reading.

sentences: 先生は、その生徒は鋭い色彩感覚を持っていると判断しました。
The teacher concluded that the student had a keen sense of color.

mnemonics.meaning: The return blossom is when the blossoms return. A second bloom. This is another word for a comeback.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the readings from 返る and the kanji 咲. Watch out for the rendaku.

sentences: 九回裏から逆転ホームランで見事返り咲いた。
It was a magnificent comeback in the bottom of the ninth from a come from behind home run.

mnemonics.meaning: A spear and a shield. Totally different things. Not at all like each other. A complete contradiction.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: それってすごく矛盾した状況じゃない？
They’re really contradicting circumstances, aren’t they?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 彼女がマシンガントークを繰り広げていたので、私が会話に入る隙はこれっぽっちもありませんでした。
She talked like a machine gun and there was no room for me to get into the conversation.

mnemonics.meaning: A crevice interval is an area with a crevice or crack.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 隙 is the one you learned with the kanji and the 間 is the 間に合う reading.

sentences: 二台の自販機の隙間に、小銭が2-3枚落ちているのを見つけました。
I found a few coins in the gap between two vending machines.

mnemonics.meaning: Cultivate and foster something. That's cultivation.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 細胞培養を作るには、何を準備する必要がありますか。
What preparations are needed to create a cell culture?

mnemonics.meaning: The livestock life. The life of a beast! Arghhh, damnit, I hate the life of a beast. Damnit.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この畜生め！何でシラチャソースを俺のベッドにぶちまけやがったんだ！
You stupid son of a bitch! How dare you spray sriracha sauce on my bed!

mnemonics.meaning: A dance is a dance.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 盆踊りの練習をして時間を潰しました。
I killed time by practicing the Bon Festival Dance.

mnemonics.meaning: A dance location is a location in which you dance. This is a dance hall or dance floor.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the readings you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 彼女はクラブでベロベロに酔っ払い、踊り場でトロンとした目つきでろれつの回らない会話を繰り広げていた。
She got so drunk at a club that her speech on the dance floor was slurred and her eye movements were slower than normal.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 僕はある梟と目を交換したから、暗闇でも目が見えるんだよ。
I switched eyes with an owl so now I can see in the dark.

mnemonics.meaning: A dark darkness is a darkness. It's the dark.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the kun'yomi reading of both kanji. The reading from 暗い and the reading of the kanji 闇.

sentences: 暗闇で戦う時は、相手の出方を見て、その上でどうするか判断した方がいいよ。
When you fight in dark you should let the other guy make the first move and then decide what to do.

mnemonics.meaning: Starve to death is death from starvation... Starving to death.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 警察は、その寝たきりの老人は餓死したと考えている。
The police think the bedridden old man starved to death.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: A diagonal is anything that's not a right angle. Even if something is at a 七 (なな) percent angle is a diagonal, slanting, tilted angle.

sentences: 水平な横線を引くように言ったのに、ちょっと斜めになっています。
I told him to draw a horizontal line, but it’s slightly diagonal.

mnemonics.meaning: If you shame and humiliate me, I will have a sense of disgrace, shame.
mnemonics.reading: The reading from 恥 is the ち reading, a reading you haven't learned yet. To remember this, just think about how the cheese jock is the biggest disgrace to this sports team. He is cheese, after all. He falls apart and smells funny.

sentences: 彼女を雑誌の表紙に起用することは、恥辱を受けるようなものです。
Using her for the cover of our magazine is like covering it with disgrace.

mnemonics.meaning: Yield a humiliation onto your life. What a disgrace. What a humiliation.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 前年度優勝校と一回戦で当たってしまい、屈辱的な敗北を味わったが、相手が悪かった。
We got matched up in the first round with last year’s champions and suffered a humiliating defeat. It was a bad match.

mnemonics.meaning: House broken livestock are domestic animals / livestock. They're made to live with us in or near our homes.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 日本独特の家畜っていうのはいるんですか？
Is there any livestock unique to Japan?

mnemonics.meaning: I have the nature of being resistant for a long time. Things that are resistant for a long time have good durability.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 太陽光発電のパネルの耐久性がどんなもんなのか気になっています。
I’m wondering how durable solar panels are.

mnemonics.meaning: A soil sack on the edge. Pretend the sacks are lined up around in a circle. It's the edge of a sumo ring. It can also refer to a last moment or critical moment in time, like the moment before getting pushed out of the ring.
mnemonics.reading: The first two kanji (土俵) use the on'yomi reading you learned. The last kanji 際 uses the kun'yomi reading, which you should know via the vocabulary. Just think of these two parts as somewhat separate bits of the word, which is why one part is on'yomi and another (the addition) is kun'yomi.

sentences: その力士は土俵際で踏ん張り、相手力士に打っ棄りを食らわせた。
The sumo wrestler braced himself at the edge of the ring and was able to throw his opponent out.
平和交渉は土俵際で難航して、打ち切りになった。
The peace negotiations ran into trouble at the last moment and were broken off.

mnemonics.meaning: If you exhaust power you are putting out efforts.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: トーフグの社長として、コウイチはサービスの向上に尽力致します。
As the president of Tofugu, Koichi does his utmost to improve the service.

mnemonics.meaning: An electricity lamp is an electric lamp. Nowadays they're all electricity, though, which means it's a lamp.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: うちの嫁さんは全然電灯を消さないんだよね。きっとスイッチがあることを知らないんだと思うよ。
My wife never turns off the light. She probably doesn’t even know there is a switch.

mnemonics.meaning: I need something to provide to me in an emergency, so I'm amassing emergency stores. I'm building up a stockpile of reserves, just in case.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 地下室に一年分のトイレットペーパーの備蓄をしてるんです。
We have a year’s supply of toilet paper stored in our basement.
これで石油を備蓄する必要がなくなりましたね。
Because of this, we don't need to stockpile oil anymore, do we?
ひどい霜で穀物が全部やられてしまった。今年は穀物の備蓄は出来ないかもしれないな。
The grains was all damaged by the heavy frost. I don't think we'll be able to stockpile grain this year.

mnemonics.meaning: I'm resistant and I endure. I have much endurance and perseverance.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 俺は社長の腰巾着かもしれないが、それって俺にはすごい忍耐力があるってことにもならないかな？
I may be following our president around like a shadow, but doesn’t that mean I have great endurance?

mnemonics.meaning: If something is resistant to fire then it is fireproof. Turtles are not this.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この消防士さんの人形は、実際に耐火性の服と手袋を身につけています。
This firefighter figurine is actually wearing fireproof clothes and gloves on his body.

mnemonics.meaning: 紛れる means "to be diverted." A thing that is diverted goes in another weird direction. It's just a fluke or chance.
mnemonics.reading: One reading does follow the 紛れる reading. But the more common reading is まぐれ. Very similar to まぎれる, but the ぎ goes to ぐ.

sentences: そのクイズの答えが当たったのはただの紛れです。
It was just a fluke that I was able to answer the questions on the quiz.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: お父さんなら今うちの冷蔵庫の霜取りをしてるよ。
My dad is removing the frost from our fridge right now.

mnemonics.meaning: A recollection and measurement of the situation is what I use to make a guess and speculation.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 人々は、その試合は八百長だったのではないかと憶測している。
People are speculating that the match may have been fixed.
これはただの憶測だけどね。
It's just my guess.
コウイチの引退について、憶測が飛び交っている。
There has been a lot of speculation about Koichi's retirement.

mnemonics.meaning: Obtain a harvest. When you do this you have a harvest or crop.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: お米の収穫期は今年はいつ頃になりそうですか？
When do you think the rice harvest will be this year?

mnemonics.meaning: The neck of the squad is the most important part of the squad, for if you lose the neck you lose the head (they're all one thing). This person is the head or leader of a group.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word so it uses the on'yomi readings, which you've learned already. Go you!

sentences: どいつが新入生の首班を占めることになると思う？
Who do you think will be the leader of the first-year students?

mnemonics.meaning: A bowl scroll is a little bowl thing that you put on your head. It's a headband.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the reading of 鉢 and 巻く, put together into one word. The reading's pretty weird, but hopefully you can wrap it around your head.

sentences: そのラーメン屋の店主は、いつも色あせた綿の鉢巻を絞めていました。
The owner of that ramen shop was always wearing a faded cotton headband.

mnemonics.meaning: If something is resistant to heat then it is heat resisting.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 友達が耐熱容器の漫画を書いてるんだけど、主人公の容器の「耐熱容器としての限界を感じた」っていう台詞が気に入ってるのよね。
My friend is writing a manga about heat-resistant containers. The protagonist container said, "I’ve reached my limit as a heat-resistant container." I really like that line.

mnemonics.meaning: An assault hit is a hit or strike or blow. Not a friendly hit, that's for sure.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the on'yomi readings of the kanji.

sentences: 突然、背後から知らない男に後頭部を殴打されました。
Suddenly, I was struck on the back of the head from behind by some random guy I didn’t know.

mnemonics.meaning: A horse hand is the hands that ride the horse. These hands belong to a horse rider.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その騎手は、自分の初めてのG1レースの日に朝寝坊をしました。
The rider overslept on the day of his first G1 race.

mnemonics.meaning: Horse horse, look at all these horses. What do you do with horses? You do horse riding.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 運動会の騎馬戦の練習があるので、明日は早起きしなくてはいけません。
I have to wake up early tomorrow morning to practice for the athletic meet’s mock cavalry battle.

mnemonics.meaning: The Empire (帝国) ism (主義) is when you are doing imperialism. Long live the emperor!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the two words this word is made up of, 帝国 and 主義.

sentences: あなたの国は、帝国主義国家ですか？
Is your country an imperialistic nation?

mnemonics.meaning: When text has a diagonal body to it, it is leaning. It is in italics or the italic font style.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: どうしてこの単語の文字のフォントを斜体に変えたんですか。
Why did you change this word’s font to italics?

mnemonics.meaning: A horse samurai is also known as a knight. Onward, knights of the round! Off to find the holy grail!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その騎士は、アメリカ国旗を掲げることを断った。
The knight refused to fly the American flag.

mnemonics.meaning: The meaning of this noun is the same as the kanji, lamp. Can also mean light and torch as well, depending on where you herald from.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is like that of 明るい, which means "bright." At least the あか part is the same. What is a lamp if not 明るい (あか)? Another way to think of it is "what is a bright color?" The color 赤 (あか) is a bright color and would make a sexy lamp.

sentences: その部屋には、小さなロウソクの灯りだけが灯っていました。
There was only a little candle light in the room.

mnemonics.meaning: A slow bloom is a bloom that happens late. It's a late flower or late blooming. Important to know if you're going to go do 花見.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is 遅い and 咲く put together (the same reading you learned from the 咲 kanji). Watch out for the rendaku.

sentences: 冬が長引いたため、今年はうちのお庭の桜は遅咲きでした。
The cherry trees in our yard experienced a late bloom this year due to the lingering winter.

mnemonics.meaning: It can melt a boulder? What is this stuff that's so hot? It's lava. It's also probably made from melted boulders too, come to think of it.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the on'yomi reading for the kanji, but you haven't learned the on'yomi reading for 岩, which is がん. When you think of lava, think about Gandhi, coming out of the lava. He's immune, because he's a robot.

sentences: 火山が溶岩を吹き出していて危険なので、これ以上近づくことはできません。
We can’t go any closer because the volcano is spewing out lava and it’s dangerous.

mnemonics.meaning: If you look to your armpit to see you're looking away from where you should be looking. If you're too busy staring at your armpit while you drive, for example, you'll probably get in an accident. So don't look away like this!
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the reading you learned with 脇 and the reading for 見る.

sentences: いてぇ。どこに目ぇつけて歩いてるんだ！脇見しながら歩いてんじゃねぇぞ！
Ouch. Watch where you’re going! Don’t look away while you’re walking!

mnemonics.meaning: The degrees of radiance show the luminance and brightness of something, so long as the degree is the right degree.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 例えば、太陽の輝度値はとても高いです。
For example, the sun’s luminosity value is very high.

mnemonics.meaning: Big hemp is marijuana or cannabis.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この国では大麻の使用は禁止されています。
It's prohibited to use cannabis in this country.
この葉っぱは大麻の葉っぱに似ているけど大麻じゃないよ。
This leaf looks like a marijuana leaf, but it's not marijuana.
君が失業したのは本当に気の毒に思うけど、でも一体どうして大麻なんて庭で育てていたんだい？
I think it’s really unfortunate that you’re unemployed, but why the hell were you growing marijuana in our garden?

mnemonics.meaning: A memo (メモ) notebook is a memo book or memo pad that you use to write notes in.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, plus メモ.

sentences: 話の途中で申し訳ありませんが、あなたのメモ帳のことでどうしても質問したいんです。
Forgive me for interrupting, but I must ask you a question about your memo pad.
