mnemonics.meaning: When you record recollections in your mind, that concept is the concept of memory. This word is not a specific memory, instead it's the idea of memory itself. So, uh, try to memorize that.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ある臭いが、ある記憶を引き起こすって、聞いたことある？俺は今まさに、下水道に落ちた時のことを思い出しているんだけど。
Do you know how a certain smell can trigger a certain memory? Well, right now I’m thinking about that time I fell in a sewer.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 根っからの蚊取り線香派なんで、電気のやつを使うのは好きじゃないんですよね。
I’m a die hard mosquito coil user, I don’t like using the electric ones.

mnemonics.meaning: A mosquito notebook, for some reason, is a mosquito net. Think of a notebook with graph paper lines on it, perhaps. These lines are shaped like a net. Surround yourself with it to make your own mosquito net.
mnemonics.reading: The first kanji, 蚊, uses the reading you learned. The second kanji has an exceptional reading, や. To remember や, think about how you had to take a giant mosquito net and cover all of Yankee (や) Stadium. They have a rough mosquito problem.

sentences: 十人用の大きな蚊帳はありますか？
Do you have a mosquito net big enough for ten people?

mnemonics.meaning: A hand notebook is a notebook you can hold in your hand. This could simply be a notebook, but it could also be a planner.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the readings you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 手帳を盗み見すると、彼女は物凄く怒りました。
She got unbelievably angry at me when I peeped at her notebook.

mnemonics.meaning: Oil coloring is better known as oil painting. What fine strokes! What fine lines!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 油彩画のコツを掴んできました。
I’m getting the hang of oil painting.

mnemonics.meaning: The painting fee isn't one of money. If you want to paint, you will have to pay the fee for paints and painting materials.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 刷毛に蛍光塗料を付けました。
I dipped the paint brush in the fluorescent paint.

mnemonics.meaning: Things that are swift and fast are going to be quick and fast and rapid and swift. So many quick things.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: こちらの件に関して、迅速かつ丁寧にご対応頂き誠に有り難うございます。
I appreciate your prompt and polite response to this matter.

mnemonics.meaning: Please record it in the notebook. This will be the registry.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 帳簿に記帳をし忘れたため、上司に叱られました。
I was scolded by my boss for forgetting to register some items in the account book.

mnemonics.meaning: My behind regret is the regret from before, which is all regret. So this means regret, or repentance.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 本当に後悔はないんですね。
You really don't have any regrets, do you?
そんなことをしたら、自分が一生後悔の念に苛まれるだけだぞ！
If you do that, you'll only be tormented by regret for the rest of your life!
美人局にいとも簡単に引っ掛かってしまったことを後悔しています。
I regret how easily I got caught in her badger game.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji is regret and this is regrettable. Could also be vexing or annoying as well.
mnemonics.reading: The coup, yah (くや), that was regrettable. The new government isn't all that great.

sentences: 他の人が日本語で何を話しているのか理解できない時、私はいつも悔しい思いをします。
I always think it’s frustrating when I can’t understand what the other people are saying in Japanese.

mnemonics.meaning: A clever person is a sage or a wise person. This word has quite an old-fashioned feel, so you'll mostly see it in old stories!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あの教授、外では賢人って言われてるけど、実は内弁慶らしいぜ。
That professor is called a sage outside the home, but I heard he’s actually a braggart at home.

mnemonics.meaning: Take your savings and amass them. That is your savings.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: うちの祖母は葬式代分しか貯蓄していないと言っていました。
My grandma said her savings is to be used only on her funeral costs.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Think of a big ol' shield. It's so big it will stand (立て) tall right in front of you.

sentences: 盾を買いたいんだけど、どこに行けば買えるのか知りませんか？
I want to buy a shield, do you know where I can go to buy one?

mnemonics.meaning: A diagonal surface is a slant. A slope.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: うちの私道は急斜面になってるので、上まで上がってくるにはスノータイヤがいります。
Our driveway has become a steep slope, so you need snow tires to get up it.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: この町で蛇がペットとして普及した時には、身震いしましたよ。
When keeping snakes as pets spread throughout the city, I trembled.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: あの班は、五輪の左端の輪っかに間違った色を選びました。
That group chose the wrong color for the far left Olympic ring.

mnemonics.meaning: The squad leader is the squad leader. Can also be the honcho (ever wonder where this word came from?).
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼は社交的でみんなから好かれているので、班長に選ばれました。
He is sociable and everyone likes him, so he was elected to be the team leader.

mnemonics.meaning: One person starves and another person starves. Then more people. So much starve that there's starvation going on. It's famine and hunger, everywhere.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: どうしてそんな風にクッキーを踏みつけたりしたんだ？毎日何千何百人という人が飢餓で亡くなるのを知らないのか。
Why would you step on a cookie like that? Don’t you know that thousands of people die from starvation every day?

mnemonics.meaning: A street lamp is a streetlight. Brightening up my street!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 大量の蛾が、各街灯の周りを飛び交っています。
There are a ton of moths flying around each street lamp.

mnemonics.meaning: If you're on armpit duty you're definitely not the lead. You're standing next to the lead's armpit, because you're the supporting actor. You're in a supporting role.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is 脇's reading and 役's reading, put together.

sentences: 彼女、オーディションに受かったって言いふらしてるけど、ただの脇役みたいだよ。
She keeps talking about how she passed the audition, but it looks like she only got a supporting role.

mnemonics.meaning: A telephone (電話) notebook is a book you use with your telephone. It's a telephone book or telephone directory.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この電話帳を整理してしまう方がいいと思います。
We should finish arranging these telephone books.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji is threat and the noun version (here) is threat or a threat.
mnemonics.reading: Think about a threat being sent to you. It's in the form of bad odor (おど). Yuck, what a nasty way to send a threat.

sentences: 寿司屋に行く途中、寿司に醤油をかけたら殺すぞ、という脅しを受けた。
On the way to the sushi bar I got a threat that said I’ll be murdered if I put soy sauce on my sushi.

mnemonics.meaning: The thing that will threaten and then urge you to do something else is the threat and menace.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 脅迫電話を受けた直後に警察に電話をしましたが、彼らは何だか対応したくなさそうでした。
I called the police right after I received the threatening call, but for some reason it seemed like they didn’t want to deal with it.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means amass and the verb vocab version is to amass or to store.
mnemonics.reading: This shares the same reading as 貯える, and the meanings are very close too!

sentences: 彼はとても立派な口髭を蓄えています。
He’s growing such a splendid mustache.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means exhaust and the verb vocab version is to exhaust.
mnemonics.reading: If something is exhausted it's because you used up too (つ) much of it.

sentences: 長い髪を手櫛で梳かしながら、彼女は僕に、あんたにはもう愛想が尽きたわと言った。
While combing her fingers through her hair she told me that she had already fallen out of love with me.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means blossom or bloom and the verb version is to bloom.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: この桃の木は、今までに一度も花が咲いた事がないんですよ。
This peach tree has never bloomed before.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means coloring so the verb vocab version is to color something, because you're doing coloring.
mnemonics.reading: You go to color something, painting the coloring all over the wall. Problem is, the coloring is made of ACID. This causes the wall to erode (いろど).

sentences: 環境に優しいアイテムに切り替えることは、あなたの暮らしを彩ります。
Switching to environmentally friendly items would color your life.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means cook and the verb vocab version is to cook or to boil. Often it has to do with cooking grains (to cook grains).
mnemonics.reading: When you cook something, it's like you're attacking (たく) the food with boiling water or fire or whatever. Attack the food by cooking it!

sentences: ご飯を炊きながら、妹は私に家計が火の車だとぼやきました。
My sister grumbled to me about how the family is in extreme poverty while she cooked rice.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means cool (temperature-wise) and the verb vocab version is to cool oneself or to cool off. Whoo, that feels much cooler now.
mnemonics.reading: You use a special product in a can to cool off with. It's an experimental product that was made by the zoo you're at (because this zoo is really warm, and it's nice to cool down). You use it, and it burns your face off. So, you sue the zoo (すず) for the face burning.

sentences: うちのワンコはあそこの木陰で涼んでいます。
Our puppy is cooling off in the shade of that tree over there.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means cultivate and the verb vocab version means to cultivate.
mnemonics.reading: You have two cheese cars (つちか) that are growing mold. But that's a good thing, because it's the good kind of cheese mold. So, you cultivate the mold on these two cheese cars, comparing the difference between the two.

sentences: 高校時代のクラブ活動を通じて、友情を培うことの大切さについてたくさんのことを学びました。
I learned a lot about the importance of cultivating friendships through the club activities in high school.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means dance and the verb vocab version means to dance.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 海の中の魚達は、みんな太鼓の音に合わせて一斉に踊り出しました。
All the fish in the sea started dancing to the sound of the drum.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means resistant. If you're resisting things, then you're enduring and withstanding them. That's why this is to endure and to withstand.
mnemonics.reading: What is it that you have to endure? A barrage of tacos (た), coming at you.

sentences: 彼のひどい寝起きの口臭に、耐えられなかったんです。
I couldn’t stand his awful morning breath.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. This is an intransitive verb, so this verb means to get spilled, to fall out, or to overflow.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 零す.

sentences: おならをした瞬間、目から涙が零れた。
At the moment I farted, a teardrop fell out of my eyes.
ソファに紅茶が零れてるんだけど！誰が犯人だ？
Someone spilled tea on the couch! Who's the guilty one?
窓から美しいメロディが零れてきた。
A beautiful melody spilled out from the window.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means humiliate so the verb vocab version is to humiliate.
mnemonics.reading: Remember the word 恥ずかしい? It has the same reading as this one, and a similar meaning as well.

sentences: みんなの前で私の事を辱めるのが、どうしてそんなに面白いんですか？
Why do you find it so amusing to humiliate me in front of everyone?

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means melt and this word means to melt something or to melt. You're doing the melting, and you know it because you are the cause (かす) of the melting.
mnemonics.reading: The thing that you melted in this situation is your toe (と). Feel your toe getting melted away. Augghh it hurts.

sentences: 電子レンジでもバターを溶かすことができますよ。
You can melt butter in a microwave too.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means paint and the verb vocab version is to paint and to plaster and to lacquer.
mnemonics.reading: Let's put a new (ぬ) layer of paint on the wall. Then we'll plaster it.

sentences: マニキュアを塗り終わってからまた電話してもいい？
Can I call you back when I finish painting my nails?

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means paste so the verb vocab is to paste (or to stick).
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 肩がこったので、湿布を貼りました。
I have stiff shoulders so I put a compress on them.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means assault. What are some ways to assault a person? How about to punch, to strike, or to hit, to name a few?
mnemonics.reading: Someone is nagging (なぐ) you and nagging you about something. You can't take it any more, so you turn around to punch them in the face.

sentences: ゴングが鳴った瞬間、そのボクサーは相手の顎を思い切り殴り付けた。
The moment the gong sounded, the boxer punched his opponent’s jaw with all his strength.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means radiance. Imagine if something is radiating on something else. That would cause it to shine or to glitter or to sparkle.
mnemonics.reading: The cog yak is so shiny. It so shiny it starts to shine and glitter. I don't know what a cog yak is, but imagine it in your head and imagine it being super shiny, shining off shines and glitter.

sentences: 明るく輝く月の下で、飲酒運転取締り検問所にひっかかり、飲酒運転の罪で速攻逮捕されてしまいました。
Under the bright, shining moon, I was caught in the sobriety checkpoint and promptly arrested for driving under the influence.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means smash and the verb vocab version of the kanji is to smash or to break.
mnemonics.reading: You want to smash my stuff? That's coo' だ (くだ). Whatever you wanna do.

sentences: クッキーが粉々になるまで、伸ばし棒で叩いて砕きました。
I smashed the cookies with a rolling pin until they were broken into small pieces.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means starve and the verb vocab version is to starve or to thirst or to be hungry.
mnemonics.reading: Who is starving? you (う) are starving. You.

sentences: 長年日本語を独学してきたんですが、今は誰かと日本語の会話をすることに飢えています。
I’ve been self-studying Japanese for many years and now I’m starving for conversations in Japanese with someone.

mnemonics.meaning: Reason is not exhausted... but what you're asking is unreasonable. Soon my reason will be exhausted, though.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 超理不尽な上司とやっていかなくちゃいけなくて、理想の仕事が一気に悪夢になったよ。
My dream job turned into a nightmare all at once because I had to deal with such an unreasonable boss.

mnemonics.meaning: "Darkness is nothing to worry about," I said unreasonably and absurdly. Of course darkness is worth worrying about. It's darkness! Who knows what is in there!
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 無闇に女の子に声をかけるのはよした方がいいよ。
You shouldn’t hit on girls indiscriminately.

mnemonics.meaning: A water coloring painting is a watercolor painting.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼女は素晴らしい水彩画家だそうですよ。
She is supposed to be an amazing watercolor painter.

mnemonics.meaning: With water it will melt. It is naturally like this. It is water soluble.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 水溶性のビタミンCはすぐに体内から排出されるので、私達の体に蓄えることはできないと読みましたよ。
I read that water-soluble vitamin C generally leaves the body quickly, so our bodies can’t store it.

mnemonics.meaning: You know that 椅子 is a "chair." What about a car chair? It's a chair with wheels. A wheelchair.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 車 is the vocab reading, くるま. Then, 椅子 is いす.

sentences: あの車椅子に座ってる女の子、めちゃくちゃセクシーじゃない？
Isn’t the girl in the wheelchair ridiculously sexy?

mnemonics.meaning: You're clever and bright so obviously you're going to make wise and sensible decisions. In fact, when you go to make these very wise choices and observations, your brain glows brightly.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: このビールを買うのは賢明なご決断ですよ。コクがあるだけでなく、喉ごしもとてもいいですからね。
Buying this beer is a wise decision. Not only does it have full-bodied flavor, but it also has such a pleasant, clean finish.

mnemonics.meaning: You know that 魔法 is "magic" so what about someone who uses magic? What are they called? How about a wizard, magician, or sorcerer?
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 魔法 is what you learned with the kanji. The reading for 使い is the same as 使う.

sentences: 約束を守らないと、みんなから相手にされなくなるぞ。いいから、お前が先日会ったっていう、その魔法使いを連れてこいよ！
If you don’t keep your promises people won’t take you seriously, so bring the wizard you said you met the other day!

mnemonics.meaning: This radical looks like a small animal (匹) has a crab (其) sticking out of it. Often when a crab is eating a small animal, that small animal was put inside a crab trap to catch the crab, luring it in with the small animal. That's why this radical is crab trap.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means times.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means wild.

Bite a tree's root with your fang to get an approximation on its age. It won't be exact, this isn't scientific or anything, but it will be pretty close. Once you have an approximation on the age, you'll be able to come up with an approximation on how much it's worth too.
mnemonics.reading: As you're recording your approximation down,  somebody comes up and shouts, “Hey guy (がい)! I’ll give you $10,000 for that tree there, guy!” This guy must be crazy. That’s much more than your approximation of the value of this thing. But you sell it to the guy anyway. The guy is trying to look at your approximation now, while calling YOU "guy" over and over, and you just want him to buy it and leave you alone!

mnemonics.meaning: You run your fingers along the words of a  paragraph. You are learning about the law because you plan to arrest somebody. Imagine reading the paragraph very slowly. You find your answer. It looks like you'll be able to arrest that person...
mnemonics.reading: Who do you want to arrest? You want to arrest こういち. Even though he's started wars, created a religion, and trapped a child in a cavity, it's going to be tricky to arrest him because he's the emperor now. Still, according to this paragraph you're running your fingers through, you can do it. You can arrest こういち.

mnemonics.meaning: If someone wants to boil, you let them boil! There's someone in your face yelling about how they want to boil! You yell back, "Okay, if you want to boil, just boil!"
mnemonics.reading: Welp, the pot is at a rolling boil and your knee (に) is in there. The person wasn't saying they wanted to boil, they said they wanted to boil someone. And that meant you. Well, your knee anyway. Once your knee is done boiling, the person kneels down in front of you and presents it on a platter, mocking you, since you can't kneel anymore. You should pay more attention to what's going on from now on or you could find yourself in... HOT WATER. Ohohoho.

mnemonics.meaning: If a helicopter loiters near a black hole then it's going to capsize. I mean, yeah, it's not a boat, but just look, that's what's happening! That helicopter is going down! If you want to save it you better cover up the black hole! The only way to save it from capsizing is to cover it right up! Imagine trying to cover up a black hole so that the helicopter doesn't capsize. It's one or the other, dude. Cover or capsize. You decide.
mnemonics.reading: You're doing your best to cover the black hole to stop the helicopter from capsizing but it's not working! “F**k you (ふく) black hole!" you shout. You just want to cover it up! You just want to do the right thing! Man, f**k you you, black hole. F**k you you. Making that helicopter capsize and then refusing to be covered?

mnemonics.meaning: The horse who can write a paragraph gets to be a chess piece. Only the most erudite of horses gets selected to be a chess piece. The knight’s chess piece is represented by a horse, and for a horse to earn this honor, they must first write a paragraph explaining why they deserve the honor. Imagine a horse trying to write a paragraph about why it deserves to be a chess piece. See the horse struggle with his hooves to write out a paragraph as he neighs in nervous frustration.
mnemonics.reading: Upon being told that he will never be a chess piece, the horse slips into a coma (こま). The horse will never awaken from this coma as he knows he will never fulfill his dream of becoming a chess piece, so he has nothing to live for. See this horse in its coma. You feel bad that it will never be able to be a chess piece, but this is a bit dramatic.

mnemonics.meaning: Your soul connects to five different mouths, enhancing your comprehension. You can easily comprehend what each of those souls belonging to those mouths wants and feels deep down. Imagine being able to comprehend everything about not one, but five other people. Deep down you can feel everything they think and feel.
mnemonics.reading: Your comprehension is the strongest with the fifth mouth, belonging to Godzilla (ご). You finally get why he wants to destroy buildings and cities. Your comprehension of Godzilla reveals so much: he's warning the Japanese people about the use of new technology and warfare and experimentation. He just wants everyone to be able to comprehend these new, seemingly incomprehensible things!

mnemonics.meaning: Your soul is going wild because you're confused. If you're confused, it's usually because you don't know what's going on or what to do. This makes the soul inside your body go absolutely wild! Think back to the last time you were confused. Remember how your soul felt? You were so confused it went wild and made you feel dumb and bad, like a wild person.
mnemonics.reading: Whenever you're confused, こういち appears to offer you guidance. He's confused a lot, so he knows how to help. And knowledge offered by こういち is the best medicine for confusion. Imagine being confused about Japanese, for example. In your confusion everything seems scary and wild and your soul is utterly bewildered, but then here comes こういち. He sits with you and pats your back and tries to help you stop being so confused.

mnemonics.meaning: Watch what you say to what appears to be a sweet tree, because that tree will 100% conspire against you. Trees may look all sweet and innocent, like they aren't listening to every word you say, but it's a front! They're conspiring against you!! They'll blackmail you and take everything!!!
mnemonics.reading: Now you're getting it! That tree is trying to conspire against you and take you down. Take your bowling (ぼう) ball and bowl it and all its friends down! Watch as the conspiratorial tree and all it's gossiping friends are bowled over by your bowling ball. Phew. You're safe from the trees. For now.

mnemonics.meaning: On the roof there's some type of turkey bird, but thinner and longer. You look closer and realize it's a crane. Picture the beautiful black and white crane dancing gracefully on the roof. Now that you know what it is, you feel a little bad about calling it a turkey bird.
mnemonics.reading: The crane leans down toward you from its roof perch and squawks, "Too rude (つる)!" You're shocked! You didn't know the crane could speak English, but even worse, it knew you called it a turkey bird. The crane keeps saying you're too rude whenever other people come close so they know what kind of person you are. Yikes, you really shouldn't have gotten on this crane's bad side.

mnemonics.meaning: You use your fingers and a stone to begin cultivation of the land. You use your fingers to till the soil, the stone to flatten the ground, and you carefully poke the seeds into the dirt and then use the stone to smash them further down. Imagine being in a field, using your fingers and a stone to cultivate the whole thing, by hand.
mnemonics.reading: Cultivation is suddenly halted because a tack (たく) sticks into your finger. You pull the tack out, throw it away and start cultivation again when... ouch! There's another tack. This field is full of tacks! Now cultivation is going to involve getting all the tacks out of here, preferably with the stone and not your fingers, so they don't get stuck anymore.

mnemonics.meaning: You take a lid, and aiming it at the sun you kick it into the air and eventually it begins to decline and crashes into the sun, causing it to supernova. Imagine kicking this lid so hard that it flies into space. See it fly up to the peak of its arch, then watch as it begins the decline until it finally collides with the sun. As you watch the lid decline, keep in mind that the sun radical its middle line extending outside the box on both sides. This is because the sun is going supernova. Pew!
mnemonics.reading: As the lid begins to decline in the sky, you realize what’s going to happen so you attempt to swing (すい) to safety. Swing on some vines in the direction opposite of the sun. You know that once that lid finishes its decline and collides with the sun, there’s gonna be trouble. Imagine swinging on these vines as you hear the sun explode and go supernova behind you. Swing faster! Swing faster!

mnemonics.meaning: A commander who's big will use his size to encourage his troops. "Look at me! You can be a big commander someday too!" he shouts, encouraging everyone.
mnemonics.reading: He encourages the Shougun (しょう) too! You've never seen the Shougun express any emotion other than intense indifference or intense dislike. Picture the encouraged Shougun: his eyes are shining with tears, his heart is pounding, he's been encouraged to be better!

mnemonics.meaning: A tsunami and a couple fires run into each other. They cancel each other out completely, and the remainder left behind is a faint remnant of what was once there. You go to see if you can find any remainder of the fire + tsunami battle. You can, but it's so faint.
mnemonics.reading: Just like the tsunami and fire canceling each other out, leaving a faint remainder of what was, your tan (たん) is extremely faint as well. Look at your skin. It has such a faint tint.

mnemonics.meaning: There’s a stone, a tree, another tree, and a coat rack. That stone and two trees will make the perfect foundation, or cornerstone, for a house to put that coat rack in! This stone is flat and heavy and both of the trees are flexible and durable. Imagine making a foundation with the stone and the two trees so you’ll have a place for your coat rack. Feel the wood grain and cold stone against your skin as you move them around to form the foundation.
mnemonics.reading: After you finish the foundation, the only step that's left is to wash the entire thing with soap (そ). Imagine getting on your hands and knees, rubbing a bar of soap all over the foundation you built. The soap gets into all the nooks and crannies in the wood and stone. Now if a coat falls off the coat rack onto the floor, you just add water and poof! Clean!

mnemonics.meaning: Compare a building to some dirt and you'll see the difference between you and His and Her Highness. You live outside and sleep on the dirt. But His and Her Highness both live in a huge building. Picture Her Highness, high up in her building. Now compare her home and life to yours, you dirt person.
mnemonics.reading: I bet His Highness has never had to sleep in hay (へい) either, like you do every night. Hay is what you use as a pillow, mattress, blanket. Basically hay and dirt are all you have. Unlike His Highness. Picture His and Her Highness coming out of their huge building and walking by you in your hay pile. "My goodness, Highness, have you ever seen such a dirty, fluffy creature?" "My no, dear, let's move quickly to remove it from our sight!"

mnemonics.meaning: In the event of a tsunami, Wolverine, your forehead, and a stool will all be immersed in it. You will become immersed in the tsunami after it hits because tsunamis are gigantic and bring a lot of water. Now you and your forehead are immersed in the tsunami along with Wolverine and a stool. Feel the water all around you as you become immersed in this tsunami. See Wolverine trying to swim his way to the top as you watch the stool floating about in the water.
mnemonics.reading: Still immersed, the stool floats over and hits you in the shin (しん). The tsunami gave the stool a good push and while it was fully immersed, it ran into your shin. It really hurts. Hear the stool crack against your shin and feel the pain erupt through your leg. You try to scream but you’re under water so you just get a big mouthful of tsunami.

mnemonics.meaning: The few members of society without power suffer from severe inferiority complexes. Most people in this world have lots of power, so the few that do not feel quite inferior. It is this feeling of inferiority that fuels their inferiority complexes. Imagine you are one of the few without power. Feel the inferiority crushing down on you. It feels terrible and there is nothing you can do about it.
mnemonics.reading: Since you suffer from such extreme feelings of inferiority, when someone offers you and your friends the chance to gain power, you yell “Let’s (れつ) go!” without a second thought. “Let’s go, guys! Come on! Power awaits us!” Let’s go, let’s go! Time’s a wastin’! I’m tired of this inferiority and want to gain some power!

mnemonics.meaning: This crab trap has the power of intuition. By the power of intuition, this crab trap can trap like, every crab. Through intuition, it knows where the crabs will go and how they will react, so it is much easier to trap them. Look at this crab trap and see it visibly glowing with intuition. Its powers of intuition are so strong that you can actually see it shimmering with intuition as it expertly traps all those crabs.
mnemonics.reading: This crab trap's intuition powers were extracted from Genghis Khan (かん) himself. And as we all know by now, Genghis Khan was the absolute master of intuition, he always knew what his enemies and his allies were about to do. Genghis Khan probably has the strongest intuition of anyone in history. This crab trap is getting close though.

mnemonics.meaning: A building that has a bully will isolate itself. Building have feelings like people, you know. Picture a single building, isolated from the rest of the city and those mean, bully buildings that live there.
mnemonics.reading: The isolated building only has one companion, and it's the cock (かく) that lives inside of it. Picture the sun rising behind an isolated building. A cock lets out a cry from the roof. It's a sad and lonely scene.

mnemonics.meaning: In the foot capital, it's tough to be a dog because you're always getting kicked.  In the foot capital, you can only use your feet. So petting dogs looks a lot like kicking them.
mnemonics.reading: When you kick a dog, there's an explosion of 毛 (け). People in the foot capital are very kick-happy, so you can imagine how much 毛 is in the streets.

mnemonics.meaning: You take a stool, another stool, and yet another stool and stack them on top of a tree to make a mulberry bush. This is how mulberry bushes are made. You take three stools and you put them atop a tree. Imagine putting three stools on top of a tree and watching it transform into a mulberry. The science of nature!
mnemonics.reading: Your mulberry tree then produces a quantity (くわ) of mulberries. Yum. Imagine the huge quantity of mulberries growing from your stool tree. Imagine picking them all. What an enormous quantity of mulberries you now have.

mnemonics.meaning: You give a flag and a spoon to a nun as an offering. You give her this flag and this spoon because they are very precious to you and you want to show the nun how serious you are about repenting for your evil deeds. Imagine handing the nun your country’s flag. And also a spoon that is very valuable to you. Imagine getting down on one knee as you do so.
mnemonics.reading: You’re getting down on one knee (に) as you present the flag and the spoon to the nun. The nun accepts your offer and takes your flag and spoon from you. Your soul is saved! Feel your knee digging into the cold floor as you present your offerings to the nun. You feel slightly sad as she takes your precious belongings from you.

mnemonics.meaning: The king takes his slide into his private jet and is given a pearl as a gift, by you! He's letting you ride in his jet today, and you were told the king should be presented with a pearl as soon as he boards. Imagine giving this gorgeous white pearl to the king after he slides down his slide and boards the jet. See his king face light up as he sees the pretty pearl.
mnemonics.reading: The king takes the pearl and tosses it into a chute (しゅ) next to the slide he took to get into the jet. You watch as the pearl goes down, down, down until it lands into a huge vat of pearls. Oh. I guess the king didn't need your pearl, since he has a pearl chute to get them off his jet before takeoff. You feel silly. And you kind of want to jump into the pearl chute yourself.

mnemonics.meaning: Your fingers give you a good reason to pluck things. You pluck flowers out of the ground. You pluck a cat out of a tree. Why? Because you have fingers! That's your reason. Imagine using your fingers to pluck grapes and apples and other things, maybe non-fruit things.
mnemonics.reading: Now that you have a reason to pluck things (you have fingers, after all) you decide you want to pluck all the fur off of Chewbacca (ちゅう). He is very furry, and you want to know what he looks like under there. What reason could you have for wanting to pluck the fur off Chewbacca? Because you have fingers! So why not?!

mnemonics.meaning: On the dirt there is a lid trying to cover the number of times the dawn has risen here. You walk over and pull the lid off and the whole thing transforms into a podium. A podium for the dawn to tell you how many times it's risen over this dirt over and over again. It just keeps going and you realize the lid was here because this dang podium can't seem to keep a lid on it! (Get it? Figure of speech!) This kanji also just... really looks like a podium right? With a guy wearing a graduation cap, pointing toward you, in the crowd.
mnemonics.reading: You listen to what the podium has to say for so long you finally can't help but ask, "Who are you?" "I'm the dawn (だん), of course!" And this is my podium where I spread the good news about the dawn! I guess that makes sense. This podium is by the dawn for the dawn.

mnemonics.meaning: The only type of can you'll be building in prison is one made of pottery. Do you honestly think they would let you have anything made of metal or plastic? No, too dangerous. You have to make all of your cans and plates and underpants the old-fashioned pottery way. Picture the first piece of pottery you ever made. Feel it in your hands. At least you've learned something new while you've been stuck in prison.
mnemonics.reading: You get so good at pottery that the guards start to notice and offer to sell what you make in とうきょう. とうきょう is a big pottery town, after all. You'll make a fortune! Well... the guards will at least. Selling your prison pottery in とうきょう might even help you get out faster. Yippee!

mnemonics.meaning: A woman sees herself (oneself) as a princess or a queen. As women should!  Just remember, when you're around other women (and woman-aligned peoples), it's important to treat each other like princess and queens, not just oneself.
mnemonics.reading: All of us princesses and queens share a special heat (ひ). When we see another princess or queen that heat passes through us and we nod to one another. All princess and queens can feel the heat coming off of the others.

mnemonics.meaning: Take your greatest treasure, hold a knife nice and close to it, and prune away all the weak and dead bits. All treasures need to be taken care of, no matter what they are. Prune away anything that isn't necessary.
mnemonics.reading: Currently, you want to prune your greatest treasure: your car (か). Your car is made of wood, and it keeps trying to grow new buds and branches, so you have to prune them off. You want your car to be small and sleek, not a giant truck, so you have to carefully prune it when it grows too much.

mnemonics.meaning: You stop a spoon from moving by tying it with thread that's purple. The spoon wouldn't stop moving around, so you had to use your favorite purple thread to make it stop. It's the strongest thread you have. Imagine tying this spoon down with thread that's a color other than purple. Ah, the thread snaps. Darn, you better use your extra strong purple thread (the best color for strength!).
mnemonics.reading: You have to use all of your purple thread, and now you need more. You go into the back yard and call over your purple sheep (し). Oh, did you think purple things were made with dye? No no, purple is a special color. You have to find unique purple sheep to make purple thread and clothes.

mnemonics.meaning: The mouth of that turkey is solely his. It’s very unique, so that mouth could belong to no other turkey but him. That mouth is solely his. Imagine what makes this turkey’s mouth so unique. This beak is solely his. It belongs to no other. This turkey is the only turkey with a mouth like his.
mnemonics.reading: You traveled a long way to see this turkey and the mouth that is solely his but you missed your exit on the highway and you have to hang a U-ey (ゆい). You know what hang a U-ey means, right? It’s making a U-turn. Well, you have to hang a U-ey on the highway so you can get off at the right spot to see this turkey and the mouth that is solely his. Imagine hanging a U-ey on the highway. Hear your tires screech as you turn around and get off where you’re supposed to.

mnemonics.meaning: A hill knife is the most sturdy knife you can find. The reason hill knives are so sturdy is because they are shaped like hills. Very wide, very thick, not so long. So, they don't break and are more sturdy.
mnemonics.reading: This sturdy (but strangely shaped) knife is used by ごういち.  Imagine ごういち rolling the knife back and forth over various things to cut them. "I love my sturdy hill knife," he says.

mnemonics.meaning: If someone loiters it's correct to subjugate them. You can't just let people do whatever they want. If it isn't correct to loiter here, then it IS correct to subjugate them, and force them to do what you want. You control them now. And they're gonna get it!
mnemonics.reading: You subjugate these loiterers with your holy blue saber (せい)! It's the correct thing to do, after all, and you were given this saber all those levels ago because you did the correct thing. As you swing your saber around, subjugating the loiterers, and making them do as you say, you remind yourself that this is correct. And if it's correct, you have to use your saber to enforce it.

mnemonics.meaning: With your fingers under an axe, you say a vow. A vow is a sacred promise, so you have to be really serious when you say one. That's why you do it with an axe hovering above your fingers—it's a reminder that if you break this vow your fingers are gonna get chopped off. Picture the axe hovering above your fingers. Now say the vow. But don't lie. The axe knows when you're lying.
mnemonics.reading: When you finish your vow, you take out your holy blue saber (せい) and cut the axe in half! You know you're never going to break your vow, and if you do, you'll use your own saber to cut off your fingers. Imagine what it would be like to slice off your own fingers with the saber you've carried for so long. You better not break that vow.

mnemonics.meaning: The leader of this valley is very vulgar. The name of the valley is Vulgar Valley, so it makes sense for its leader to be very vulgar. Imagine meeting the leader of Vulgar Valley. Imagine all the vulgar things he says to prove he is worthy of being the leader of Vulgar Valley. He is so very, very vulgar.
mnemonics.reading: This vulgar leader leads his Bosozoku (ぞく) bike gang through Vulgar Valley, patrolling the area and spreading vulgarity as he goes. Hear the motorcycles rev and purr as they carouse the Vulgar Valley. Hear the leader screaming vulgar things as he and his Bosozoku bike gang ride all around.

mnemonics.meaning: A tsunami at the gate of the king makes sure all of his plants get watered. The gate prevents the tsunami from damaging anything inside the king’s home, and the plants around the gate get watered by the water of the tsunami. Hear the tsunami crash into the gate as you see the water slosh around and make sure that all of the king’s plants get good and watered.
mnemonics.reading: These plants are getting watered in June (じゅん), the month they need watering the most. June is a hot month, so it’s good that this tsunami came and got the king’s plants watered when it did. Again, watch and hear the tsunami crashing into the gate and getting the plants watered. This time, remember that the month is June and it is very hot and sticky outside. You’re sweating and very hot.

mnemonics.meaning: Pluck a phenomenon out at random. It doesn't make sense. You can't physically pluck out a phenomenon! The reason is abstract.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼女のレビューは何だか抽象的だったので、あまりよく分かりませんでした。
Her review was kind of abstract, so I didn’t really understand it.

mnemonics.meaning: An approximation of the calculation is an approximation or rough estimate.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 旅行費用の概算を教えてもらえますか。
Could you give me a rough estimate for the travel costs?

mnemonics.meaning: Boiled things turn into boiled foods or stewed foods. You can eat anything, if it's boiled long enough.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the readings you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 彼女は小食ですが、煮物ならモリモリ食べます。
She is a light eater but when it comes to stewed foods she eats with gusto.

mnemonics.meaning: A buddha podium is the podium on which you put Buddha. This is a Buddhist altar.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 仏壇の前でうつ伏せになって寝転がっていると、母がやって来てそれは失礼なことだと怒られました。
When I was laying on my stomach in front of the buddhist altar, my mom came over and told me doing that was rude.

mnemonics.meaning: A pearl calculation is calculations you do with pearls. If you think about using pearls to calculate something, it's going to look a lot like using an abacus. That's why this calculation is calculation with abacus.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

sentences: 今日は珠算を勉強するって気分じゃないんだよね。
I don’t feel like studying calculations on an abacus today.

mnemonics.meaning: It revolves then capsizes. When a ship revolves onto its back and then capsizes, this causes capsizing.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

sentences: ワニだらけの沼沢で私のカヌーが転覆した時は、どっと冷や汗をかきましたよ。
I suddenly broke out in a cold sweat when my canoe capsized in a swamp full of alligators.

mnemonics.meaning: The Pottery art is making pottery. That is the ceramic arts or simply ceramics.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼女の陶芸作品のルーツは、日本文化にあります。
Her ceramic works have roots in Japanese culture.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Can also refer to a shogi piece too, since that's Japanese chess, after all.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 父さんが日曜日にチェスの駒の動かし方を教えてくれるって約束してくれたんだ。
My dad promised me that he would teach me how to move chess pieces this Sunday.

mnemonics.meaning: Vulgar language isn't necessarily bad words, or something like that. It's just rougher and not as standard as standard language. It is a colloquialism or colloquial language.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この俗語はアメリカ独特の表現です。
This colloquialism is an expression unique to America.

mnemonics.meaning: I will subjugate everyone to wear the clothes I want them to wear. They will wear my uniform, for they will be under my subjugation. I will conquest them!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: トーフグが世界征服をしようとしているということを又聞きしてしまいました。
I overheard that Tofugu is trying to conquer the world.

mnemonics.meaning: Under the shade people conspire. When people do this, conspiracy appears.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼は秘密結社が世界を支配しているという陰謀論を信じています。
He believes in a conspiracy theory that a secret society is controlling the world.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned with the vocab.

sentences: たくさんの折り紙の鶴を醤油につけて、日本人の女の子の部屋に置いてみるってのはどうかな。
What about dipping a bunch of origami cranes in the soy sauce and putting them in the Japanese girl’s room?

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how 皇太子 is "crown prince"? Turn this crown prince into a "crown prince queen." Not a real queen, but a child queen. This is the crown princess.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 皇太子妃が軍に志願するはずねぇだろうが。
The Crown Princess would never volunteer for the army.

mnemonics.meaning: 貨幣 is "currency" and 価値 is "value." This shows the currency value. Hopefully it's good for you when you visit Japan!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その時からどれぐらい貨幣価値が変わったか、知っているかい？
Do you know how much the value of money has changed since then?

mnemonics.meaning: Something that declines and retreats from decline is something that's on a decline. It's also decay.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: どの専門家も、投資市場の衰退は信用収縮によって誘導されたと口を揃えて言うけれど、それってつまりはどういう意味なの？
All the experts say that the decline in investments was driven by a credit crunch, but what does that mean?

mnemonics.meaning: Arrest and put the criminal in detention and confinement. Get in there, criminal!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その女性は豆柴を膝に載せたまま酔っぱらっていたので、見かねた警察がその犬を保護拘置し、後から返してあげたそうです。
I heard that the woman was drunk with a miniature Shiba Inu on her lap, so the police, who could not bear to see the situation, took the dog into protective custody and returned it later.

mnemonics.meaning: Your inferiority has changed. In fact, it's getting worse and worse, changing by the minute. Each minute that goes by is another minute where you're getting worse. This is deterioration.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 女優やモデルの見た目が以前よりも老けた時、日本のネット用語で「劣化した」と言います。
When actresses or models age and look older than they use to, the Japanese internet word for them is "deteriorated."

mnemonics.meaning: 明瞭 is "clarity." If there is not any of this clarity, then you have dimness or obscurity.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 説明書を読んだんですが、あまりに不明瞭だったので、新モデルの実力についてちょっと不安に思っています。
I’m a little worried about this new model’s capabilities because even though I read the instructions, they were really unclear.

mnemonics.meaning: Something that invades and eats away at something is something that causes erosion and corrosion.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 木々を切り倒すことで、土壌の侵食が引き起こされることがあります。
Chopping down trees can cause soil erosion.

mnemonics.meaning: If you isolate this month from next month, and then do that over and over again, you'll be looking at every other month isolated from the other months.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 日本文化の授業が隔月で開講されるんですが、今月は餅つきをする予定です。
We have a Japanese culture class every other month and we plan to pound mochi this month.

mnemonics.meaning: Isolate this week from next week, and do that over and over. That way we have every other week.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: このアニメは隔週で放送されていて、私はそのオープニング曲とエンディング曲が好きです。
This anime airs every other week and I like its opening and ending songs.

mnemonics.meaning: A far distance we must travel to subjugate our enemies. This is a long expedition and campaign to do just that!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 豚インフルエンザの流行により、遠征は中止となりました。
Due to the prevalence of swine flu, the expedition was discontinued.

mnemonics.meaning: To pluck and then exit those plucked items is to do an extraction.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 五時までに抽出データを整理してもらうことはできますか。
Could you sort out the extracted data by 5 o’clock?

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of faint? It's faint.
mnemonics.reading: You look at the distance. You see something very faint and pale out there. It's... it's... awwwa (あわ) a puppy! Awwwww! Aawwww!

sentences: 話を変えて悪いけど、淡いピンク色のチーク持ってなかったっけ？
Sorry to change the subject but didn’t you have some pale pink blush?

mnemonics.meaning: A group of folding fans, no matter how big it gets, is still a fan.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 団 is an exceptional reading. It's the same as 内's reading so you can think about how a group of folding fans to make a big fan is just a bunch of fans inside of fans. The reading for 扇 is also an exceptional reading. Imagine a walrus (わ) using the 内 fan.

sentences: 同じ模様の団扇だけど、私の物の方があなたのより少し小さくて軽いみたいね。
Our fans have the same design, but mine seems to be a little smaller and lighter than yours.

mnemonics.meaning: A flower podium is a podium of flowers, put up higher than the ground. This is a flower bed.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その花壇を見ると、いつも母を思い出します。
I always think of my mother when I see a flower bed.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is different from the one you learned with the kanji. Someone waves a folding fan at you, but it just blows hot air at you. "ohh gee" (おうぎ), you say. "Thanks for nothing."

sentences: あの、紫色の扇をもったご婦人は一体どなたですか。
Who on earth is the lady holding the violet folding fan?

mnemonics.meaning: The peoples who are vulgar aren't refined city folk. They're people with folk customs and ethnic customs.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼は、歴史民俗資料館の館長です。
He is the director of the Museum of History and Folklore.

mnemonics.meaning: A foundation of foundations is a foundation. It is the fundamentals.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 基礎の日本語であれば教えられないこともないですが。
I could teach Japanese if it was just the fundamentals of Japanese.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: A foundation is made of stone (いし). And it holds up an entire zoo A (ずえ) but none of Zoo B. Zoo B will fall apart when an earthquake hits.

sentences: ここにいる人は皆、総合格闘技の礎を築いた故人の死を悼んでいると思います。
I think everyone here is mourning over the deceased who laid the foundation of mixed martial art.
手塚治虫は日本文化の礎となった人物と考えていいと思います。
I think it is safe to say that Osamu Tezuka is a cornerstone of Japanese culture.
大変だ。お城の礎となる石が誰かに壊されてしまった。一刻も早く避難しないと城が崩れるぞ！
Oh, no. Someone broke the stone that forms the foundation of the castle. If we don't evacuate as quickly as possible, the castle will collapse!

mnemonics.meaning: A faint water is water that's not thick with salt. It's fresh water.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 金魚は淡水魚だから、水槽に塩を入れてはいけませんよ。
Goldfish are freshwater fish so you shouldn’t put salt in the tank.

mnemonics.meaning: An approximation of thought is just thinking up the general idea. The concept or notion.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ほとんどの無神論者は、神や神々の概念に対して否定的です。
Most of the atheists have negative feelings regarding the concept of God or gods.

mnemonics.meaning: An old woman is who this is. Then, you add ちゃん for the name ender. You add お to be nicer. This person is a granny or grandma or old lady or old woman.
mnemonics.reading: The reading isn't the ば you learned with the kanji. It's a slightly longer ばあ, because you gotta be nice, you know? Also, the person you thought was a granny is actually a sheep. Baaaa! (ばあ).

sentences: お婆ちゃんに、嘘をついたことで責められた。
My grandma accused me of telling lies.

mnemonics.meaning: 恨む is "to hold a grudge." This is the noun version, which is a grudge or a resentment.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 恨む, so if you know that no need to hold a grudge.

sentences: アポを取ろうとしたんだけど、彼はどうやらうちの社長に何か恨みがあるみたいで、時間をくれなかったんだよね。
I asked for an appointment, but he wouldn’t give me the time of day because he apparently has a some kind of grudge against the president of our company.

mnemonics.meaning: 憎む is "to hate" - the adjective version is hateful.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 憎む as well, so if you know this no need to show any hate towards this vocab.

sentences: 候補者のコウイチ氏は、大統領候補討論会の前、憎らしいほど落ち着いていました。
Candidate Koichi was provokingly cool before the presidential debate.

mnemonics.meaning: If 憎む means "to hate" then this adjective version is hateful.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 憎む as well. Good times.

sentences: こんなに誰かのことを憎いと思ったのは生まれて初めてです。
I’ve never hated someone this much in my life.

mnemonics.meaning: If 憎む is "to hate" then the noun version would be hatred.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 憎む.

sentences: てっきり彼らはお互いに憎しみ合っているものだと思っていました。
I certainly thought they hated each other.

mnemonics.meaning: Inferiority is bad. It is inferiority, after all.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 劣悪な職場環境の会社は、日本ではしばしば「ブラック企業」と呼ばれます。
Companies with very rough work environments are often called "black companies" in Japan.

mnemonics.meaning: Inferiority is what I feel because I don't have an equal feeling with you. This is due to my inferiority complex, my sense of inferiority .
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その詐欺師は劣等感の塊だった。
That con artist was a mass of inferiority complexes.
人と自分を比べては、劣等感に苛まれてしまう。
I tend to compare myself with others and feel inferior to them.
彼女が私に対して劣等感を抱いていると誤解していました。
I was under the false impression that she had an inferiority complex towards me.

mnemonics.meaning: A big approximation is when I say something in general. I'm mainly and mostly telling everything.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 万引きをするのは大概、退屈で孤独を感じている女性だと言う人がいますが、ある調査が男性の方が女性よりも万引きをすることが多い可能性を示唆しているそうですよ。
Some people think shoplifters are mainly bored, lonely women, but I heard that a study suggested that more men shoplift than women.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Also could mean perception or hunch.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the one you learned from the kanji.

sentences: 成功の秘訣は、鋭い勘をもつことです。
Having sharp intuition is the key to success.

mnemonics.meaning: Isolate and detached from everything else. This thing (or person) is in isolation and quarantine.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼は二日酔いであまりにも酒臭すぎるので、別の部屋に隔離しています。
We have quarantined him to a separate room because he is hungover and reeks of liquor.

mnemonics.meaning: Pluck lucky ticket out to choose the winner of the lottery / raffle! Today I pluck... number 23! We've chosen a winner!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私はあの病院の抽選で、胃のバイパス手術が当たったんです。
I won a gastric bypass surgery from that hospital’s raffle.

mnemonics.meaning: Cover your face. Not with your hands or a puppy, but with a mask! Okay, I guess you could cover it with a puppy mask, but that's all you.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 覆面のスーパーマンは、ボッロボロのマントを身につけていました。
The masked superman was wearing such a tattered cloak.

mnemonics.meaning: The solely things theory is the theory that only things are important. This is also known as materialism.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 母国語でも唯物論について説明できないのに、どうして外国語で説明できるというのか。
I can’t even explain materialism in my native language, so how can I explain it in a foreign language?

mnemonics.meaning: An intuition difference is a misunderstanding or wrong guess. Sorry! My intuition was off.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 「すみません、間違えました。違う人と 勘違いしました。」「正確には誰と間違えたんですか？お願いします。教えてください。」
"Excuse me, my mistake. I thought you were someone else." "Exactly who did you mistake me for? Please. Tell me."

mnemonics.meaning: Let's take the grass and prune it. This is called mowing.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is 草 and 刈 put together into one. The か reading for 刈り comes from the kanji's reading.

sentences: 昨日は俺が悪かったよ。本当にごめん。お詫びの印に、今日は草刈りをするよ。
I am really sorry for being a jerk yesterday. I’ll mow the grass today to apologize.

mnemonics.meaning: A mulberry field is a mulberry field or mulberry plantation. This is more like a commercial / organized mulberry growing operation, so not some random field of mulberries.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 桑 (kanji reading) and the vocab word 畑. Watch out for the rendaku.

sentences: 私の地元には、桑畑があちこちにあります。
Mulberry fields are everywhere in my hometown.

mnemonics.meaning: A mulberry field is a mulberry field.
mnemonics.reading: These are both the kun'yomi readings, but you haven't learned this for 原 yet. It's actually the rendaku'd version, so let's just use mnemonic to remember it instead: You know you're in a mulberry field when you see a bunch of capybaras (ばら) rolling around in there with you. Capybaras love mulberries! Picture a whole family of capybaras munching on mulberries. Mm Mmm!

sentences: かつては桑畑がたくさんあったため、この場所は「桑原」と呼ばれるようになりました。
People started calling this place "Kuwabara" because there used to be a lot of mulberry fields here.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji means mulberry, but this refers to a mulberry tree.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 桑の実と林檎と胡桃の組み合わせが最強に美味しいんだよね。
Mulberries, apples, and walnuts taste best when they’re combined.

mnemonics.meaning: A random boil isn't all that random. It's specifically the new year's dish or mochi soup, eaten on new years. Old people and children tend to die every year from this (choking on the mochi), so be  careful if you eat it! Maybe the reason it's called "random boil" is because someone decided to boil a bunch of random things (like mochi) and then it became a new years dish later on. Who knows. That information isn't even known by the ancients.
mnemonics.reading: You learned the reading for 煮 on the kanji page, but the reading for 雑 is an exceptional one. You did learn this reading with 雑巾, though. Just imagine yourself with a dust cloth in your new year's dish.

sentences: お雑煮そろそろ煮えたんじゃないかな。
The New Year’s mochi soup should be ready by now.

mnemonics.meaning: A nun priest is a nun or priestess.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その尼僧は、寝起きはいつも顔がむくんでいます。
That nun’s face is always swollen when she wakes up.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Are you a nun? I am a (あま) nun.

sentences: 彼女は尼さんなのにお酒をたくさん飲みます。
Even though she’s a nun, she’s a heavy drinker.

mnemonics.meaning: It's solely one. The only one. The sole one. Totally unique.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 唯 is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, though there is also a shortened version which has ゆい shortened to ゆ. The reading for 一 is one you haven't learned yet, wow! You're finally going to learn the second, rare on'yomi reading for 一! It wants to be the only reading now, so it eats (いつ) the other one. Oh no, you can't remember that other reading now. いつ is the sole 一 reading in your brain!

sentences: あいつは奴の家族の中で唯一まともな人間だよ。
He is the only decent person in his family.

mnemonics.meaning: An approximation of what we need is my outline / summary.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 青年海外協力隊についての概要は、こちらのページでお読み頂けます。
You can read an outline of the Japanese Peace Corps on this page.

mnemonics.meaning: Fear mixed with confusion creates panic! You get a scare so bad, you're fearful and you don't know what to do.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!

sentences: 私が留守だった日、村は恐慌に包まれた。
The village was consumed with panic on the day I wasn't there.
人生で二度もの経済恐慌を経験するとは思っていなかったよ。
I wasn't expecting to experience two economic scares in my lifetime.
国全体が恐慌状態に陥った。
The entire country flew into a panic.

mnemonics.meaning: Intuition from my dialect tells me that I should pardon you. Give you forgiveness. You're lucky I speak this dialect.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 勘弁してちゃぶ台。今日は忙しかったし、滅茶苦茶疲れているんだ。
Cut me some slack. It’s been a long day and I’m terribly tired.

mnemonics.meaning: A reality pearl is a real pearl! That's just a pearl.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

sentences: 真珠を身につける人は減ってきています。
Less and less people are wearing pearls.

mnemonics.meaning: Immersed to the point where it's transparent, because it's so soaked... that is total permeation and soaking and osmosis.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: こちらの化粧水は、お肌の奥深くまで浸透するということで、すごく人気が出てきています。
This face lotion is getting really popular because it deeply permeates into the skin.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 壇上で、小さな可愛いフラワーガールの女の子が、しばらく花嫁の人気をさらいました。
The cute little flower girl upstaged the bride on the podium for a moment.

mnemonics.meaning: A pottery container is pottery. It's ceramics.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: もう使わないんだったら、白い陶器は全部誰かにあげちゃえば？
Why don’t you give away all these white ceramics if you don’t use them anymore?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: フグは、わざとサーモン妃にぶつかりました。
Fugu bumped into Princess Salmon on purpose.

mnemonics.meaning: The profits that I'm watered with are pouring all over me. That's my profit and returns.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 日本には資源超過利潤税は無かったと思うよ。
I don’t think there is a Resources Super Profits Tax in Japan.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is different from the one you learned with the kanji. To remember this reading, think about how the previous village you went to was all purple. It was the "村先" (むらさき) that you went to. Everything. Absolutely everything was purple.

sentences: 暗闇の中でキラキラ光る紫色の光を見た瞬間、「母だ」と思ったんです。
The instant I saw purple light shining through the darkness, I thought, "Mom."

mnemonics.meaning: The king of princesses is the greatest and highest ranking princess of them all.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私は王妃と友情を育んだ。
I cultivated my friendship with the queen.

mnemonics.meaning: The conspiring I'm doing? Nothing... that's how much. If I don't conspire, I don't think about my actions. If I don't think, then I am just being reckless and thoughtless.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私の娘を止めてもらえませんか。無謀にもスパイ活動をしようとしているんです。
Could you stop my daughter? She is recklessly engaging herself in espionage.

mnemonics.meaning: Open up cultivation back on this land. It was closed before, due to it being a wasteland, but now it's time for reclamation and cultivation of this land.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 畑は違えど、新規市場を開拓するという点においては、前職とさほど変わりはないよ。
Although it’s a completely different field, there isn’t much of a difference in terms of cultivating a new market.

mnemonics.meaning: I'd like to infer and encourage this item to you. It is my recommendation. It is my endorsement.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: このカボチャのパイは、焼き上がりでも美味しく召し上がって頂けるのですが、私たちは御賞味の前に少し冷蔵庫に入れて頂くことを推奨しています。
This pumpkin pie is delicious right after it’s been baked, but we recommend refrigerating for a short time before eating it.

mnemonics.meaning: The red light district (花柳) world of the red light district is the red light district, though this can refer especially to the "pleasure quarters" or "world of the geisha" as well.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 花柳界を経験してみるのが夢だったんだ。
I’ve always dreamed of experiencing the red-light district.

mnemonics.meaning: I've memorized this to the point of comprehension. It was my resolution to learn all this to comprehension. This way I have readiness.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私は痩身手術を受ける覚悟を決めました。
I resigned myself to undergo weight loss surgery.

mnemonics.meaning: If 憩う is to rest, then this noun version (I know it looks like an adjective, but it's not) would be rest.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 憩う, so if you know that you can rest easy.

sentences: 私はうちの食堂を忙しいサラリーマンの憩いの場にしたいんです。
I want to make my restaurant a place of rest and relaxation for busy salarymen.

mnemonics.meaning: A rest (休憩) place is a rest area or rest stop.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

sentences: 逮捕された男は、休憩所に不法侵入した疑いがかけられていた。
The man they arrested is suspected of breaking into the rest area.

mnemonics.meaning: A number of pearls, put together on a string. This refers to a rosary or prayer beads. You'll see these a lot in Japan, for sale or with monks wearing them.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this word is different from both of the kanji readings you learned. This word sounds a lot like Jews (じゅず), so we'll have to go with that. Just imagine a Jewish rosary or prayer beads, with a Jewish person using it.

sentences: 高額な数珠を私に売りつけようとした男の名前が思い出せません。
I can’t remember the name of the guy who tried to force me to buy an expensive rosary.

mnemonics.meaning: Encourage study money is money that you give to a kid to encourage him to study. That comes in the form of a scholarship or stipend.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その占い師に、私は奨学金をもらえるだろうって予言されたんだけど、当たったよ。
The fortuneteller predicted that I would receive the scholarship and she was right.

mnemonics.meaning: An elderly person in decline is someone who is old and in decline. They are experiencing senility or senile decay.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 母親が老衰で亡くなったとき、妻が「厄介者がいなくなってせいせいした」と独り言を言っているのを私は聞き漏らしませんでした。
When my mother died from old age, I didn’t fail to hear my wife mutter, "that parasite is gone, good riddance," to herself.

mnemonics.meaning: Things that are vulgar are things like slang, local manners, and just plain common stuff.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 貧乏から金持ちに成り上がった人は、俗に成金と呼ばれます。
People who went from rags to riches are commonly called nouveau riche.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji means solely, and this means solely, but also other related things like only or merely. They're all pretty close, so try to remember a few!
mnemonics.reading: To spice up something you'd describe with words like only and simply use Ta da! (ただ) to spice it up. It's like magic! Now it isn't just a gift, it's a TA DA surprise gift.

sentences: 彼女は私の母ではなく唯の付き添い人です。
She is not my mother, she’s just a chaperone.

mnemonics.meaning: I'd like to isolate this interval of time. Take it, make it separate, and then look at it. Now there is a space there. An interval, if you will.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 生理痛程度の陣痛が15分から20分ぐらいの間隔で始まって、今行った方がいいのか病院に電話をしました。
Mild contractions are starting in 15 to 20 minutes intervals and I called the hospital to see if we should go now.

mnemonics.meaning: I will divide the intuition up. For some reason when I say "intuition" I mean "money" because this is referring to splitting the cost, like when you're at a restaurant.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is 割る and 勘, put together.

sentences: 私は下戸でお酒を飲まないので、お酒のお勘定は割り勘じゃない方が嬉しいんですが。
I can’t drink because I get drunk easily, so it would be nice if we didn’t split the alcohol bill.

mnemonics.meaning: If 粘る is "to be sticky" then the noun version is stickiness.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 粘る.

sentences: 一生懸命粘り強く努力すればいつかは報われると思っていましたが、それは間違いでした。
I believed hard work and persistent efforts would pay off some day, but it was wrong.

mnemonics.meaning: A spirit of approximation is the approximation of spirit. My approximation of your spirit? I think you have a strong spirit. I think you have backbone.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その教師は、教室で見て見ぬふりをされている問題に取り組む気概がなかった。
The teacher didn’t have the guts to deal with the problems in the classroom.

mnemonics.meaning: Immersed in water. That sounds like submersion. Possibly like a flood, even.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 気温が上がるのは素晴らしいことだけど、私達は雪解け水による浸水を心配しています。
It’s great that the temperature is rising, but we’re worried about a flood from the melting snow.

mnemonics.meaning: You know that 詐欺 is "fraud." An expert in fraud is someone who does this it lot, and possibly for a living. That's a swindler, a con artist,  or a scammer.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the reading of 詐欺 as well.

sentences: 派手にお金を使っているなぁと思っていたら、詐欺師だったんですね！
I thought you are a big spender, and you turned out to be a con artist.
不動産詐欺師というものが結構いるらしい。
I heard that there are quite a few real estate scammers out there.
「ねぇ、今俺のこと、嘘つきって言った？」「そうは言ってないけど、詐欺師とは言ったよ。」
"Hey, did you just call me a liar?" "No, but I called you a swindler."

mnemonics.meaning: Using our intuition we will come up with a plan. We'll be taking into consideration the information we have along with our intuition, so don't worry.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 様々な状況を勘案すると、私にとって仕事を辞めることがベストな選択だったんです。
Taking various circumstances into consideration, quitting the job was the best option for me.
自分がされたり言われたりしたらどう思うかってことも勘案に入れるようにしてます。
I try to take into consideration how I would feel if things were said or done to me.
この投資に関して、どのようなリスクを勘案していますか。
What kinds of risks have you taken into consideration concerning this investment?

mnemonics.meaning: You are a 疲れ (tired) 様 (honorific that kind of refers to whoever's being mentioned with this word). You say this to people after a day of hard work or after a good practice, etc. お疲れ様でした! I suppose the assumption here is that everyone worked until they were tired, so it was a good work, and then you thank them for it and mention how tired everyone is.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 疲れ and 様, combined together into one word.

sentences: 私の妻は私の背広をハンガーに掛る時に、「今日も一日お仕事お疲れ様でした」といつも言ってくれるんです。
When my wife puts my jacket on the hanger she always says, "Thank you for working hard again today."

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. This is an intransitive verb, so it means to be cooked, to be boiled, or to be done cooking. Also a little cultural note — this word is used for both rice, and other foods in western Japan, while it's only used for rice in eastern Japan.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 炊く.

sentences: ご飯、炊けた？
Is the rice done cooking?
今晩はカレーライスじゃなくてカレースパゲッティ。コンセントを差し忘れて、ご飯が炊けてなかったんだ。
Today's dinner is curry spaghetti, not curry rice. I forgot to put the plug in, so the rice isn't cooked.
大根が炊けるまであと五分やで。
It's only five minutes left until the daikon gets cooked.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means inferiority and the verb vocab version is to be inferior to.
mnemonics.reading: When thinking about cars, an automatic (おと) car is inferior to a manual car. Sure, manual is harder, but way more interesting to drive.

sentences: 今、彼は私のこと嫌っているから、私の立場は挨拶程度の人よりも劣っているってのははっきりしてるわ。
