He hates me now, so I’m pretty sure that I'm even more inferior to him than a nodding acquaintance.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means watered. When something is watered, it is moist and damp. That's why this verb is to be moist or to be damp or to be watered.
mnemonics.reading: If you get moist and damp, then you're all (うるお) wet. It's just how it is.

sentences: このローションを使えば、あなたのお肌はプルプルに潤いますよ。
If you use this lotion it will moisturize your skin so that it’s firm and soft.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means capsize but the verb version is what happens when a plan or idea capsizes. It going to be overturned. It was a bad idea, go back, don't do it or we'll all sink!
mnemonics.reading: Of all the ideas that need to be overturned, it's the ones from the 靴 guy (くつがえ). He thinks we should only wear shoes. Not shoes and nothing else, but shoes all over out entire bodies. Yikes, now that's an idea I'd like to be retracted, 靴 guy.

sentences: スポーツはずっとそんなに好きではなかったんですが、一度野球の試合を見に行った時にそれが覆りまして、今ではマリナーズの大ファンです。
I didn’t always like sports, but that was overturned once I went to see a baseball game and now I’m a big fan of the Mariners.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. This is an intransitive verb, so this verb means to be smashed, to be shattered, or to break (for things like waves and tension!).
mnemonics.reading: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 砕く.

sentences: 急に窓ガラスが粉々に砕けた。
Suddenly, the window shattered into tiny pieces.
海辺に座って、波が砕けるのを見るのが好きです。
I like sitting on the beach and watching the waves break on the shore..
緊張した雰囲気がやっと砕けたと思ったんだけど、パーティはすぐに終わっちゃったんだ。
When I felt like the tension in the air finally broke, the party was almost over.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means immersed. Things that are immersed are described by verbs like to be soaked in or to be submerged or to be flooded.
mnemonics.reading: What is soaked and submerged in water (that shouldn't be)? It is your heater (ひた). It's all soaked and doesn't work anymore :(

sentences: お風呂で図書館から借りたホーソンの『巌の顔』を読んでいたんですが、うっかりお湯に浸ってしまったんです。
I was reading Hawthorne’s "The Great Stone Face" that I borrowed from a library in the bath and thoughtlessly soaked it in bathwater.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.  The kanji itself means boil and the verb vocab version is to boil something. This is a transitive verb, so it's used when you put something into a pot and boil it up.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 今日は、この脂ののった秋鮭を煮てみたいと思います。
We are going to simmer this fatty autumn salmon today.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means conspire and the verb vocab version is to conspire or to plot.
mnemonics.reading: A group of hackers (はか) are getting together and trying to conspire and plot to take down the mainframe! Those hackers!

sentences: あいつらはフィレンツェのダビデ像の前でのドラマチックな暗殺を謀っているんだ。
They’re plotting a dramatic assassination in front of the Statue of David in Florence.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means decline and the verb vocab version is to decline.
mnemonics.reading: You're wandering through the jungle exploring, when you come upon a deep pit. Since you're looking for treasure, you decide to go down into the pit to look for some. You take out your handy auto rope (おとろ), made of organic, environment friendly materials, and easily rappel down into the pit. Unfortunately, you get lost down there, and it takes you fifty years to get back to the pit you came in from. But your auto rope is gone! This is the last time you buy an organic rope, made to decay and to wither away when left in the wild.

sentences: 数年前にこの牛肉を食べた時は、非常に良く熟成されて霜が降っていることに感動したんですが、今はちょっと味が衰えたみたいでとても残念ですね。
When I had this beef several years ago I was really impressed by how well it was aged and marbled, but the taste seems to have declined a bit and I’m really disappointed.

mnemonics.meaning: 挿入 is "insertion" so the verb version is to insert.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 挿入, so if you know that you can insert this reading into your memory no problem.

sentences: DVDはここから挿入できるよ。
You can insert the DVD from here.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means isolate and the verb vocab version is to isolate or to partition or to separate. You get the idea, anyways.
mnemonics.reading: Why did you have to isolate him from the rest of the soccer players? Because all he could do was headers (へだ) and that was getting pretty dangerous. He would head everything in his reach. He was going crazy with headers. He had to be isolated!

sentences: 私のアパートでは、浴槽と洗面所はシャワーカーテン一枚で隔てられています。
In my apartment, the bathtub and the washroom are separated by a single shower curtain.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means kick so the verb version is to kick.
mnemonics.reading: This vocabulary word uses the same reading you learned with the kanji, plus the hiragana attached at the end.

sentences: どっちの足で蹴ったの？
Which leg did you kick with?
どうしてそのオファーを蹴っちゃったの？
Why did you reject the offer?
妖怪が妖精を蹴ったのを見ました。
I saw a yokai kick a fairy.

mnemonics.meaning: Giving one kick is certainly an effective (if brutal) way to flatly reject or to brush aside something or someone. That one kick can also be used to easily beat anyone.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji.  First up, notice that いち changes to いっ. And since you haven't learned the on'yomi for the kanji 蹴 (kick) yet, here's a mnemonic to help you: When you're planning to flatly reject someone, one kick is all you need. Before you do that, be absolutely sure to put your shoe (しゅう) on first.

sentences: コウイチに告白したが一蹴された。
I confessed my love to Koichi, but he totally rejected me.
ビエトは妖怪を一蹴した。
Viet beat the yokai easily.
上司に休暇を申請したが一蹴された。
I submitted a holiday request to my boss but it was flatly rejected.

mnemonics.meaning: If you prune and take from what you pruned, you're going to mow or to reap or to harvest whatever it is you're pruning.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the reading you learned with 刈 and the reading from the vocab 取る.

sentences: 私の実家は農家で米を育てているので、今週末は稲の刈り取りを手伝わなきゃいけないんです。
My parents are farmers who raise rice so I have to help them harvest rice this weekend.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means confused or bewildered but this is usually just used when someone starts to panic. They're so confused and bewildered that they try to hurry through things.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Whenever you start to panic you can't help but blurt out, "A wha- (あわ)?" to everything people say and ask. For example, "Would you like a mint?" "A WHA?!" Yeah, you really do sound upset.

sentences: 慌てないで、安全運転をお願いします。
Please don't rush—just drive safely.
火事だと思い、慌てて水をかけたら、ただのロウソクだった。
I panicked, thinking there was a fire, and threw some water, but it was just a candle.
慌てず、慎重にね。
Don't hurry, do it carefully.

mnemonics.meaning: If something is pathetic then you should try to pity that thing.
mnemonics.reading: Awww (あわ), you're so pathetic it's cute! I will pity you. Reading also comes from 哀れ.

sentences: 彼女のお婆さんが、「あの子の人見知りは哀れむべきものだ」とぼやくのを聞きました。
I heard her grandmother grumble, "That girl’s shyness should be pitied."

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means prune and the verb vocab version is to prune (or to mow or to cut).
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 草を刈り終わったから、放してやってよ。
I’ve finished mowing the grass, so turn him loose.

mnemonics.meaning: If you have comprehension, then you are probably going to realize something about something else. Comprehension leads to realization, after all.
mnemonics.reading: You realized something so amazing that you couldn't believe it. That comprehension, wow! The realization was so big that you sat (さと) down in disbelief. If you didn't you would have fallen on the ground.

sentences: 背中の曲がったお婆さんは、不法滞在者として拘置所に拘留された時、そこで自分が死を迎えることになることを悟りました。
When the hunchbacked old lady was sent to a detention center for being an illegal immigrant, she realized that it would be where she met her death.

mnemonics.meaning: The purple outside line is the color spectrum that's outside purple. Those are ultraviolet rays (the lines are the rays).
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あんたはまずその紫外線恐怖症を克服しなきゃいけないね。
You must first conquer your fear of the ultraviolet rays.

mnemonics.meaning: We're moving towards one approximation. It used to be more approximations, but now it's just one, and because it's just one it's not really an approximation anymore. It's unconditionally set. It's set as a rule.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 定額給付金は一概に良い事だとは言えない。
I can’t say that tax rebates are unconditionally good things.

mnemonics.meaning: When you are sturdy and healthy you are full of vigor and virility.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼は剛健な昔の武士のような見た目だが、彼の足にある血豆を誤って押してしまった時に、泣き叫んでいました。
He looks like a strong warrior of long ago, but he wailed when I accidentally pressed a blister on his foot.

mnemonics.meaning: A purple color is a violet color, mainly, for some reason, though I'll let "purple" slide as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 紫 is different from the one you learned with the kanji. To remember this reading, think about how the previous village you went to was all purple. It was the "村先" (むらさき) that you went to. Everything. Absolutely everything was purple.

sentences: 彼女はいつも制服の上に紫色のベストを着ている。
She always wears a violet colored vest over her school uniform.

mnemonics.meaning: This looks like an adjective, but it's actually a noun. This word is the same as the kanji meaning: vow (or oath).
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as 近い (ちかい). Just think about how when you're making a vow or oath, you become closer to the thing or person you're vowing to. You belong to them, in a way, which is why you become close (近い).

sentences: 結婚の誓いの言葉を述べている時、自分が間違った男の人と結婚しようとしていることは分かっていました。
When I was saying my wedding vows I knew I was marrying the wrong man.

mnemonics.meaning: A vow promise is the promise that you made with your vow. It's the oath you swear to keep!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: こちらが誓約書となっておりまして、こちらとこちらにサインをして頂く必要があります。
Here is the written pledge. You need to sign it here and here.

mnemonics.meaning: Your highness I am so below you because your majesty is so great and amazing!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 陛下、恐れ入りますが会議にご出席のご予定だったのでは。
Your Majesty, I’m sorry to impose but you were supposed to attend the meeting.

mnemonics.meaning: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means name.
Inside this guy's forehead you have a spoon and a bunch of hair, not to mention whatever that is in the top left. That's the mind of a psychopath right there.

Although a little bit modified, there is a turtle shell that's on a mustache with this radical. The only thing with a mustache that hangs around turtles is Splinter, the giant rat from Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles. So this radical is Splinter (the giant rat).

The leader, Master Splinter (the rat from Ninja Turtles) isn't even supposed to exist. He exists because someone accidentally poured ooze on him. Imagine someone accidentally spilling ooze on a rat, then watch the rat turn into a sentient rat martial artist.
mnemonics.reading: But really, if you do something accidentally, it's probably a good (ぐう) thing in a way. You learn a bit about how you can improve yourself so you don't do it again, or in Splinter's case, it's just a good mistake! However you look at it, try to make this accident be a good accident.

mnemonics.meaning: The construction beggar is one who begs for construction projects. He doesn't do it for money or fame, he begs for construction because he is so adept at what he does. The construction beggar looks like any other beggar, which makes it even stranger that he's so adept at what he does. He really puts everything into his construction work.
mnemonics.reading: "The most adept at construction in all the land is me," says the construction beggar to emperor こういち. The construction beggar is giving a presentation on why he would be the best choice for making a grand new palace for Emperor こういち. Point number one: he is the most adept at construction. Hint: When you see 工 in a kanji it will often take the こう reading.

mnemonics.meaning: A fish in its mouth and in the other mouth is half a beggar (the head is cut off). The other half is on the ground. The animal that has fishes and beggars in its mouth, is an alligator. Just imagine the blood  and fishes and beggars everywhere. The alligator is having a good meal tonight.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the わに in "Wanikani." Ever heard of it? So long as you've ever used WaniKani, you probably know the reading of the word alligator.

mnemonics.meaning: Put your fingers on the bed, grasp the sheets and bundle them up. Now you can do the laundry! Imagine pressing your fingers into the bed, grasping tightly and ripping the sheets free. Then you bundle them up into your arms so you can stuff them into the washing machine.
mnemonics.reading: In between grasping and bundle-ing, you shout HA (は)! That's when the sheets come off the bed. The next time you grasp your bedsheets yell "Ha!" as you yank them off. Now chuckle a bit, ha ha ha, as you bundle them up into a ball. You can't beat me, bedsheets.

mnemonics.meaning: A horse that is fat is a burdensome animal. A fat horse. So burdensome. Not to mention the burden on the horse on top of the fatness.
mnemonics.reading: But you have to be nice to the burdensome horse because this horse is your dad (だ). Go visit your dad the burdensome horse because you have to visit your dad. It's weird because you're a human and he's a horse.

mnemonics.meaning: A tsunami is the same as a cave. Because, if a wave is big enough, it will curl over on itself, creating a sort of cave within the wave. That's why it's the same as a cave! Also, imagine a tsunami hitting a cave, becoming the same as the cave (since a cave will shape it).
mnemonics.reading: Best way to remember the reading for this kanji is to think about how the shape of a cave is the shape of a doughnut (どう). Also note that the 同 part of this kanji gives away the reading as well. 同 and 洞 have the same readings!

mnemonics.meaning: The leader all in white is the chief. All the other leaders are wearing some other color, but that's how you tell the chief apart from the other leaders. Imagine all the leaders standing around, then the chief person standing there all in white.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as 白, which is included in this kanji. The other reading is お, and it's like the honorific 御, in a way. You'd want to be polite to someone who is the chief ______, right? That's why it could be お, too. You'll learn more about which reading to use when the vocabulary roll around. In the meantime, try to remember both of them the best you can!

mnemonics.meaning: Under a canopy, someone thinking with a brush in their mouth has a sudden thought, and uses the brush to write the word "China". Thus, China was born. All of a sudden China existed! Pretty crazy, right?
mnemonics.reading: Believe it or not, this sudden invention of China happened in とうきょう. Well, it wasn't とうきょう yet. And it was a traveling Chinese person who did it. But you know legends, they're just all over the place. Oh my gosh, can you imagine how mad China will be when you tell them they were invented in とうきょう? Maybe you shouldn't tell anyone this story. Just keep it between you and me, kay?

mnemonics.meaning: You want to write a chapter about hair in your new book so you have to make sure it's really clear. Clear enough so that ANYbody can read it. Your writing is so clear and concise that just about everyone does read it. Well, everyone with hair that is.
mnemonics.reading: Your clear writing got the attention of the Shougun (しょう) and now he's at your door once again. Although, this time he's angrier than usual. His hair also looks awful. He took your advice after reading the book and cut his entire ponytail off. Picture the Shougun angrily yelling at you about his hair disaster! The only good thing he can say about your book is that it gave clear directions.

mnemonics.meaning: Watch what you say to the next mouth over, because they hired you to consult them. The person with the next mouth in the room is waiting for you to open yours to consult them. He'll do whatever you say.
mnemonics.reading: You panic, and consult the man into buying a sheep (し). He was asking for love advice, so I guess you consulted that he give a sheep to the person he likes? Uh oh. Remind me never to consult with you when I'm feeling unsure about things.

mnemonics.meaning: The Yoga King presides over all courts: law, imperial, and so forth. In this case, you've met him in the court of law, where he is judge, jury, and executioner. Picture him sitting above you in the judge's chair in court. He's about to make his judgement.
mnemonics.reading: The court of the Yoga King is against you. You have to turn this around, so you start pushing tater (てい) tots into his tater-tot-hole shaped mouth. "I hereby sentence you to..." *ploop* "Ooh, this is really good. I hereby sentence..." *ploop* "Wow, are these tater tots? Court dismissed."

mnemonics.meaning: This is an animal with an angled sword claw that's filled with cow meat but looks like an insect. What kind of animal is that? It's a crab. If you think about the different parts you can see why this is a crab. A delicious, delicious crab.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the かに in WaniKani. If you've used WaniKani before, you probably know this reading, hopefully. All praise the great allicrab!

mnemonics.meaning: The sun hits this and breaks into three suns. What can split the sun in three directions? A crystal! Crystals take light and refract it around into many directions. That's why there are three suns in this kanji.
mnemonics.reading: Who is hoarding and harnessing the power of these crystals? That would be the Shougun (しょう). Imagine the Shougun laying in his bed of crystals. He still has his really serious, angry face though. Even as he rubs the crystals to his face, he's glowering.

mnemonics.meaning: A woman is making a dirt cage in the sun. She's using it to trap water, making this a dirt dam. If you think about it, dams are just dirt cages anyway. Picture the woman working tirelessly in the hot sun, moving and shaping the dirt around this river into a dam to make a pond.
mnemonics.reading: Something about the woman working hard to build this dam makes her super sexy (せき) to you. Maybe it's because the sun is so bright, making her shine, or maybe it's because hard work is attractive. Who knows. If you wanna be sexy maybe you should build a dam too.

mnemonics.meaning: If a tsunami hits your helicopter while you are jackhammering, it will drift out to sea. What were you doing with a jackhammer at a time like this? Now your helicopter is drifting away! Picture your helicopter as it drifts out to sea with the tsunami.
mnemonics.reading: As it drifts away you shout, "Heyooo! (ひょう)." You know the helicopter probably can't hear you (or understand you) but maybe it will turn on and stop drifting away if you shout it enough. "Heyoooo stop drifting awaaaay!!"

mnemonics.meaning: A tsunami hits a roof and then corrects itself. This causes it to swirl around, creating an eddy. An eddy requires water to change direction and then twirl around, and when the tsunami hits the roof, that's exactly what it does.
mnemonics.reading: There is a person trying to create an eddy with a tsunami, and when their roof correction device is shown to be effective, they sing: "This is how you do (よど) it." Imagine them singing this, emphasizing the "you do" part of the song as they watch the eddy being formed.

mnemonics.meaning: The correct way to block the sun with dirt is with an embankment. Build a huge, sloping embankment correctly and the sun won't be able to bother you ever again! Imagine an embankment made of dirt, in the correct place, blocking the sun from your eyes.
mnemonics.reading: Unfortunately, building a correct embankment doesn't just take dirt, but tater (てい) tots too. You pile up the dirt and the tater tots so the embankment can be nice and high. Picture an embankment made of dirt and tater tots. Not like, tater tots just thrown in the embankment, you probably see those all the time. But dirt AND tater tots in the embankment itself.

mnemonics.meaning: You walk out on a cliff, where you find in the ground a mouth poking out. It speaks: "It is me, the empress of these lands!" She was buried in the cliff down to her mouth so nobody would find her! You pull her out of the ground and soon what was just a mouth becomes a whole empress!
mnemonics.reading: When you finish unburying the empress, the first thing she says to you is: "Please, you must hurry and take me to Emperor こういち." It's only natural the empress would want to see her emperor. And right now, the emperor of these lands is Emperor こういち.

mnemonics.meaning: Turn a sickness into a weapon and it becomes an epidemic. This sickness spreads to everyone and it's all your fault because you put it in the water supply. Imagine if countries decided to make sick weapons that would spread epidemics like this all over part of the world. Let's hope they don't...
mnemonics.reading: These epidemics spread by 駅 (えき). Each train takes the sickness and shoots off in a different direction, spreading it further. Picture a single 駅 on a map, bright red. Now watch the red spread to all of the other 駅 on the map, dyeing them red and spreading the epidemic all over your country.

mnemonics.meaning: You have a numbered feather. Pick your favorite number and put it on the feather. Then, put the numbered feather on your head. When you put it on, you're able to flip and flip over and over. Imagine yourself doing flips with this feather on your head. Flip flip flip.
mnemonics.reading: You're pretty good at your flip technique, but you're not that good. You really need to practice and hone (ほん) your skills and get better. Or, maybe you get so good that you write a 本 (ほん) about doing a flip. Wow, you're good!

mnemonics.meaning: A tree can be a tree, but it can also be a psychopath. The tree goes from being a regular tree to being a psychopath. Such mood swings are so rough. Especially when the tree slips to gloom. Imagine all the mood swings of this tree. Psychopath tree! Also very gloomy sometimes.
mnemonics.reading: Then the tree switches from gloom to being super excited (these moodswings!). The super excited tree starts doing dubstep. Uts (うつ) uts uts uts uts ♬. Sing along with the moody tree. Gloom to dubstep. Such a big change.

mnemonics.meaning: There is a tsunami coming up over a cliff made of dirt. You can see this happening very far away because it's right on the horizon. Picture the tsunami breaking over the cliff on the horizon. It would be beautiful if it wasn't so frightening.
mnemonics.reading: You squint into the horizon and see something else. There's some guy (がい) up there. And he's... he's being swept away by the tsunami. The guy disappears into the horizon. The guy is gone. You wonder who that guy was. You wonder why he was there. You wonder if he's still alive out there, past the horizon.

mnemonics.meaning: A gold name on this piece of wood is the inscription that shows the artist's signature. This inscription refers to a signature or something similar. This is an artisan's signature in the form of an inscription.
mnemonics.reading: The inscription is a name written on something, right? Remember the kanji for "name"? It is 名, and it shares the reading with this kanji as well, making both names めい. If you need to review 名 go ahead and do that. It will help you to remember this kanji.

mnemonics.meaning: The leader cat pirate is the greatest cat pirate of them all. It leads all the cat pirate leaders, even! This is truly a cat pirate to look up to. Imagine this majestic cat pirate leader of leaders. Feel in your heart that you look up to this cat pirate, truly.
mnemonics.reading: Your job is to bring this leader of cat pirates (whom you look up to) its favorite food: gyoza (ぎょう).  Of course, the gyoza is filled with fish, because we're talking about cat pirates, here.

mnemonics.meaning: A tsunami crashes into the sun, which is then caught in a net tied to a stool! Wait a second... this doesn't sound realistic, this is from that pirate manga you're always reading! Imagine reading this issue of your favorite stretchy pirate boy manga, Lumpy uses his arms as a net, his legs tied to a stool, and traps the sun in a net right as the tsunami hits. Gee what kind of crazy trouble is he getting into this time?!
mnemonics.reading: Manga starts with man (まん)! You already know all about manga and now you can read them too. Look how far you've come. Wow, what a journey. And you're almost at the end. Gosh, I'm just so proud of you, kiddo.

mnemonics.meaning: A bamboo tsunami's specialty is to crush everything in front of it, smash down, and turn into multiple record books.  The bamboo flattens as it hits the ground then turns into papers. The papers combine to become record books that show what happened here, this day.
mnemonics.reading: A record book is a book (ぼ), when it comes down to it. Bamboo can also become bo staffs too, if they don't turn into record books.

mnemonics.meaning: The restaurant radical and the restaurant kanji are the same! The meaning of this kanji also extends other resting places, like an inn or a pavilion. Know your radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: This restaurant only serves tater (てい) tots. Really, would you ever want to go to a restaurant that didn't have tater tots? No. Imagine going to a restaurant and seeing a menu of all different types and styles of tater tots and nothing else. Even the drinks are tater tot based. Mmm mm.

mnemonics.meaning: What you say on the street needs to be revised. Your words need to be polished, you can't publish improv. Revise your street word inspiration before you share it again. Think about all the stupid things you said on the streets today. Do you want those exact phrases, mistakes, and mouth sounds following you around forever? Revise it before you write it down!
mnemonics.reading: You want to revise the song you wrote about tater (てい) tots at lunch today. But it needs a lot of revising. "Tater tots, tater tots, tater tots, man. Bake me a tater tot as fast as you banana." Well that's bad. Better revise this so it rhymes. "Tater tots, tater tots, tater tots, man. Bake me a tater tot as fast as you want." Nope, still bad. Revise! "Tater tots, tater tots, tater tots, man. Bake me a tater tot as fast as you clam." Yes. It's gold.

mnemonics.meaning: A samurai who can fight with icicles on him is more robust than regular samurai. Can you imagine how robust you'd have to be to fight in weather cold enough to form icicles on your body? Picture samurai standing in a line. One, two, three... woah. You look up. This guy has icicles growing off him and he's the size of a bus. Now that's a robust samurai.
mnemonics.reading: You may think it's just his robust body, but it's actually the samurai's robust soul (そう) that keeps him fighting through the cold and the icicles. Physical robustness is just a reflection of the strength of your soul!

mnemonics.meaning: There are nine cars all driving in the same place. With so many cars driving in the same place, they create a rut. Imagine the cars spinning out in the rut. Spin spin spin. The rut gets bigger. Nine is too many cars.
mnemonics.reading: To get out of the rut you have to put in a second key (き) that turns on the thrusters. You put in the key and press the "take off" button. Imagine turning the thrusters key, then feeling the car lift off the ground. You'll finally get out of this rut!

mnemonics.meaning: A big turkey in the rice paddy is getting all stirred up. He's kicking up all the rice. Who stirred him up? He is a really big turkey too. Like, 12 feet tall, or something. Don't want to stir up a turkey that's that big.
mnemonics.reading: While the turkey is stirred up, it also looks like it's having a lot of fun (ふん).  Is it laughing? Oh no, this is bad, it's enjoying being stirred up, now we'll never stop it.

mnemonics.meaning: At the top of the mountain is a signpost to tell you you've reached the summit. Literally every mountain that humans have reached the top of has one of these summit signs. If that signpost wasn't there how would you know you reached the summit? Like, if you were on top of Everest and there was a bad storm... you'd just topple off the other side. Those summit signposts are important!
mnemonics.reading: At the summit, you decide to build your new home (ほう). It's been destroyed so many times, and you're sick of it. Maybe if you build you home at the summit of this mountain it will be safer. Picture your beautiful summit home. You know, George Washington had one of these too. So. That's cool, I guess.

mnemonics.meaning: There's a cross in the dirt and the dirt is surrounded by flowers and shells from shellfish. This is a tomb. The flowers and shellfish were put here as decorations and to honor the dead that currently lay under the dirt. And the cross marks the tomb, obviously. Can you picture this big dirt tomb, with flowers and shellfish decorating it and a cross right on top?
mnemonics.reading: This may be a tomb, but it feels really fun (ふん). It is decorated, after all. This tomb isn't a sad place, it's a fun place to remember the people you loved. The next time you see a tomb think about how much fun that person had while they were alive. This tomb is motivating you to try and have as much fun as you can while you can!

mnemonics.meaning: With your fingers you put some weapons in a boat for transport. This is a transport boat and its your job to get these weapons from one place to another. Imagine loading a bunch of weapons into a boat and sailing off to transport them somewhere else.
mnemonics.reading: Hey! You're transporting weapons just like Han (はん) Solo! I mean, it was a spaceship, not technically a boat, but he definitely used the Millennium Falcon as a transport. Picture yourself as a cool smuggler, transporting stolen... I mean... totally legitimate weapons from one place to another. Just like Han Solo!

mnemonics.meaning: A fang on a building shows that it's wicked. Something wicked probably lives in the building too. Not like, wicked cool, but like wicked evil. I see you, New Englanders.
mnemonics.reading: You peek inside the wicked building and a wicked jaguar (じゃ) suddenly pounces at you! You let out a sigh of relief when it's stopped by the window, but then... the window opens?! What a wicked building! It's letting the jaguar get you! Imagine being chased around the outside of this wicked fanged building as the wicked fanged jaguar tries to eat you. Ahhh!

mnemonics.meaning: A notebook that is also a record book is an account book or register, showing the records of all the transactions that have gone through.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 帳簿を燃やしてしまうという考えは思いつきませんでした。
I didn’t think of the idea to burn the account book.

mnemonics.meaning: You're so adept! That makes you adept at that thing. Skillful and clever are other ways to do it too.
mnemonics.reading: Remember 旨い, which means "delicious"? Remember how it also means "skillful" and "clever"? It's the same with this word, and the reading is the same as well.

sentences: 話が巧すぎるぜ。何か企んでるだろ？
It’s too good to be true. What are you scheming?

mnemonics.meaning: The great alligator! This can mean both alligator or crocodile, because really, they're not so different, are they? No crabigator, that's for sure.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is a reading you've known your whole life. It's like you were born with the reading, whispering in your ear, ready to emerge at just the right moment... and that moment is now.

sentences: この鰐の置物、邪魔なんだけど。
This alligator statue is in the way.
鰐蟹って漢字、何も見ずに手書きで書けるの？すごいね！
You can handwrite the kanji for WaniKani without looking at anything? That's amazing!
鰐の剥製が部屋に飾ってあります。
I have a stuffed alligator displayed in my room.

mnemonics.meaning: An old tomb is an ancient tomb. They're mostly from the Kofun period, and indeed that's where the period gets its name.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 近年その古墳を訪れる人が増えています。
The number of people visiting the ancient tomb has been increasing in recent years.
このカフェでは、古墳の形をしたケーキが食べれます。
In this cafe, you can eat cakes in the shape of ancient tombs.
古川君は、古墳マニアなんですよ。
Furukawa-kun is ancient tomb enthusiast.
古墳時代は、三世紀末頃から七世紀頃までの時代を言います。
The Kofun period refers to the period from around the end of the 3rd century to the 7th century.

mnemonics.meaning: The chief mother isn't your own mother, but she is the chief of your mother. She's your mother's lady sibling, who has always owned your mom. She's the chief mother. She's your aunt.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for the 母 part is just the first は in はは, rendaku'd. You can also think of your aunt as a sheep, too, if you'd like.

sentences: 伯母はどうして私達の結婚式に来ようとしなかったんだろう。
I wonder why my aunt didn’t come to our wedding ceremony.

mnemonics.meaning: The inscription's pattern shows what brand or make this item is. If the pattern of the inscription is an apple, you'll know the brand is Apple. If it's a Window, you know it's Microsoft. Etc.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the on'yomi reading for the first kanji and the kun'yomi reading for the second. Luckily, you've learned them both already so you should be able to slap them together and know the reading of this word!

sentences: 後どれくらいでお客さんに推奨する銘柄が決まりそうですか。
How much longer will it take you to decide which brand to recommend to your customer?

mnemonics.meaning: Accidentally but naturally (as in nothing was set up artificially before). So, the accident was a true, natural accident. This kind of accident is something that happens by chance, unexpectedly.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 空港で偶然、高校時代の友人に会ったんですよ。
I unexpectedly ran into a friend from high school at the airport.

mnemonics.meaning: Transport and exit these goods from here (by transporting them). Take it away. It's time to carry out.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 日曜の夜七時までに全ての作品を搬出する必要があります。
By 7pm on Sunday, we need to take out all of our work pieces.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Hoe Ra (ほら), the version of Ra who carries a hoe around, is using said hoe to dig out a cave for himself, to provide shade from the sun (despite being the god of sun). He digs digs digs and then sits in his nice cave, hoe in hand.

sentences: その薄気味悪い洞は、村の北外れにひっそりと佇んでいました。
The eerie cave stood silently in the outskirts north of the village.

mnemonics.meaning: A cave hole is a cave or den.
mnemonics.reading: The reading of 洞 is one you've learned. The reading of 穴 isn't one you've learned, though. So, think about how you go inside this cave, only to find yourself covered by some red goopy liquid. You think it's blood, but luckily it just turns out to be ketsup (けつ). If you want to be less formal, you can also use the kun'yomi and say ほらあな, but then you'd never learn that reading for 穴, and where's the fun in that?

sentences: その洞穴で躓いて、足首を捻挫しました。
I stumbled into the cave and sprained my ankle.

mnemonics.meaning: When you flip your idea of something, you're changing how you think about it. That's why this word is change one's mind.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この結婚について、絶対に翻意することがないことを誓います。
I swear, I will absolutely not change my mind about this marriage.

mnemonics.meaning: The chief of this district is that guy, the count. He's also the earl of another district, and the chief of yet another.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the はく reading you learned with the kanji.

sentences: フグの爵位を伯爵にして、フグ伯って呼ぶことにするのはどうかな。
How about giving Fugu the title of an earl, and calling him Count Fugu?

mnemonics.meaning: A wind that is wicked comes and blows on you. It's so cold, and ends up getting you sick. You now have a cold.
mnemonics.reading: Strangely, the reading for this word is the same as the vocab reading of 風 (かぜ). That's probably going to be the easiest way to remember this, especially since otherwise the reading would be one big horrible exception.

sentences: 「なんで母親の葬式に来ないの？」「風邪ひいてるからだよ。」
"Why aren’t you coming to your mom’s funeral?" "’Cause I caught a cold."

mnemonics.meaning: This is the noun version of the kanji and has the same meaning as well: coloring.
mnemonics.reading: The reading has いろ (like 色) in it, then a ど, so think about an 色 dog, running around coloring things, because that's what an 色 dog does.

sentences: 父の弁当は、彩りについて全く考慮がされておらず、全部茶色だったので嫌でしたね。
I didn’t like my dad’s bento because he never really took coloring into account and all of it was brown.

mnemonics.meaning: A manga genius! For some reason, this is a comic dialogue or two man comedy. Look up "manzai" on YouTube for some good times if you don't know what this is. It's not exactly the same, but 漫 DOES refer to manga, which is a type of comic book. Take the "comic" part from "comic" book, then change it to the "haha funny!" meaning of "comic," and then imagine people doing a dialogue. Then, you have a comic dialogue. Lots of steps, but hopefully it'll get you there.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

sentences: 漫才を見て大声で笑うことはストレス解消になる。
Watching two man comedy acts and laughing loudly relieves my stress.

mnemonics.meaning: When you revise something to make it correct you are doing a correction and revision.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: もし私の日本語に間違いがあれば、その場で訂正してもらってもいいですか？
If I make a mistake in Japanese would you mind correcting it on the spot for me?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji refers to a bundle, but this refers to a counter for bundles. Put this on a number, and you have "1 bundle" or "2 bundles" or even three, oh my!
mnemonics.reading: Saying "1 bundle" and "2 bundle" takes too long, so you decide to call these bundles what they look like: わ for walrus (わ)!

sentences: わっ！ほうれん草一把で九十八円だって。
Wow! A bunch of spinach is only ninety-eight yen!

mnemonics.meaning: The law courts are the courts you visit to get law distributed. The room in which you do this in is a courtroom.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あとどれくらい私達がこの法廷にいることになるか分かりますか？
Do you know how much longer we will be in this courtroom?

mnemonics.meaning: The meaning is the same as the kanji's meaning, crab. If you know this word, and you know the word 鰐 as well... then, well, you know something, though I'm not sure what that something is.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. But you knew that already, didn't you?

sentences: お腹がすいてきた。晩ご飯の蟹が楽しみだ。
I’m getting hungry. I’m looking forward to having crab for dinner.

mnemonics.meaning: A water crystal is just a crystal. I guess crystals are clear and look kind of like water, yeah? That's why it's being referred to as a water crystal, making it really just a crystal.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この水晶は大中小の三つの大きさがあります。
This crystal comes in three sizes; small, medium, and large.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 私の息子は、ある日突然、堰を切ったように日本語をペラペラ話し始めたんです。
One day, my son suddenly started speaking Japanese fluently, as if a dam in him had been broken.

mnemonics.meaning: A feeling of inscription is the feeling one gets when something so strong happens that it's like the feeling gets inscribed into your soul. This is something that left a very deep impression.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私達は彼のピアノの演奏に深く感銘を受けました。
We were deeply impressed by his piano performance.

mnemonics.meaning: Someone who is bad but also clever (賢い) is someone who is using their cleverness for evil. When you refer to clever evil people, usually you describe them not as "clever" but as devious, cunning, or other things.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is 悪い and 賢い combined together into one word. Be careful of the rendaku.

sentences: あいつは悪賢い男で、猫かぶりが大のお得意なんだ。
He’s such a cunning guy and he’s very good at feigning innocence too.

mnemonics.meaning: Drifting down the stream. Something that is doing this is drifting. It could also be the drift of something.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 帆が折れて、ヨットが海に漂流し始めた時は、ちょっと悲観的でしたね。
When the mast broke and my yacht started drifting out to sea, I got a little pessimistic.

mnemonics.meaning: Something has drifted to the point where it has arrived. Where do drifting things arrive? They arrive on shore (as they drift on top of water). That makes this word drifting ashore.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 傷ついた赤ちゃん鯨が、とある砂浜に漂着するところを想像してみてください。
Imagine a wounded baby whale drifting ashore onto a sandy beach.

mnemonics.meaning: You look at this inscription then you look at that inscription and you notice that each one is an individual inscription.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: うちの家族の銘々がその写真を持っています。
Each member of my family has this photo.

mnemonics.meaning: The embankment prevents the water from going over the edge. It's an embankment.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 水が堤防を越えそうになっているから、近づかない方がいいですよ。
The water is almost running over the embankment, so you should be careful.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is like the reading of 包み, which means "bundle" or "package." Try to think of an embankment that's made purely from bundles and packages. These 包み (つつみ) are the only thing holding the water in!

sentences: 村長は、堤が切れるのを防ぐため、堤に人柱を埋めることを決意しました。
The village head decided to bury a human sacrifice in the embankment to prevent it from collapsing.

mnemonics.meaning: My interest is stirred up! I'm feeling excitement and stimulation from all this stirring up, in fact!
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 興奮 is one you didn't learn with the kanji, though it's similar. Instead of きょう it's こう, so just think of how whenever you feel excitement, it's thanks to こういち. So just think of こういち exciting you in some way to remember this vocab's reading.

sentences: 止まれの標識を無視する度に、興奮するんです。
Every time I ignore a stop sign I get excited.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember 殴る, which means "to punch"? Well, add on 合う and you've got punches that have come together with other punches. By "come together" I mean your fist is coming in contact with someone's face, and their fist is coming in contact with your kidneys. In other words, this is a fistfight.
mnemonics.reading: The readings come from 殴る and 合う, punched together.

sentences: 俺の連れは今クラブで殴り合いの喧嘩の真っ最中さ。
My man is in the middle of the fist fight in the club.

mnemonics.meaning: Nothing but burdensome. That's all you get out of doing this task. The futility of it is ridiculous. The uselessness is huge.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 言うだけ無駄だよ。フグは決して忠告には耳を貸さないんだから。
Just saying it is useless. Fugu never listens to advice.

mnemonics.meaning: Look below you. These things carry your burdensome weight. All of it. These are the shoes you wear, though in this case they are specifically geta, or Japanese wooden clogs. The clogs themselves are kind of burdensome and hard to wear too, actually, so you can think of it that way as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 駄 is the secondary kanji reading. Instead of だ it's た. Hopefully you've heard of "geta" before. This will make it really easy for you to remember the reading of this vocab word.

sentences: こちらの下駄は二色のお色をご用意しております。
These wooden clogs come in two colors.

mnemonics.meaning: A gloomy energy has filled the room. This makes for a gloomy feeling. One of melancholy.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Careful of the shortening of 鬱 or you'll feel gloomy.

sentences: 伯父は、鬱気で家でふさぎ込んでいる。
My uncle's been home feeling melancholy.
鬱気を吹き飛ばしてくれるような歌ですね。
This song can really blow the gloom away.
今日は鬱気が邪魔をして、日本語を勉強する気になれません。
My depression's bothering me today and I can't get myself to study Japanese.

mnemonics.meaning: Gloom pottery is... well, it's gloomy. And it puts me in a gloomy mood. It's depressing, really!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Be careful of the shortening, and don't be tricked by the hiragana sticking out. The readings of the kanji don't change.

sentences: 「この女マジ鬱陶しいんだけど。」「よー。気にすんなって。」
"This girl is so depressing." "Yo, don’t worry about it."

mnemonics.meaning: Using the grasp meaning of 把 and combining it with grip, you can tell you're grasping at something and then gripping it. I usually grasp then grip at things flying at me, which makes this word mean grasp or catch.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 正直、まだ事態の把握すら出来ていない状況です。
Honestly, I haven’t even been able to grasp the overall situation yet.

mnemonics.meaning: A tomb grave is a grave... or it could be a tomb. Or maybe both.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ツタンカーメンの墳墓は絶対に訪れた方がいいよ。
You should definitely visit the tomb of Tutankhamen.

mnemonics.meaning: A hemp cloth is a hemp cloth.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the individual vocab readings of 麻 and 布 combined together.

sentences: 麻布の服が好きなんだけど、結構お値段が高いんだよね。
I like clothes made of hemp cloth, but they’re rather expensive.

mnemonics.meaning: A wicked devil! Ugh, I hate those things. They're always a hindrance and intrusion. Just imagine a wicked devil hanging out in your house, eating your food, and sleeping on your bed. What a hindrance.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私の邪魔をするな。一人で出来るよ！
Don’t stand in my way. I can do it by myself!

mnemonics.meaning: A sky cave is a cave with sky (open space) in it. This is a hollow, but can also refer to a cavity.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 白熊が木の空洞の中でうたた寝をしていると、近くに木こりがやって来ました。
A polar bear was snoozing in the hollow of a tree and a lumberjack soon came along.

mnemonics.meaning: You've seen that 飢える is "to starve." The noun version is hunger or starvation.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 飢える.

sentences: 飢えに苦しむ子どもたちの写真を見る度に胸が痛みます。
My heart aches whenever I see the pictures of those starving children.

mnemonics.meaning: To excuse yourself from the epidemic, you'll have to have immunity or immunization from the disease.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: いつも微熱とひどい頭痛があるのでお医者さんに行ったら、免疫機能が弱ってきていると言われました。
I went to the doctor because I always have a slight fever and terrible headache, and I was told that my immune system is weakening.

mnemonics.meaning: A shinto shrine courts are the courts of the Shinto shrines. Shinto is often associated with the emperor, which is why this the imperial court. Royal court will do as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 宮 is one you haven't seen before. Just think about how cute (きゅう) this imperial court is. It's a My Little Pony imperial court, or something.

sentences: 宮廷では咳風邪が流行っています。
A chest cold is going around the Imperial Court.

mnemonics.meaning: An epidemic of sickness is going to come from an infectious disease. Perhaps a plague or epidemic of some kind?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その村の人々は、全員疫病で亡くなりました。
Everyone in that village died from the plague.

mnemonics.meaning: Something that is adept but strange in how adept it is would have to be something truly ingenious and skillful. Like looking at alien technology.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ある邪悪な魔法使いが、巧妙に偶然を装って女性に近づきました。
The evil witch cleverly pretended to approach the girl by mere chance.

mnemonics.meaning: If there is nothing wicked about your spirit at all, you are a going to be an innocent and simple minded person.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 子供達は無邪気に笑い合っていた。
The children laughed innocently.

mnemonics.meaning: The emperor empress is the emperor's wife. That's the Japanese Empress, specifically, since 皇 usually refers to the Japanese emperor.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Be careful of the rendaku.

sentences: 彼は誤って皇后であった母親を殺害してしまいました。
He accidentally killed his mother, the Japanese Empress.

mnemonics.meaning: A fluid crystal is a liquid crystal.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 俺の投げたライターがテレビに当たって、液晶画面にヒビが入りました。
The lighter I threw hit the TV and cracked the LCD screen.

mnemonics.meaning: It's so robust and big! Things like this are magnificent, grand, and epic!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: なんて壮大な曲なんだ。凄く感動しています。
This is such a magnificent song. I’m so impressed.

mnemonics.meaning: A manga drawing is manga, aka Japanese comics.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 漫画には色々な形式があります。
There are various styles in manga.

mnemonics.meaning: Take along this summit and move it across a range, visiting more summits. One summit after another you take the summit along to. By covering this many summits, you notice there's a string of mountains. This is a mountain range!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

sentences: 今日の連峰はよく晴れていて見晴らしがいいです。
Today’s mountain range cleared up nicely and the view is great.

mnemonics.meaning: If something is burdensome to the eye (when you look at it), you know that that thing is not good or hopeless. Just look at that burdensome thing with your eye. This can also mean not allowed. Parents say this to their kids all the time.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the readings you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 男の子と旅行に行くのは、絶対に駄目ですからね！
You absolutely cannot go on a trip with a boy!

mnemonics.meaning: Something you do accidentally is hopefully something you do occasionally or once in a while.
mnemonics.reading: For the reading, think about the word 弾 (たま), which means bullet, and how you occasionally shoot people with bullets when you're out hunting... but not too often. Dick Cheney level.

sentences: 偶にぎっくり腰になるんですよね。
I strain my back every once in a while.

mnemonics.meaning: A life horizon is your life, which you're looking out over, all the way to the very end. This is one's lifetime, though it could also refer to one's career. Basically, at the end of it something dies.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 生涯ずっと独身なんて嫌だよう。
I don’t want to stay single my whole life.

mnemonics.meaning: A rut in the road is for some reason an orbit or trajectory. Maybe imagine a big ol' rut in the road. You drive at it at very high speeds, hit it, and fly into the sky at a trajectory that will send you into orbit. Now you're up in space, circling the earth, wishing you didn't drive so fast.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ロケットが軌道に入ったというニュースを聞いて、誰もが喜びました。
Everyone was delighted to hear the news that the rocket entered orbit.

mnemonics.meaning: You look up to someone... twice. That's too many times that you're looking up to someone. They must be pretty amazing for that to happen. Really, though, you're being fooled. This person is pompous and exaggerated. So you think they're cool, but really they're pretending to be more than they are.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, x2 with a しい added on for good measure.

sentences: 仰々しい言葉遣いをする人は嫌いです。
I hate people who use pompous wording.

mnemonics.meaning: Your robust years are the best years of your life! This is the prime of life.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼のお兄さんは壮年期に心臓発作を起こして亡くなりました。
His older brother had a heart attack and passed away in the prime of life.

mnemonics.meaning: You want people to express how they feel about you in a clear manner, so you demand they give you public acknowledgement. You want clear, concise public recognition for all of your amazing talents, skills, and for reaching level 50 of WaniKani. Maybe they'll throw you a parade!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 表彰式には出席せずに帰ってきてしまいました。
I came home without attending the awards ceremony.

mnemonics.meaning: A public announcement is a public notice.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: トーフグの決算公告、もう見ましたか。
Did you already see Tofugu's public, financial announcement?
トーフグは、日本政府の官報にコウイチについての重大な公告をのせることにしました。
Tofugu decided to put up an important public notice about Koichi in an official telegram.
日本には、電子公告規則という法律がありますが、あなたの国はどうですか？
There is a law in Japan called the Electronic Public Notice Regulation. Do you have anything like that in your country?

mnemonics.meaning: We have to examine you during this epidemic... soooo, if you could come over here and just stay here for a long time, that'd be great. Yeah, it's kind of a quarantine, sorry about that.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: オーストラリアの検疫法はすっごく厳しいから、食べ物は何も持って行かない方が身のためだよ。
Australia’s quarantine laws are very strict, so you shouldn’t take any food there.

mnemonics.meaning: I need to consult you on this problem, if I could. I have a question / enquiry I'd like to ask you.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その日は経済財政諮問会議が開催される予定です。
The Council on Economic and Fiscal Policy plans to hold a meeting on the same day.

mnemonics.meaning: If 輝く is "to shine" or "to glitter" think about the noun version of this. This would be radiance. Radiance can come in the form of shining and glittering.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 輝く.

sentences: 私はそのダイヤモンドの輝きに目がくらんでしまいました。
I was disoriented by the radiance of the diamond.

mnemonics.meaning: To assault then crowd. That means you're assaulting a place, then crowding into it, presumably doing a raid on the place.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 殴る and 込む.

sentences: 殴り込みの前に早めの昼食を取りました。
We had an early lunch before the raid.

mnemonics.meaning: A name record book is a book that contains names. That is a register of names or a list of names. Is your name on the list?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼は仰向けに寝転がって、名簿の全ての名前に目を通した。
He laid face up and looked through all the names in the register.

mnemonics.meaning: I believe and look up to a higher power, for I have religious faith.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for the 仰 portion is an exceptional one. Instead of ぎょう it's こう. Just remember, when it comes to religious faith, all you need to believe in is こういち.

sentences: 私はキリスト教を信仰していて、神への揺るぎない思いを持っています。
I believe in Christianity and I have unwavering faith in God.

mnemonics.meaning: If you see the kanji restaurant attached to a place name, there's a good chance that it's a restaurant, especially a traditional Japanese restaurant. It also crops up on the end of other places where you can rest, like inns, those traditional pavilions you see in Japanese parks and temple grounds, and tea houses.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 多くの人が、コウイチは最初のレストランを「トーフグ亭」と名付けるのではないかと踏んでいる。
Many people think that Koichi would name his first restaurant Tofugutei.

mnemonics.meaning: The renewed and revised edition of something is the revised edition.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

sentences: バスの時刻が改訂されたなら、改訂版の時刻表をもらわなきゃ。
If the bus schedule was revised, I need the revised edition.

mnemonics.meaning: Feeling so robust I just want to get up and go! It's so rousing!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼のために金曜日壮行会を予定してるんですが、ご都合は如何ですか？
We are planning a farewell party for him on Friday. Are you available?

mnemonics.meaning: Distribute yourself accidentally to someone. That person ended up becoming your spouse. You distributed yourself to one person a little too much, it seems.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 新しい配偶者を探そうかとずっと考えているんです。
I’ve been thinking about looking for a new spouse.

mnemonics.meaning: I'm stirred up causing me to wake up. I'm stirring and rousing oneself.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼女の一言が、彼を奮起させ、受験勉強をさせた。
Her one word roused him to study for the test.

mnemonics.meaning: A stab from China is sudden and unexpected. Whoa, what? China, why would you stab me? I thought we were neighbors? No, I thought we were friends?!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼女、唐突に車の修理をしてほしいって俺に頼んできたんだよ。
She suddenly asked me to repair her car.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Can also be peak or ridge.
mnemonics.reading: Look up at the summit. It's such a mean (みね) summit. So big, so stormy, so mean.

sentences: 妹と私は、雲の上にそびえる富士山の峰に登頂しました。
My sister and I climbed up to the peak of Mt. Fuji, rising up above the clouds.

mnemonics.meaning: I look up to heaven, and I am taken aback and amazed by it. It's just so amazing.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私は真美がどれだけ速くベーコンを食べれるのかってことにびっくり仰天しました。
I was astonished at how quickly Mami could eat bacon.

mnemonics.meaning: Rut traces left in the road are usually left by tires. This is a tire track left on the ground.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今日は、昨年の英語学習の軌跡を辿っています。
Today I’m going down the path I took to learn English last year.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means accomplish and the verb vocab version is to accomplish.
mnemonics.reading: Everything you've accomplished can be stored in your single little pinky toe (と)... you haven't accomplished that much, apparently.

sentences: 諦めないで！やり遂げるんだ！お前なら出来るよ！
Don’t give up! Accomplish it! You can do it!

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. You already learned 煮る, which is used for when you purposefully boil something. This verb, on the other hand, is intransitive, meaning that it refers to when something is getting boiled or cooked up, with no emphasis on who put the thing in the pot. That's why this verb means to be boiled or to be cooked.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji. Good for you!

sentences: 豆、ちゃんと煮えてる？
Are the beans cooked well?
さて、そろそろジャガ芋が煮えるころだ。
Well, it's about time that the potatoes should be cooked through.
鍋の中には怪しげなスープがグツグツと煮えていた。
There was a mysterious soup gurgling and boiling in the pot.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. While the kanji means flip, the verb vocab version is to billow or to flutter, as in some kind of material (maybe a dress or a flag) billowing or fluttering in the wind. It can also mean to suddenly change your mind, or your attitude, etc.
mnemonics.reading: For something to billow and to flutter, you'll need to ask the here guy (ひるがえ) - that's guy who's here right now - to open the window and let in the breeze.

sentences: 彼女のスカートが風で翻ったのは分かるんですが、その時の彼の心象を翻訳するのは私には難しすぎます。
I know her skirt billowed in the wind, but rendering how he felt at the time is too difficult.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means lamp, so the verb version is to burn or to be lit. Just like what you'd do with a lamp.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who wanted the candle to be lit? Tom (とも) Cruise. He's afraid of the dark so he always wants all the lights and candles in the house to be burning at all times.

sentences: あの部屋に明かりが灯るのを見たんだ。
I can see light burning in that room.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means consult and the verb vocab version is to consult with or to discuss.
mnemonics.reading: You need to consult with a hacker (はか) to solve your hacking problem. Imagine consulting with a hacker, whatever a hacker looks like in your mind.

sentences: この問題は取締役会に諮る必要があります。
We need to discuss this problem at the board of directors meeting.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means drift and the verb vocab version is to drift or to waft.
mnemonics.reading: You're going to drift away. Drifting drifting drifting. Then, you turn into a yo-yo and yell "ta da yo-yo (ただよ)! Not sure why drifting turns you into a yo-yo, but imagine it and don't question it.

sentences: 美味しいみそ汁の臭いが漂ってきて、目が覚めました。
I was awakened by the smell of delicious miso soup in the air.
今日、浅田さんからなんかヤバイ悲壮感漂ってない？
Don't you think some tragic feeling is drifting from Mr. Asada, today?
焼き芋を食べた後のおならは、他のおならよりも長い間空気中を漂う気がするよ。
Farts after eating roasted sweet potatoes seem to hang in the air longer than normal farts.

mnemonics.meaning: 尽きる is "to exhaust." 尽くす is when you're doing the exhausting of something, which makes it to exhaust or to run out.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 尽きる.

sentences: 「これ、明日までにできるかな？」「わかりました。最善を尽くします。」
"Can you do this by tomorrow?" "I see, I’ll give it my best."

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means look up to and the verb vocab version is to look up at or to look up to.
mnemonics.reading: Personally, I look up to the color 青 (あお). Literally and figuratively. I love the color blue, so I look up to it and respect it. Also, I look up at the sky and it's blue.

sentences: 色んな人から、彼の指導を仰げば間違いないと言われましたが、それは明らかに間違いでした。
I was told by various people that if I looked to him for guidance it could be trusted, but that was clearly a mistake.

mnemonics.meaning: 溶かす is "to melt something" and that makes 溶ける to melt (where something just melts, and you're not doing the melting).
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 溶かす.

sentences: あの光り輝く星々が、夜空に溶けるのを想像してみてください。
Imagine that the glittering stars are all melting into the night sky.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means regret and the verb vocab version is to regret or to mourn.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 悔しい.

sentences: ガンガン響く頭と共に目を覚ます度に、前日の夜飲み過ぎたことを悔やみます。
Whenever I wake up with a pounding headache, I lament drinking too much the night before.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means threaten and the verb vocab version is to threaten.
mnemonics.reading: I'm going to threaten you with your life if you have a bad odor (おど). Imagine someone with a bad odor, then threaten them.

sentences: その教師は何名かの男子生徒を刃物で脅したとして解雇されました。
That teacher was fired because he threatened some male students with a knife.

mnemonics.meaning: Flip the translation of a word from one language to another. That is the translation of that word (or phrase, etc).
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ちょうど君の翻訳を見させてもらってたところだよ。
I was just looking over your translation.

mnemonics.meaning: To carry you and transport you. That's a form of transport. Could also be a carriage, which is also a form of transport.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

sentences: このレストランには、食事やその他の細々したものを運搬するためのミニエレベータがあります。
There is a mini elevator used to transport food and other small things in this restaurant.

mnemonics.meaning: Things that transport and send you places are forms of transportation.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 搬送作業時に左肩を脱臼してしまいました。
I dislocated my left shoulder when I was doing conveyance work.

mnemonics.meaning: The chief father isn't your own father, but he is the chief of your father. He's your father's older brother, who has always owned your father. He's your uncle. This word can be used for your mother's brother too, but in both cases he has to be the older brother, not younger.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this is an exception, at least the 父 part is, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember: Your uncle is a very religious man, he is the chief, after all. Whenever you see him he's always shouting, "Oh Jesus! (おじ)" at the sky. Your uncle and Jesus are pretty close.

sentences: 伯父は銀行員です。
My uncle is a banker.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This is a long reading for such a short word! Think of something being wicked. Evil, even! But what is wicked? It's the side of the island... but only the side. It's the 横島 (よこしま).

sentences: 神様は私の邪な心を見透かしていらっしゃったんだわ。
God saw through my wicked heart.

mnemonics.meaning: The eddy river isn't so much a thing as it is a famous place. We're talking about Yodogawa. It might be better to look at the reading to learn the meaning. Look up this Osaka Prefecture river if you'd like more info.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is 淀 plus 川. Be careful of the rendaku.

sentences: 汚い水にも怯まず、彼女は淀川で泳いだ。
The dirty water didn’t stop her swimming in the Yodogawa.
